His Excellency the Governor-General having retired-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Clerk, I remind the Senate that the time has come when it is necessary for the Senate to choose one of its members to become President. I propose Senator Sibraa, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Sibraa do take the chair of the Senate as President.
The Clerk-Are there any further nominations? There being no further nominations, in accordance with the Standing Orders, Senator Sibraa is elected President and will take the chair.
Senator Sibraa having been conducted to the dais-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for re-electing me for what is now a third time. I am conscious of the high honour that you have bestowed upon me today. I am very much aware of the responsibilities attached to the office of President. It is not an easy task to preside over a Senate in which no one party holds a majority. However, I will continue to endeavour to treat all sides with fairness and without prejudice. I hope that, with the assistance of all honourable senators, we will all work together in a way that will reflect credit on the Senate and on our parliamentary system of government. I again thank you very much, and with your permission I shall occupy the Chair.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I congratulate you on your re-election yet again as President of the Senate. Having experienced your three years as President of the Senate, I am sure that your re-election reflects merit rather than numbers or anything else. When we last met in this chamber a number of speeches were made about your merits and the fairness which you showed as President of the Senate, and I believe that those speeches came with equal force from both sides of the chamber. We congratulate you on your re-election and, on behalf of all senators, I express the wish that you preside as well as you have done in the past. We wish you every success during this term as President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Opposition senators, I also wish to congratulate you, Mr President, upon your re-election. You would no doubt have noticed that it was unopposed. We believe that you have been fair and impartial. We believe that you have held your high office with dignity and also with a personal touch, and we think that both are important. As one who does not travel much, I also acknowledge the international work you do, particularly with the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, which enhances the standing of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: There are two incidental matters I wish to briefly mention. We on this side of the chamber recognise that on some occasions Government Ministers are unhelpful to you. I would simply like you to know that if you need to deal with disrespectful Ministers, you have our full support. The second matter is that, of course, some outside this place may not realise that your office is also one of high administrative function. Some concerns have been expressed on this side of the chamber about some administrative matters, which we intend to pursue, but I assure you that that will be done in a constructive way.
Mr President, we wish you well and assure you of the ongoing respect that we hold for your office and for you personally.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I congratulate you on your re-election as President of this House. We note that the fact that you did not have any opposition holds you in very high stead and indicates that you are recognised for your fairness in the chamber. We wish you all the best.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I wish to join in the congratulations which come to you in your re-election. We note your comments about the difficulty of presiding in a chamber where the Government does not necessarily have a majority. We hope that your spirit of cooperation and fairness is mirrored in our actions and responsibilities in this chamber. Your experience is met both here and internationally, as Senator Hill has said. This is going to be a particularly important year for you, and I know that you will bring further honour to this chamber and this Parliament as the year progresses. Congratulations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I congratulate you on your unanimous election to the office of President of the Senate-although, speaking personally, it would have been far more convenient to me to have known that you were being nominated unopposed.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, you have displayed a fairness and a degree of discernment which is befitting the high office you hold. As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Appropriations and Staffing, I am confident that the matters to which the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) referred will continue to be considered by you in the best interests of this institution, rather than otherwise. I note that in the press a number of pressures are being applied for substantial changes to procedures of the other place to be made. No doubt they will be applied here, and I am confident that you will consider those matters in the best interests of the institution.
I congratulate you and convey my desire that this place operates efficiently and assure you of my full confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also congratulate you, Mr President, on your re-election. I have really appreciated your fairness in undertaking your tasks and look forward to your good management of the Senate continuing in the future.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful to those senators who have spoken-Senator Button, Senator Hill, Senator Powell, Senator Boswell, Senator Harradine and Senator Vallentine-for the remarks that they have made on this occasion. In reflecting on these remarks, I am conscious of the responsibilities of the office of President in this chamber and in the wider context in which a presiding officer is required to carry out these responsibilities. I also appreciate the standards of fairness which were set by my predecessors, and I shall strive to maintain these high standards.

INTERJECT.PARA: During the last Parliament there were a number of procedural highlights, which included the first revision of the Standing Orders since 1903; the third joint sitting of both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament to fill a casual vacancy; the passing of the Parliamentary Privileges Act; the disqualification of a senator; consideration of electronic voting; the conduct of Question Time; and the televising of the Senate and its committees.

Today we are making history with the first television coverage of these proceedings. There will undoubtedly be many more challenges and changes facing the Parliament. For example, during this session you will be involved in the most significant development in the role of the Senate committee system since it was established 20 years ago. The Senate has adopted new procedures for the reference of Bills to legislative and general purpose standing committees. It is envisaged that this will ease the pressures of the legislative program on the chamber's time and enable a closer examination of detailed provisions of legislation.

The past year has seen significant developments in the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff. A major project to computerise Hansard operations has been undertaken. This project comes to fruition today when, for the first time, material for the Daily Hansard will be transmitted electronically to the Government Printer after having being processed within Hansard.
I note the words of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) about the administration of the Parliament. I can assure him that I will always consult with Opposition senators.

For the benefit of the unusually high number of new senators, I have made clear throughout my time as President that my door is always open and I welcome the opportunity to discuss matters of concern with all senators.
In conclusion, I again thank you for placing your trust in me. I will tackle the task with enthusiasm and in a way of which I trust honourable senators will approve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to inform honourable senators that His Excellency the Governor-General will be pleased to receive the President and such honourable senators as desire to accompany him in the Members Hall forthwith.

The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair, and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to report that, accompanied by honourable senators, this afternoon I presented myself to His Excellency the Governor-General as the choice of the Senate as President and His Excellency was pleased to congratulate me upon my election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Victoria-Leader of the Australian Democrats)-I seek leave to make a short statement relating to the leadership of the Australian Democrats.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to inform the Senate that after a nationwide ballot of all Australian Democrat members I have been elected leader of the Australian Democrats and Senator John Coulter has been elected Deputy Leader.

DEBATE.TITLE: ELECTION OF DEPUTY PRESIDENT AND CHAIRMAN OF COMMITTEES

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now proceed to elect a Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to the Senate for its Deputy President and Chairman of Committees Senator Colston, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Colston be appointed Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to the Senate for its Deputy President and Chairman of Committees Senator Crichton-Browne, and I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senator Crichton-Browne be appointed Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further nominations? There being no further nominations, I invite the two candidates to address the Senate.
—Mr President, I submit myself to the will of the Senate.
—Mr President, I submit myself to the will of the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —There being two nominations, in accordance with the Standing Orders a ballot will be held. Before the Senate proceeds to ballot, the bells will be rung for four minutes.

INTERJECT.PARA: The bells having been rung -

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Senate will now proceed to ballot. Ballot papers will be distributed to all honourable senators, who are requested to write upon the paper the name of the candidate for whom they wish to vote. The Clerks will now distribute ballot papers to honourable senators. The candidates are Senator Colston and Senator Crichton-Browne. I invite Senator Jones and Senator Reid to act as scrutineers.

INTERJECT.PARA: A ballot having been taken-

TALK.START.PARA: —The result of the ballot is as follows: Senator Colston, 41 votes; and Senator Crichton-Browne, 35 votes. I declare Senator Colston elected Deputy President and Chairman of Committees in accordance with the Standing Orders.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I thank the Senate for its support and for the confidence it has shown in my ability to carry out the duties of Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I regard my election as a great honour. I also thank my party colleagues in the Caucus for supporting my nomination for the ballot that we have just concluded. It is interesting to note that I was first appointed a Temporary Chairman of Committees 12 years ago tomorrow. I held that position continuously, and it is comforting to know that after all those years I no longer have the tag of `temporary'.

SPEECH.PARA: I offer my commiserations to Senator Crichton-Browne. It is unfortunate that when two senators vie for the one position only one can be successful. I look forward to serving the Senate loyally and, in doing so, being a loyal Deputy to you, Mr President.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Colston on his election as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. As Senator Colston pointed out in his remarks, he has had 12 years service as Temporary Chairman of Committees, so in the Senate we are used to having him in the chair. I think honourable senators will agree that in chairing Committee meetings of the Senate, Senator Colston has discharged his duties with fairness, impartiality and in a cool manner. I congratulate him on his new post and wish him well in the term ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of Opposition senators, I also would like to congratulate Senator Colston on his election as Deputy President. We recognise his commitment to the committee system. We recognise that he has been a dedicated chairman, albeit one with whom we have disagreed on some occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to remind Senator Colston that he has a hard act to follow. David Hamer left a legacy of reforms as well as a record of dedication to the job. He also left a reputation of having been totally fair to all sides of the chamber, no matter what the circumstances. We wish Senator Colston well. The Opposition, of course, will seek to be constructive and helpful to him in the exercise of his duties.

Before I sit down, and without any disrespect to Senator Colston, I have to say that I am disappointed that the practice that has been adopted in recent years and that has worked so well is not to be continued. The way in which you, Mr President, and Senator Hamer were able to work together over the years, representing the two major parties in this chamber, demonstrated a responsibility to the Senate and to the institution of the Parliament that went beyond partisan politics. The way in which you worked together demonstrated that it could be done and helped you, Mr President, in what was spoken of this morning-that is, the somewhat difficult circumstance of managing the Senate with the numbers as they are at this time.

Therefore, I am disappointed that under their new leadership, the Australian Democrats have obviously decided to depart from the practice that they had previously followed. In some ways I guess it gives some credence to those who see them as simply slipping towards becoming yet another faction of the Australian Labor Party, perhaps replacing the somewhat discredited socialist left that has been corrupted by the spoils of office.

I also want to say that this is not a one-sided expression of disappointment. I would have thought that the Australian Labor Party, as the party in government, would also recognise the value of having somebody from the Opposition as Deputy President, particularly in view of the experiences of recent years. Its members may be somewhat short-sighted in having reached the conclusion they reached in the last couple of days, but that was clearly a decision for them to make. Having expressed those sentiments of disappointment that the Senate will now be a different place, I would not like to be misunderstood. Senator Colston has our total support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of the Australian Democrats I congratulate Senator Colston on his election as Chairman of Committees and, indeed, as your Deputy in this place. Senator Colston remarked on his long term of office as a Temporary Chairman of Committees. In one respect, at least, we share something in common in that I lead a party whose presence here was for many years seen rather wishfully-on both sides-as possibly temporary. We have made it clear that we are not temporary any more. I must say, Senator Colston, that after your long years of experience as a Temporary Chairman, I congratulate you on not being temporary any longer.

SPEECH.PARA: I have served as a Temporary Chairman of Committees on the same panel as Senator Colston and have benefited from his advice from time to time as, I believe, have many other temporary chairmen. I certainly wish him well in his term of office and wish you well, Mr President, in your relationship with Senator Colston in his role in the new Senate.

In reply to Senator Hill's comment, I point out that times do change. The Senate does change. There are many changes here today-new faces and new appointments of many kinds. I think we can all choose to make those changes positive or negative. Certainly my colleagues and myself are determined that all of the changes today will be positives for this chamber, this Parliament and this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Colston on his election as Deputy President of the Senate. Senator Colston has, of course, a great deal of experience which will stand him in good stead in his new office. Apart from being a Temporary Chairman of Committees, he has been a chairman of an Estimates committee, a very difficult Estimates committee at that. I found him most fair and, indeed, not so much an embarrassment to the Government as a champion of the rights of senators to exercise their function of audit and control over executive government decisions and executive government expenditure. As such, I feel that that will stand him in good stead in his position as Deputy President. He is a fair man, and I expect that that fairness will carry on to his position as Deputy President.

SPEECH.PARA: Mention has been made about former Senator David Hamer, his predecessor. David Hamer made a number of proposals, but those proposals did not quite get up until it was time for him to depart this chamber. Senator Colston's job is not going to be easy because the new committee system, whereby Bills are to be referred to standing committees of the Senate, will be a real test for the Chairman of Committees-that is to say Senator Colston, the Deputy President. He will need the support of all honourable senators, including government senators, to ensure that that committee system works and that there is money to ensure that it works.

I would like to commiserate with Senator Crichton-Browne. Of all of us, Senator Crichton-Browne has been the defender of this institution. He has spent a great deal of time and effort on that, for which we are very grateful. I personally hope that he will continue to maintain his very vigorous stance, a proper one I might add, in the defence of this institution.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, in a very personal sense I congratulate Senator Colston on his election.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with honourable senators in congratulating Senator Colston on his election as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees. I think that Senator Colston and I are now the only Australian Labor Party survivors from the 1975 election in either the Senate or the House of Representatives.

INTERJECT.PARA: I must say that the previous Deputy President, Senator David Hamer, played a very supportive role in the last Parliament. He work ceaselessly and tirelessly for me in that role. I am sure that Senator Colston will continue in that tradition, and I congratulate him on his election.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of the honourable senators to the presence in the gallery of a former distinguished senator and Leader of the Australian Democrats, Don Chipp, and welcome him to Canberra.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR THE HONOURABLE JAMES LUKE CAVANAGH

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 19 August 1990, of former Senator the Hon. James Luke Cavanagh, senator for South Australia from 1962 to 1981.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on 19 August 1990, of the Honourable James Luke Cavanagh, a senator for the State of South Australia from 1962 to 1981, Minister for Works from 1972 to 1973, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1973 to 1975 and Minister for Police and Customs in 1975 places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Mr President, Jim Cavanagh was born on 21 June 1913 in Paddington, South Australia, and educated at the Dominican Sisters School in Adelaide. From 1945 to 1962 he was Secretary of the Plasterers Society of South Australia, and from 1960 to 1962 was Commissioner of the Board of Industry of South Australia. He was elected to the Federal Parliament as senator for South Australia in 1962 and served in that position until 1981. During his time in Federal Parliament he held a number of portfolios. He was Minister for Works from 1972 to 1973, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1973 to 1975, and Minister for Police and Customs in 1975.

If I might just indulge in a very brief personal reminiscence of Jim Cavanagh, I must say that all those who were senators during his time, or during part of the time in which he was a senator and Minister, will recall him as a keen and vigorous debater in this place, a zealous student of the Standing Orders, and a man of considerable intelligence who, as a Minister and debater in the Senate, was always a very cool person, not easily rattled. I think his contribution to the Senate in terms of being a vigorous debater will be characterised for all of us by his gravelly voice, which remains memorable, I think, to everyone who was here at that time.

I think most senators who were here in his day will share those reminiscences of him and share reminiscences of him as a man of considerable integrity. He certainly made a distinguished contribution to Australia during his time in office and, on behalf of the Government, I extend to his family our most sincere sympathy in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on behalf of Opposition senators I wish to join the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in moving this motion and expressing our deep regret at the death on 19 August of Jim Cavanagh.

SPEECH.PARA: I, of course, did not know him personally, as I came into the Senate at the same time as he retired. But it is interesting that a number of my colleagues in the years during which I have been here have said to me that his skills as a debater and his use of the Standing Orders, which have been mentioned, would be a good training ground for anyone who wishes to practice the art of politics in this place effectively. There are many who have said to me that if Jim Cavanagh had had the opportunity of education that so many of us who have come in here in more recent times have had, he could have achieved practically anything in politics. But, even having said that, I acknowledge that his record was one of great credit to him.

He obviously also was clearly a man of compassion. Not only do I know that from the work he did in relation to Aboriginal Affairs, of which I have read, but it can be seen simply by reference to his final speech in this place, when he quoted from the words of Henry Lawson. I remind the Senate of it, because it certainly demonstrates the style of the man. He said:
I was human, only human,
And if in days misspent
I have injured man or woman
It was done without intent.
If at times when stumbling blindly,
Heavy heart and aching brow,
If I said a word unkindly
Then I'm sorry for it now.
Mr President, Opposition senators send their condolences to the family of the late Jim Cavanagh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the National Party with the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and supported by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) in expressing condolences to Senator Cavanagh's family.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Cavanagh spent 19 years in the Federal Parliament. He certainly was not here when I was here, but I do recall hearing his voice over the radio when I was listening to Parliament. He represented the Australian Labor Party, he was a Minister and covered three portfolios, and he served his country well. I extend my sympathies, on behalf of the National Party, to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate the Australian Democrats, also, with the offering of condolences to former Senator Cavanagh's family, and also to note his contribution to the welfare and progress of Australia. Like Senator Hill, I never knew Senator Cavanagh personally, but, as a South Australian, I certainly knew of him. It has already been noted that he came from a working class background, but certainly rose to the very high office of holding a number of very important portfolios in the Senate of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Button said, he was born in 1913 and he had a long career as a plasterer and also in the Plasterers' Union and in the Australian Labor Party before being elected to the Senate in 1961. He took his seat in 1962. I note also that he was a Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in the Whitlam Government, when considerable improvements were begun in the welfare of the original Australians.

Those who have not been in parliament themselves or closely associated with someone in the Australian Parliament have very little idea, I believe, of the sacrifices made, both at the personal level and at the level of the family, in order to advance those matters of principle in which many of us believe and which many of us hold very important. Senator Cavanagh and his family clearly made very significant sacrifices over a very extended period of time-as we have already heard, 19 years. We are the inheritors and beneficiaries of the work of those who have gone before-people such as Senator Cavanagh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, as a South Australian representative of the Australian Labor Party in this chamber and as a friend of Jim Cavanagh's for over 20 years, it is my sad duty to associate myself with this motion of condolence.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim Cavanagh left school at the age of 14 and worked as a plasterer throughout the Depression. He first became involved in politics through the League against War and Fascism, a prominent prewar pacifist group. He actively supported the campaign against Franco during the Spanish Civil War, as far as his pacifism would allow. During the Second World War he continued working as a plasterer, becoming Secretary of his union the year the war ended. Like his father before him, he became a leader of the progressive forces within the South Australian Trades Hall and, at the same time, gained the reputation as an excellent debater and a fearsome advocate before the industrial court. This training held him in good stead during his time as a senator, and he was proud of his ability to match and often master those he referred to as the `legal eagles'.

Senator Button has canvassed the many achievements of Jim Cavanagh in public life and I do not intend to repeat them. I would like, however, to make some brief comments about his career. From the very outset he demonstrated a deep and genuine concern for the needy and underprivileged, and a streak of radicalism which often disturbed the more conservative in this chamber. In his maiden speech he condemned the McCarthyist-style campaign which had been directed against him in the 1961 election and he also defended the right of workers at a Port Pirie smelter to a decent standard of living.

His principles showed themselves in a number of different ways. For example, he attended an anti-Vietnam rally instead of a parliamentary lunch in honour of Lyndon Johnson. It was as Minister for Aboriginal Affairs that he was in his element-a job where he could directly assist one of our society's most underprivileged groups. He was always a quiet man, but no person who ever came into contact with him could question his deep commitment to the Labor movement and to those people it was created to protect.

Jim represented one of the finest traditions of the Labor Party: a tough, uncompromising and unashamedly progressive trade unionist who spent a lifetime in the Labor movement fighting for the rights of workers and for any who needed to have their rights defended-fighting often hard and bloody battles with all the money and power ranged on the other side. On his retirement he was described as one of the last old style Labor warriors of the Left. It was a war of sorts and Jim Cavanagh, for all his pacifism, was well-known as one of the heartiest fighters it produced. He will be missed. My condolences and those of former senators Reg Bishop, Arnold Drury, Jim Toohey, Don Cameron and Geoff McLaren, go to Jim's family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to associate myself with this condolence motion. Those of us who were in this chamber when Jim Cavanagh was also here will realise that in fact his forte in the chamber was his contributions during the committee stages of the debate, when, often to the annoyance of his own side, he would constantly pressurise and question Ministers about particular clauses of legislation. I do hope, incidentally, that when this new committee system commences to operate full consideration will be given to the rights of individual senators to continue to do that in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: In that regard he was a very independent minded person and he was able, on a number of occasions which we recall, not to trip up but to have Ministers rather flabbergasted and searching for words to explain the meanings of particular clauses in legislation. He was certainly missed when he left this chamber-there is no doubt about that. I would like also to convey my condolences, through you, Mr President, and through the Senate, to the family of Jim Cavanagh.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President I wish to be associated with the motion of Senator Button in relation to the death of former Senator Cavanagh. He was a person whom I held in high regard and for whom I had a great deal of respect. His association with me developed on the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I draw to the attention of the Senate the final two paragraphs of my report as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances in June of 1981, when I was the Chairman and he was the retiring Deputy Chairman. I said then:

SPEECH.PARA: On 30 June 1981, Senator the Hon. J. L. Cavanagh will retire from the Senate and consequently from his position as Deputy Chairman of this Committee. Senator Cavanagh has been a member of the Committee for 12 of his 19 years as a Senator for South Australia. The Committee wishes to place on record its appreciation of the inestimable services of Senator Cavanagh to the Committee and the Senate.

His clear understanding of the operation and principles of the Committee, his profound knowledge of the principles of statutory interpretation, and his concern to ensure that there is no derogation of the law-making responsibilities of the Parliament have, in the Committee's view, been among the major features of his contribution to the Parliament as a whole, and through it to the people whom he has so ably represented for almost twenty years.

At this stage I would like to confirm that since then those views that I expressed then have not changed in my mind. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee and this Parliament certainly have missed his wisdom, common sense and experiences. I recall that one of the first things he pointed out to me was the difficulties that I, as a government member of the Committee, would face in dealing with the members of my Executive because, as those who have served on that Committee would be well aware, the Government members are in an extremely difficult position in that they are going to their own Ministers and telling their Ministers to change the regulations that they made. He well appreciated the difficulties which Government members of that Committee had and then when we went into opposition I think I made it clear to Australian Labor Party members of that Committee that they would have similar difficulties and I am pleased to see that they have overcome them so well while in office.

I might say that he was, as my friend Senator Archer said a few moments ago, a formidable foe, especially in this chamber; as Senator Harradine has mentioned, in committee stages of Bills he was likely to trip a Minister at any tick of the clock and especially Ministers who in the Senate were only representing a colleague in the other chamber. It was not uncommon for the debate on a Bill to be adjourned while that Minister went back and discussed with the Minister in the House of Representatives what changes should be made to the legislation.

He also, I might mention-and this is something that I think all new senators should be aware of-would regularly draw our attention to the need to ensure that laws were made by legislation rather than by regulation whenever it was possible because, as he pointed out to me when I first asked, `Why do you say that?', the problem is that we can only disallow a regulation whereas we can amend legislation. Let us say that someone came up with a schedule for, as an example, compensation for an injury and let us say it was $20,000 but the Government wanted to increase it to $30,000. But we wanted it to be $40,000. If the Government brought in a regulation increasing that amount to $30,000 all we could do would be to disallow it. We could never disallow an increase from $20,000 to $30,000 so we would be stuck with the regulation. Whereas if the Government did it by way of a schedule to the Bill then when it brought in the amendment to the schedule we could propose that it be $40,000 or some such thing. It is something that, unfortunately, far too often we overlook.

People used to ask, `How good would he have been if he had had legal training?'. Let me say that so far as statutory interpretation was concerned he could never have been better than he was. He was absolutely brilliant at understanding the meanings of words and notwithstanding the fact that he--

TALK.START.PARA: —Not confused by legal training.

—Yes, I write that in the Hansard for Senator Crichton-Browne, because I agree with it. In any event he was certainly brilliant, and if he had done a law course he may very well have been wealthier but he certainly would not have been any better at statutory interpretation.

SPEECH.PARA: I might mention one personal matter and that is that I came into this place in December 1976 when both Houses were still suffering from the conflict between the then Government side and the Opposition side arising out of the events of 1975. There was some considerable anger expressed on the part of Labor members of parliament about the events of 1975, as honourable senators will recall and, as I discovered 12 months later, that conflict was still going on.

I arrived here in December 1976 and I ended up at some sort of Christmas function in the old Senate club room, with my wife. I walked in and I met a fellow who turned out to be Georgie Georges. I was talking to Georgie Georges and he said, `Sit here', and I sat there. After a while-and I did not appreciate it, but with hindsight I now realise I was sitting in a faction of the left wing of the Labor Party-this fellow, whom I later came to know was Jim Cavanagh, started to talk to me. Then I saw him turn to someone and he said, `Who is this bloke?'. After all, I had only been there about two days. Someone then told him, and Jim said, `Bloody Liberal', and he turned his back on me and we did not have another word that night. But later, after serving with him for many years and admiring and respecting him, we counted each other as friends at the end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to support this condolence motion for Jim Cavanagh. As a former secretary of the Australian Labor Party in South Australia and assistant secretary and official for nearly 15 years, I knew Jim Cavanagh through the Labor Party. I never, of course, had the opportunity to serve in the Senate with him, but I knew him through the Labor Party and through his contributions to the Party and the community in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Jim Cavanagh could be described very clearly within South Australian Labor Party terms as a working-class hero; or, to use that other phrase that has occasionally been used, Jim Cavanagh deserved the description of being the cream of the working class-certainly as I would describe it.

The remarkable thing about Jim Cavanagh, which other members have alluded to, is that he had a very poor formal education, and yet I have never seen a person debate better in the forums of the Labor Party in South Australia. Once one got used to the gravelly voice and the slow delivery, one realised that the substance of what he was saying was usually compelling and overwhelming. Though I occasionally disagreed with Jim Cavanagh, as we all disagree from time to time in politics, in debate within the Party I respected absolutely his view and his integrity. I remember one occasion when I was the minute secretary for a State convention. Someone had moved the gag resolution and I had missed who it was, so I looked round and saw Jim Cavanagh sitting there and I just wrote his name in the minutes. At the beginning of the next session he stood up and very simply said, `I see the minutes have said I moved the gag motion. It is wrong. I have never moved a gag motion in my life and I never will. I do not believe in gagging debate in the Labor Party'. It was a salient point to me, to my own embarrassment.

One of the things that should be remembered about Jim is that in the late forties and early fifties, when he was secretary of the Plasterers Union in South Australia, he represented workers at Woomera. He was refused entry to Woomera because he was considered a security risk by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. I always think it is one of the great ironies of democracy in Australia that in the Whitlam Government he became Minister for the Federal Police and in charge of the security arrangements of such places as Woomera. It is an absolute insult to Jim Cavanagh's integrity that anybody could believe that he could be a security risk for Australia. It was a marvellous outcome that in the end he became a Minister of the Crown and a Minister in charge of security at Woomera.

Jim had an utter commitment, an absolute commitment, to the underdog. That took him at times into strange alliances. Though Jim was a very committed trade union official in South Australia, within the Labor Party in South Australia we had a system of voting called the `card vote', which gave a preponderance of voting strength to the trade unions of which Jim was a part, yet for 30 years in the Labor Party he consistently argued against the system of the card vote because he believed it gave too much power to too few people, including himself. He did not believe that that was the best way the Party should run. It was interesting that when he made those points many of his union colleagues never heckled, never argued with him, and that was because of their respect for his view and his standing.

I want to pass on my sympathy to Jim's family. It is with regret that I will not be able to attend his funeral on Thursday because of commitments I have as Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, but I certainly will take the opportunity to express personally to his family the fact that in my view Jim Cavanagh was one of the half-dozen great Labor members South Australia has produced in 100 years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very sad to learn of the death of Jim Cavanagh. Jim was a veteran in the Parliament when I arrived in this chamber following the 1975 Federal election. In those days the Liberal-Country Party coalition had a majority in the Senate. It was therefore quite valuable for Labor members to be able to fall back on the experience of people like Jim Cavanagh. I was always impressed with his detailed knowledge of Bills which came before this chamber. Had he been given the educational opportunities now available to many young people, he would have been one of our leading lawyers.

SPEECH.PARA: I can remember vividly one occasion on which I was speaking to what I thought was an unacceptable piece of government legislation-and I hasten to add that it was of the Fraser Government. A note suddenly appeared before me telling me to `wind up', and dutifully I did so. Jim leaned back from his seat in front of me and said, `You'll get lots of notes like that in this place. My advice is to ignore them'.
I learned a lot from Jim Cavanagh. As well as his being a colleague, I regarded him as a firm friend. I extend to all his family my sincere condolences on his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my colleagues by expressing my condolences. Jim Cavanagh was one of the old school of the Labor Party. My greatest memories of him were of a continual sparring between him and Reg Wright. Jim was a bush lawyer, as he called himself, but he was certainly equal to Reg, who had all the qualifications under the sun-and equal to him on so many occasions.

SPEECH.PARA: We could always be sure, when a Bill came before the Senate, that both Jim and Reg had done their homework on it well. As Senator Harradine said, they both excelled at the committee stages, and when they both left we missed them very much. We found that many Bills were never dealt with as thoroughly as had been done by them previously.

For some reason or other, Jim and I became quite friendly, and I recall one amusing incident. One night very late, after a prolonged debate, Wally Lee, our old transport officer, said to Jim and me, `Come on, get in that car, you're both going in the same direction'. It happened to be a Mercedes, and Jim said, `I'm not getting in any capitalist car'. The next car was a Holden, and I said, `Oh, come on, just try it for once'. Anyway, I persuaded Jim to try the Merc. Half-way home we had an accident which swirled the car right round. Jim got off scot-free and I had a couple of fractured ribs. Jim always blamed me for the accident and I assured him that if we had been in the Holden we would have both been written off.
I would like to extend my sympathies to his family. I know that we have missed him in this place, and I am sure he will be missed by his many friends.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would simply like to add my remarks to those of my colleagues on the death of a South Australian senator, Jim Cavanagh. When I came into Parliament in 1983, Jim Cavanagh had been retired for two years and he featured, along with a number of other retired senators, in many of the stories that were then told about that time and particularly about times past. Indeed, it is probably a line I can offer to many senators today: it is the role of new senators to listen to the stories told and retold, often quite differently, about the events and the particular heroes or villains from times past. So I would have to say that when I came into the Senate Jim Cavanagh, in his own lifetime, had become the stuff of myth and legend.

SPEECH.PARA: In reading about the man, I am particularly struck about his closing comments in the Senate when he referred to his own lack of formal education. There are two things I would like to say about that: firstly, many Australians of Jim Cavanagh's age did not have access to a formal education and were never able to develop their full potential. As has been said many times already, Jim Cavanagh was one of those people who argued passionately for the rights of the poor and the workers in Australia, not only from his own experience but also from his lifelong commitment to establishing those rights for people. Secondly, notwithstanding his lack of formal education, Jim Cavanagh succeeded splendidly. His lack of formal education did not, in the end, restrict him-at least in this place.

However, I think we can say fairly that the challenge of lack of formal education, coupled with considerable intelligence, did mean restricted opportunities for many people. I am pleased that the Australian Labor Party provided one path of opportunity for Jim Cavanagh to make his considerable contribution in this place on behalf of ordinary Australians. I join in messages of sympathy to his family.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I wish to associate myself with the condolence motion. Reference has been made this afternoon to the late Senator Cavanagh's knowledge of the Standing Orders. I admit that he did have a great knowledge, but I must say that I think it was his interpretation of the Standing Orders that at times kept the Senate tied up for long periods, which is a very good tactic when in opposition.

INTERJECT.PARA: I will just recall a personal story: I had been a member of the Senate for approximately six months. I went to Jim Cavanagh and said, `Jim, I would like some advice. I find the time in the chamber when you are in opposition pretty boring, and I find the committee work very stimulating. What should I do about that?'. He said, `Well, you should put forward a notice of motion to change the Standing Orders so that can take place'. So I did that. When it came up for debate, of course, the first person on his feet to completely demolish my argument was Senator Jim Cavanagh. He then went on to lecture me about how the voters sent me here to sit in the chamber and not to sit down in committee meetings.

Jim Cavanagh did have a very strong belief that he should spend as much time as possible in the chamber. I think that is one of the reasons why he became such a formidable debater in this chamber. He will be sadly missed, particularly by the Australian Labor Party in South Australia. I wish to associate myself with the condolence motion to his family. I invite all honourable senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF FORMER SENATOR ALBERT PATRICK FIELD

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I inform the Senate of the death on 1 July 1990 of former Senator Albert Patrick Field, senator for Queensland in 1975.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Button) proposed:

That the Senate expresses its regret at the death, on 1 July 1990, of former Senator Albert Patrick Field, senator for the State of Queensland during 1975, and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion. Pat Field was a senator for Queensland for only 99 days during one of the most turbulent times in Australia's constitutional history. It is unfortunate that he is most well-known for the difficult circumstances surrounding his appointment, for this tends to cloud the other achievements of his life.

SPEECH.PARA: He was a french polisher by trade, a staunch unionist-in fact, he was State President of the Federated Furnishing Trade Society in Queensland-and a longstanding member of the Australian Labor Party who was proud to represent his fellow workers. The Opposition extends its condolences to his family in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button). Senator Field came to this Parliament under very controversial circumstances. I understand the sensitivities that the Australian Labor Party would feel at a time like this. Nevertheless, he was an elected member of the Senate and he served for 99 days. He left a family of, I think, a son and a daughter. On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I convey my sympathies to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be expected that I would speak to this condolence motion. Those who remember the history of Federal politics of 1975 would be aware of the way in which I was involved in the Queensland Parliament's selection of a replacement for Senator Bert Milliner, who died on 30 June of that year. That casual vacancy was filled by Mr Albert Patrick Field.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not intend to speak in any detail today about the controversy of Mr Field's appointment. Enough has been said and written about that particular event. Nor do I intend to comment today on any aspect of Pat Field's acceptance of the Queensland Parliament's nomination. I have decided on that course of action for two reasons. Firstly, I believe in the old dictum de mortuis nil nisi bonum: Do not speak ill of the dead. In saying that, I do not imply that under other circumstances I would speak ill of Mr Field. That would not be my style. Secondly, if there were a villain in Pat Field's appointment, it was not Mr Field himself but a group which had no care for the political conventions of the time.

I shall, however, make some remarks about the consequences of Mr Field's appointment. To some extent the consequences were also the result of Mr Bunton's replacement of the retired Senator Murphy. Whichever appointment was the principal catalyst, however, less than two years after Mr Field came to this place by way of the Queensland Parliament, the people of Australia approved three changes to the Australian Constitution. The aim of one of these changes was to alter section 15 to ensure that Senate casual vacancies are filled by persons of the same political party as that represented by the deceased or resigned senator.

Unfortunately, the changes made to section 15 of the Constitution did not go far enough. This became quite evident after Senator Grimes resigned and our colleague Senator Devereux, then Mr Devereux, was nominated by the Australian Labor Party to take his place. Stalling tactics in the Tasmanian Parliament delayed Senator Devereux's entry into this chamber until the election following the double dissolution of 1987. Preventing a situation like that occurring again is a matter which must be addressed if Australia makes further changes to its Constitution.

Mr President, for some, death is mercifully swift. For others, death occurs only after a long period of suffering. Mr Field did, in fact, have an enduring illness and we can only be saddened at the tragic way in which he died. Although his name will feature in future histories of the Federal Parliament, particularly in relation to the controversial circumstances of his appointment, Mr Field, the man, is now at peace.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish very briefly to associate the Australian Democrats with the condolence motion for Albert Patrick Field. The particular circumstances to which reference has already been made occurred before all of us were in the Senate and certainly before even the Australian Democrats were thought of as a party, so we cannot comment on that. It is indeed sad that a person who has been elevated to the high office of senator should pass on. As Senator Colston has pointed out, and from my understanding of newspaper accounts, former Senator Field suffered a considerable disability for quite some time before he died and that is, indeed, very sad. We offer our condolences to members of his family and add our condolences to those made by other party speakers.

—I desire to associate myself with the condolence motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), supported by the Opposition and by the other speakers who have contributed. I take this opportunity of conveying my deepest sympathy to the relatives of Senator Albert Patrick Field.

PETITION.TITLE: Mining and Export of Uranium
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your petitions request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Durack (from one citizen) and Powell (816 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Very Fast Train Proposal
PETITION.PARA: To the Federal Government of Australia,

We, the undersigned, respectfully request that: the Federal Government initiate a National Inquiry, constituted under the Environment and Protection Act, (impact or proposals) 1974, be undertaken immediately into the Very Fast Train proposal.
The V.F.T has the potential to completely restructure South East Australia.

A well resourced inquiry on a federal level is needed to examine the short and long term implications including the Multi-Functional Polis proposal and all aspects of Transport and Land development in Australia. Clearly giving terms of reference broad enough to examine Real community need and explore all transport and land development options.
This is a National Issue deserving an indepth National Inquiry.

PETITION.TITLE: Foreign Bases, Uranium Exports and Arms Exports
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled the pet- ition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
We the undersigned deplore the recent decision of the Federal Government to extend the lease of the United States bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar.
We condemn the continuing export of uranium from Olympic Dam/Roxby Downs.
We also condemn the easing of restrictions on Australian Arms exports.
Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government:
* to cease exports of uranium to France while that nation continues to test nuclear weapons in the Pacific.
* To begin the process of bringing foreign bases under the United Nations control for arms control verification purposes.
* to restore controls preventing arms exports to countries engaged in conflict or where the risk of conflict is likely.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will every pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Warships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President of the Senate and senators in Parliament assembled:
We, the undersigned citizens of Australia demand that the Australian Parliament ban nuclear-armed and nuclear-powered foreign warships from entering Australian ports and Australian waters.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senate and the Senators in Parliament assembled; the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call for;
the establishment of a parliamentary inquiry into the Family Law Act.

PETITION.TITLE: Air Landing Fee: New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament:

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the proposed air landing fee for regional and commuter airlines landing at Sydney Mascot Airport during peak times discriminates severely against people in rural Australia and will force many airlines to either revise their schedules, cancel flights or increase passenger fares to cover this additional financial impost of the Federal Labor Government. And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws the attentions of the Senate to our opposition to any attempt to close the National Acoustic Labor- atory at Southport.

PETITION.TITLE: Papua New Guinea and Bougainville

We, the undersigned participants of the 1990 ASPAC conference for disarmament, security and co-operation in the Asia-Pacific region call upon the Australian government:

SPEECH.PARA: We the undersigned concerned citizens, wish to bring to your notice our dissatisfaction with the present legislation pertaining to the Family Law Act. Whilst the Act, as it stands might make divorce easier, child custody has become another `possession', along with property settlement on the matrimonial battleground.

The Family Law Act concerns all citizens, and society as a whole has a responsibility to ensure that children caught between this conflict are not socially deprived of equal access to both parents wherever possible, a human right necessary for normal childhood development.

Accordingly, we request that representations be made on our behalf to bring to the notice of the legislature our dissatisfaction of the Family Law legislation and further request urgent action be taken to address a totally unacceptable situation.

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That a Parliament House Advisory Panel be established, to advise the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives on proposals for signi- ficant works in Parliament House.
(2) That the following provisions apply to the Panel:
(a) the Panel shall consist of 8 members, as follows:
(i) the President or a person appointed by the President to represent the President, and one other person appointed by the President,
(ii) the Speaker or a person appointed by the Speaker to represent the Speaker, and one other person appointed by the Speaker,

(iii) the Minister designated by the Prime Minister as the relevant responsible Minister or a person appointed by the Minister to represent the Minister, and one other person appointed by the Minister,
(iv) the Leader of the Opposition in the House of Representatives or a person appointed by the Leader to represent the Leader, and

(v) a chairman who is an eminent member or former member of either House of the Parliament, appointed by the President and the Speaker after consultation with the Minister and the Leader of the Opposition;

(b) members shall be appointed to the Panel within 15 days after this resolution has been agreed to by both Houses of the Parliament, and shall hold office until the expiration of 15 days after the first meeting of the House of Representatives after the general election next occurring after this resolution has been so agreed to;

(c) members of the Panel, other than those appointed under paragraph (b), shall be appointed within 15 days after the first meeting of the House of Representatives after a general election of the House, and shall hold office until the expiration of 15 days after the first meeting of the House after the next ensuing general election;

(d) a member of the Panel other than the President, the Speaker, the Minister and the Leader of the Opposition may resign the member's office by writing addressed to the President and the Speaker, and the consequent vacancy shall be filled by the President, the Speaker, the Minister or the Leader of the Opposition, as the case requires;

(e) a member of the Panel appointed by the President, the Speaker, the Minister or the Leader of the Opposition may be removed from office, and the consequent vacancy filled, by the President, the Speaker, the Minister or the Leader of the Opposition, as the case may be;
(f) if the chairman is not present at a meeting of the Panel the Panel may elect a member to act as chairman for the purposes of that meeting;
(g) the quorum of the Panel shall be 4 members;

(h) questions before the Panel shall be decided by a majority of members present and voting, including the chairman or member acting as chairman, and if the votes on a question are equally divided the chairman or member acting as chairman shall have a casting vote; and

(i) the President and the Speaker may determine allowances for expenses and fees to be paid, out of an appropriation provided by the Parliament, to members of the Panel, other than the President, the Speaker, the Minister and the Leader of the Opposition, in respect of their service as members of the Panel, and a copy of each such determination shall be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after the determination is made.

(3) That all proposals made to or by the President or the Speaker, or the President and the Speaker, for works in Parliament House, which are designated by the chairman, in accordance with guidelines determined by the Panel, as significant works, be referred to the Panel.
(4) That a copy of guidelines determined in accordance with paragraph (3) be laid before each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after the guidelines are determined.

(5) That the Panel provide to the President and the Speaker a report on each proposal referred to the Panel, and draw attention to any aspects of the proposal the Panel considers significant, particularly having regard to the effect of the works referred to in the proposal on the architectural and aesthetic integrity of Parliament House.
(6) That it is expected that, in considering a proposal, the Panel will obtain and have regard to appropriate advice.
(7) That the President and the Speaker attach to each report provided to them a statement indicating:
(a) the action required to give effect to the proposed works referred to in the report;
(b) whether that action is the responsibility of the President or the Speaker or of the President and the Speaker; and
(c) whether it is intended that that action be undertaken.

(8) That a copy of each report and attached statement be laid before each House of the Parliament within 15 sitting days of that House after the provision of the report of the President and the Speaker.
(9) That a message be sent to the House of Representatives requesting its concurrence in the foregoing resolution.
