The speech read as follows-
Mr Speaker

In moving this resolution today I want to take this first opportunity available to me to inform the House of the view the Government has taken of the situation which has arisen in the Middle East over the past three weeks, and of the measures which we have adopted to meet that situation.

On 2 August Iraq invaded Kuwait. That action has provoked one of the gravest international crises since the Second World War; and it has challenged us to define the way in which the world community will cooperate in the years ahead.

Over the past few years the frightening rigidities of the cold war have dissolved, and the threat of global war between the superpowers has receded. The task for all of us has been to construct a new world order which will guarantee that the end of the cold war will bring an era of peace. That cannot be taken for granted. In the cold war, regional conflicts were contained by the care that each superpower took to avoid confrontation with the other. But now, as the threat of global war recedes, the risk of major regional wars may, paradoxically, have increased.

Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is a tragically clear proof of the new dangers which exist, just as those of the cold war thankfully fade into history. And those dangers are not unique to the Middle East. Wherever we find big armies, national rivalries and reckless leaders, we will find a risk of major war. It is not inconceivable that those conditions could emerge in the Asia-Pacific region in the coming years.

We need therefore to work out how to manage these dangers wherever they may arise. In doing so we are casting back to the era before the cold war began; those twilight years of optimism between the end of the Second World War and the fall of the Iron Curtain.

We find ourselves looking again to the United Nations to uphold the rule of law as the principle of international relations, over the rule of force. The cold war often made the UN look impotent and irrelevant; but as the cold war fades, the UN has moved back to the position its founders intended for it.

In drafting the UN charter, the founders of the UN drew on their vivid and bitter experience of a world sliding into chaos: the failure of the League of Nations in Manchuria and Abyssinia; the appeasement of fascism in Europe; and the catastrophe that followed.

The world has changed a lot since 1945, but I think the lessons of the 1930s, which underpin the UN charter, still hold true today: that international disputes must not be settled by force; that national borders must be respected; and that those who use force must not be permitted to prevail.

Those lessons establish principles that engage our real, tangible interests, not just our sense of right and wrong. The security and prosperity of the world, and the security and prosperity of Australia, will depend in the years ahead on the strength of those principles. And the strength of those principles in the years ahead depends absolutely on the support we give them today. This is the broad framework within which the Government has considered Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, and Australia's response.

Within that framework, Mr Speaker, Iraq's actions are cause for very deep concern. That concern arises from the nature of Iraq's leadership, from the capabilities of its armed forces, and from the nature of the Gulf region itself.

Iraq's Government has, over many years, proved that it is willing and even eager to use armed force to achieve its national goals; and that those goals encompass nothing less than the domination of all its neighbours-Iranian as well as Arab-and the accumulation of greater and greater power at the expense of them. Any who doubt that analysis of Iraqi intentions should ask Iraq's neighbours themselves, in the Gulf and in the Middle East generally.

But the Iraqi Government's ambition has been matched by its ruthlessness-including to its own citizens. In the war with Iran it inflicted years of suffering and hundreds of thousands of casualties on the people of Iraq, for a few miles of ground that it has now surrendered. And in Kurdistan the Iraqi Government gassed its own people.

But the Government of Iraq is not only very ruthless and very ambitious; it is also very powerful. It has one of the largest armies in the world, well-equipped and battle-hardened, and a large airforce. It has a large force of ballistic missiles, a massive chemical arsenal, and a program to develop nuclear weapons within a few years. That power is based on oil. The Gulf remains the hub of the world oil market. Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia alone hold nearly half of the world's oil reserves. That is a very important aspect of this situation, for two reasons.

The first is that Iraq's power would increase dramatically if it could control Kuwait's oil assets, and even more if it controlled Saudi Arabia's. With increasing power would come increasing ambition, making Iraq even more dangerous than it is today.

The second is that any nation which controlled the oil industries of Iraq, Kuwait and Saudi Arabia would be able to dictate oil prices. There can be no doubt what Iraq's pricing policy would be; and there can be no doubt what that would mean for the world's economy-and for Australia's. We may be a net energy exporter, but we import oil, and the markets for our exports depend absolutely critically on the economies of our customers.

I do not intend to go into the merits of Iraq's grievances against Kuwait, nor of its claims to Kuwait's territory. They are irrelevant to the current case; because no matter how strong those claims might be, there can be no justification for asserting them by armed force. As I emphasised to the Iraqi Ambassador when he called on me yesterday, if Iraq does have grievances they should be addressed through proper, internationally recognised and peaceful procedures.

Mr Speaker, I want to turn now to review the steps taken by Australia and by the world community to meet the challenge posed by Iraq's actions. The Government has condemned the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq in the most direct terms. The Opposition has done the same, and I welcome that. I hope that the Parliament, speaking as it does in a very special way for all Australians, will express its condemnation through the resolution we are proposing.

The fact that the vast majority of Australians agree in condemning Iraq's invasion is important. But how much more important is it that governments and people all over the world have felt the same concern, and expressed the same condemnation?

That vital consensus has been reflected in the UN, where the Security Council has not only been able, promptly and unanimously, to pass resolutions condemning the invasion. It has also been able, for the first time, to go beyond that to adopt mandatory and comprehensive economic sanctions designed to compel an Iraqi withdrawal.

Australia is committed to implementing those sanctions with full rigour. That will not be without cost; Iraq has been a major export market for Australia. But we have no choice; economic sanctions are an essential element of the international effort to restore peace and stability to the Middle East. The economic and security costs of shirking that responsibility are much greater than the costs of the sanctions themselves.

But the sanctions will not do the job by themselves. They will act, slowly but surely, to force Iraq to give up Kuwait. In the short term, however, there has been an urgent need to deter Iraq from taking even more territory. In the days after its invasion of Kuwait, Iraq built up huge forces on the border with Saudi Arabia. All the evidence pointed to a plan to invade Saudi Arabia and seize the Saudi oilfields which lie close to Kuwait on the shores of the Gulf.

To respond to that very rapidly emerging threat, it was necessary to act quickly. At the request of Saudi Arabia, the US deployed forces swiftly to deter further Iraqi aggression. After an historic meeting of the Arab summit other Arab states quickly followed, providing forces of their own to help defend Saudi Arabia from Iraq, and endorsing the US contribution.

This operation appears to have succeeded in deterring an Iraqi invasion of Saudi Arabia, and those involved deserve credit for it. I want to be absolutely clear about this-in the absence of such action I believe it highly likely that we would be faced now not with a military stand-off, deeply worrying and dangerous though that is, but with actual hostilities; not to mince words-war.

And this action has therefore provided a framework in which sanctions can do their work. But to be effective the sanctions also need to be enforced. It is at this point that I want now to describe the decisions the Government has taken in deploying ships of the RAN to the Gulf region.

Mr Speaker, this has been a very serious decision. I have left it up till this point in my statement today because I have wanted to place our decisions in the context in which we made them; that is, in the light of our assessments of the broader international framework, of the particular characteristics of the Iraqi regime and of the Gulf region, and of the significance of all of these for Australia.

Australia values its alliances, but we recognise that increasingly we will have to look to our own security. As a self-reliant country, we may need to depend more and more in the years ahead on the principles of the UN charter to protect our interests. So we are not sending ships to the Gulf region to serve our allies; we are going to protect the international rule of law which will be vital to our security, however our alliances may develop in the future.

After carefully assessing Australia's interests, the nature of the job to be done, and our ability to do it, the Government decided to deploy two guided missile frigates and one replenishment oiler to participate in the enforcement of the UN embargo against Iraq.

Many other nations have reached or are considering the same decision. So far the United States, United Kingdom, France, Canada and the Netherlands have announced that they will deploy ships to act in support of the embargo against Iraq: while Italy, the Federal Republic of Germany, Greece, Spain, Belgium and Portugal are considering what role they can play.

In joining this group, Australia is acting within the UN charter to assist Kuwait-at its specific request-to exercise its right of selfdefence, under article 51, through implementation of the UN economic sanctions.

Like most members of the group, Australia believes that the establishment of a UN force acting under the UN flag as provided for explicitly by article 42 of the UN charter would be the best framework for enforcement of the UN's economic sanctions, and we are working hard to achieve that.

There is as well a number of alternative mechanisms available under the UN umbrella to enhance direct UN involvement in the operation of the force. These are being explored. But we believe that the interests of the UN itself, as well as the dynamics of the situation in the Gulf, require that we work within the very clear legal framework provided by article 51 until these issues have been resolved.

We believe that to refuse to participate unless a fully-fledged UN force was established would make it less likely that such a force would be established, and more likely that the economic sanctions, and the UN itself, would fail in meeting Iraq's aggression.

Our ships are being sent to the Gulf region with a clear mission to assist in enforcing economic sanctions. The Government has defined the way in which our ships will operate in fulfilling that mission-identification, contact, interrogation and warning-and discussions are now under way with other participants to establish coordination procedures and areas of operations. The operational roles of our ships will be reviewed if necessary to ensure that they meet the aim of the deployment, but our discussions so far have confirmed that their current roles will allow them to fulfil their mission with a sensible minimum of force. Any change to the role proposed for the Australian ships would necessarily involve the widest possible consultation.
I should make it quite clear here that our ships are not being sent to the Gulf region to attack Iraq. They will engage Iraqi armed forces only in self-defence.

Our ships are well-suited to the role we are asking them to fulfil. They are the most modern ships in our fleet, equipped with state-of-the-art weapons and sensor systems, and manned by crews that are as good as any in the world. The same type of ships are serving with the US Navy in the Gulf region at the moment, on similar tasks to those our ships will perform.

Nonetheless, we must acknowledge that the deployment of ships is not without danger, and this has been reflected in the conditions of service for personnel on the deployment which were approved by Cabinet last week.

Apart from this deployment in support of the UN sanctions, the Government will continue to pursue diplomatic approaches to the problems in the Gulf. We do not seek conflict-absolutely the opposite. We will support any constructive diplomatic effort to resolve the crisis. But that cannot be through turning a blind eye to aggression, and it cannot succeed without the maintenance of pressure on Iraq. Our Foreign Minister, Senator Evans, will leave tomorrow for Europe where he will consult the Chairman of the Economic Community before visiting Cairo, New York and Washington for discussions on the crisis, returning to brief Cabinet before the end of next week.

Mr Speaker, it is of course difficult to say how the crisis in the Gulf will develop from here. Logic should dictate that the Iraqi regime-recognising that it has aroused the anger of the whole world, that it will not be allowed to succeed, and that it will pay a high penalty for its adventurism-should withdraw from Kuwait and allow the restoration of the legitimate government there. The Government earnestly hopes that that might happen, and happen soon. But the behaviour of Iraq's Government gives no ground for optimism.

In particular, we are all appalled by the actions of Iraq's Government in detaining foreign nationals-including Australians-against their will, and in particular the contemptible practice of placing them as human shields around Iraq's arsenal of offensive weapons. In the language of the resolution, this is an outrage against all the norms of international law, international conduct and human decency. Any mistreatment of these people will be a stain on Iraq's Government for ever.

About 150 Australians are among those being held in Iraq and Kuwait against their will. The Government, through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and in cooperation with our friends, is doing all it can to help and advise these people. We cannot simply, by some action of our own, restore their freedom. But we can and will take every action open to us-consistent with our principles-to persuade the Government of Iraq to do so.

The only solution to the crisis created by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait is for Iraq to withdraw from Kuwait and to release all foreign nationals. We hope that will happen, but we cannot assume that it will happen soon. The embargo will take time to work. It would be wrong of me to hold out hope of an early breakthrough. What we need is clarity of purpose, and firm resolve.

Mr Speaker, before concluding I want to make it plain that the Government does not condemn the people of Iraq. We condemn the actions of their Government. The peoples of Australia and Iraq are not inherently hostile to each other. There remains at this fundamental level the basis for cooperation once the present crisis is satisfactorily resolved. The responsibility for resolving the crisis lies totally in the hands of those who brought it about-the Government of Iraq.

The language of the resolution which the Government proposes be adopted by the Parliament is crystal clear. It embodies in plain terms all the elements of attitude and approach to the crisis which I have described as being appropriate for Australia. It reflects our convictions as a people and our interests as a nation.

Australia is geographically distant from the crisis. But our interests are real and they are important. We have a real stake in supporting proper norms of international behaviour between nations in the post cold war world which is emerging. We have a real stake in doing what we can to prevent the Middle East from being engulfed in a widening conflict. We have a real stake in the affairs of a region which provides the vast bulk of one of the commodities most vital to the health of the international economy.

Our policy must continue to be governed by a clear-headed recognition of those interests and by careful and responsible consideration of the means open to us to protect them. The adoption by the Parliament of this resolution will send a valuable signal-a signal of clarity and of firmness in Australia's attitude and approach to this extremely important issue. I commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition (4.54)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in Senate (Senator Button). We have agreed that the speech be incorporated because of time constraints and because it has already been read in full in the other place by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke).

SPEECH.PARA: The matter we are debating is of grave concern. There is probably no matter more serious for the Parliament to be considering than that of the decision of the Australian Government to send naval vessels into a hostile environment in support of interests that are vital to Australia.

What occurred earlier this month was an inexcusable invasion of Kuwait. There is no possible justification for what happened. There is no doubt that Iraq felt that it had suffered economically because of a lowering of oil prices by Kuwait and others and that there were disagreements over certain underground oil reserves. But in no way could that justify the invasion that occurred.

Furthermore, Iraq immediately became a threat to Saudi Arabia. There was a threat simply by the positioning of forces on the Saudi Arabia border. But there was also the very real chance that Saddam Hussein was going to go across the border into Saudi Arabia. As honourable senators will be well aware, the principal oil wells of Saudi Arabia are in the north-eastern region of the country.

If that had occurred-and it could have happened within a very short period-it would have put under Iraq's control half of the world's oil capacity. It would have given Iraq and Saddam Hussein the capacity to hold the industrialised world to ransom.

Even worse consequences would have been possible. Without wanting to be too speculative, one would have to wonder what would have been the reaction of Israel with so much of the Arab world coming under the control of the President of Iraq. If Israel had become involved, the chances are that others would also have been involved and the consequences would have been absolutely awful. In other words, what may have been seen in the first instance as a localised dispute could have very quickly got out of control, become a regional conflict and then perhaps an even wider conflict.

The action which was taken by the United States of America, Britain and others, and then by the Australian Government has to be put in the context of Saddam Hussein's record. For months he had been making clear his goal of becoming the undisputed leader of the Arab world. The only language he knows is that of force. He demonstrated that in the invasion of Iran, in gassing his own people and in the summary execution of his opponents. A situation has developed in which a person with that record not only invaded Kuwait but potentially could invade the Gulf states and Saudi Arabia, with real economic and strategic consequences, we believe, for Australia.

In such circumstances we expected the Australian Government to act. We recognised the urgency and stressed that urgency to the Australian Government. We were pleased, therefore, that the Security Council acted as quickly as it did. A moment ago I mentioned the United States and Britain. We were pleased that they were so quickly willing to take action to enforce the embargo determined by the Security Council.

In those circumstances we said on 9 August that Australia and the Australian Government should not stand passively by but that we should look for ways in which we could constructively help our allies in what we believed was not only in their best interests but in ours as well. It might be remembered that we suggested to the Australian Government that it consider putting a proposal to the United States by which we could perhaps relieve United States ships on patrol in the Indian Ocean, to allow them in turn to be deployed in the Gulf area. In other words, without wanting to dictate-because that would not be proper with our sources of knowledge and intelligence-what Australia should do, we nevertheless said that our Government should be looking actively at a way in which we can assist.

Middle East

The following day, 10 August, the Prime Minister made the statement of his determination to send three naval vessels to the Gulf. We said that we supported that decision and in supporting this motion today we are again demonstrating that.

However, from the outset we said of his statement that there was a lack of clarity in what he was seeking of the Australian naval involvement. Senators might remember that in his statement he said that there were a number of goals, a number of missions, for the Australian naval vessels. He said that, firstly, they were being sent to enforce the blockade. Secondly, he said that they would act as a deterrent and, thirdly, as I recall it, he said that they would have a role in helping to keep the sea lanes open. Our concern was the ambiguity of that. We immediately asked whether that meant that in some way the vessels would be linked with the forces that were already being formed in Saudi Arabia-the United States forces that were already taking up positions-because they in turn were there to help deter further aggression by Saddam into Saudi Arabia. Were we in fact sending our forces to play a part in that deterrent? That was unclear.

When the Prime Minister was questioned on this at a press conference, he said that any further decision would be made in Australia at a subsequent time. But it seemed to us, on the information that was then available, that there would simply be one operation, that there would be one operational command and it was difficult for us to understand how, in circumstances that could deteriorate very rapidly, there would be the options open for an Australian captain of a vessel, who was under a unified operational command, to seek further instructions from Australia as to what he should do. This confusion caused us some concern and we asked the Government for further clarity. We did that, not in an effort in any way to undermine what the Government was doing, but because, as I said at the outset, the decision to send ships into a possible engagement of this kind is a grave one-one that we would want to support, but one which the Australian people have the right to understand in full and clear detail.

The position was of course not helped in one way in that a few days later, after a Cabinet meeting, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, went on to say that the role of the Australian vessels was not to enforce the boycott, as had been said by the Prime Minister, but rather to warn. This was not the function that had been clearly made apparent to the Australian people by the Prime Minister. We find that uncomfortable because clearly the Prime Minister had been liaising with President Bush. They had been on the telephone together, and it was immediately after the understandings had been reached and communicated by telephone that the Prime Minister had made his statement to the Australian public. As honourable senators will remember, he made it without Cabinet consultation. He has since told us he made it with the feeling of his Cabinet colleagues and yet, after a Cabinet meeting, Senator Evans announced a very much revised and reduced mission for these vessels. Presumably then Mr Hawke had to go back to President Bush and say that in fact what he had previously offered and undertaken had been subsequently revised.

We find that uncomfortable. We do not think that that is the way in which Australia should be operating its foreign policy, particularly when dealing with such grave matters as this. Of course there have been further instances since of some confusion in the Government's position and regrettably some undermining from within the Labor Party when different factions have advanced different views on whether or not Australia should be involved in this operation and, if so, what should be the limitations. As of yesterday we were even being told through the press that Caucus was of a view that any further engagement should first go to a Caucus resolution. We find that an astonishing concept in these circumstances of great danger-that the Prime Minister should in some way be restricted by having to call together Caucus and gain its consent before he can take any further action.

It seems that this morning Caucus finally decided after faction meetings last night, led by Senator Evans, who I am pleased to hear will participate in this debate, that perhaps there was not wisdom in that idea and the Prime Minister was given due authority to act. We do not think that that process has been helpful because all it has done is encourage the Australian community to believe that what the Government has done is in fact questionable. We do not think it is questionable; we believe that its decision was correct. We do think it would have been much helped if the Prime Minister had called a Cabinet meeting first, determined the details of the commitment and put out a statement that did not have to be contradicted subsequently by Senator Evans.

We further suggest, with respect, that it would have been constructively helpful in these circumstances if the Prime Minister had also consulted the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). This is not something that we often seek but, as I said earlier, in these grave circumstances that were being considered, it would have been more than a courtesy, it would have helped to engender the type of bipartisan attitude that is necessary to give confidence to those men whom we are sending off on this dangerous assignment. But the Prime Minister failed to do that and, interestingly, even right up until today he did not take any occasion to discuss any aspect with the Leader of the Opposition. I find that disappointing.

Even the motion that we will support today limits the Government's ability in some ways to act decisively in response to any future development. It restricts the role of our ships to that of identification, contact, interrogation and warning. In some ways this implies that there is parliamentary approval only for the actions specified in the resolution and if that implication is to be accepted we do believe that it is arguably unduly restrictive. We have supported the Government in good faith; we supported it in its original announcement of sanctions when it obviously accepted the mandatory sanctions that were then imposed by the United Nations Security Council; and we supported it when Mr Hawke made his announcement that naval vessels would be sent. We supported that even though we would have preferred to have had much more detail on such issues as the command structure, rules of engagement and operational control, the extent to which our vessels would be involved in the blockade, exactly what their role would be vis-a-vis American ships or other vessels and whether they would be in the Persian Gulf or outside it. In fact, as I understand it, today Mr Hawke has said that the ships will be stationed outside the Persian Gulf, which is the first time that I have heard of that.

The Government has asked a lot of the Opposition in these circumstances and, despite the ambiguities, we have been prepared to support it. In other words, we would have preferred that the Government had not handled the matter in quite as muddled and confused a way and that the Labor Party had seen the urgency in fully supporting the Labor Government instead of coming out with its heavy ideological baggage of anti-United States, anti-Vietnam War type analogies, thereby sowing doubts, uncertainties and bewilderment in the community at the time when unity of purpose is essential.

Madam Deputy President, there has, I guess, been one good thing that has come out of this crisis and that has been the extent to which the international community has been prepared to act as one to deter aggression-further aggression in this case. The reasonable unity of purpose of the super powers in some ways gives us hope for the future. The fact that the Security Council has been prepared to pass in a short timeframe two resolutions of a mandatory nature also gives us hope. We hope that the Australian Government will encourage a Security Council resolution to enforce the boycott. Perhaps Senator Evans will clarify that matter in his contribution, and tell us exactly what Australia's role is in that regard.

We would prefer this force to be under United Nations auspices, even though we recognise that in the urgency I have outlined it was not possible. There was not time to wait for that resolution. Had we waited for that resolution we would still be waiting. The deterrent would not be in place, certainly as it is applied by the United States, and the consequences could have been horrendous.

As I said, there is that hopeful sign that with the end of the Cold War perhaps the world is now moving into a new era of international cooperation if it can get past this immediate crisis. Our hope is that the concerted and speedy action by the international community has, in fact, put a hold on the developing crisis and has allowed time for a settlement to be negotiated. It seems to me that holding the line was what the international community was seeking to do. Now particularly it seems to me that Arab nations must play a part in looking for an Arab solution within the Arab world that can provide a long term settlement.

The worst aspect of the whole tragedy is that of the hostages and the horrible way in which they are being used as pawns in this conflict. We feel great sympathy for the families of Australians and other hostages who must be existing currently in Iraq and Kuwait in circumstances of great fear. We trust that the Australian Government is doing everything within its capacity, both bilaterally through our powerful allies and through our friends in Arab countries who still have reasonable lines of communication with Saddam Hussein, to indicate that it is not too late to end what is becoming one of the worst experiences in international relations since the last war, that is, the using of innocent people as human shields in a conflict of this nature. I would appreciate hearing from Senator Evans in a definitive way what the Australian Government is doing to get Australians out of that predicament. I would also like Senator Evans to indicate that his Department is receiving the calls of the families and friends of these people and responding to them with the sympathy and sensitivity that they deserve, because there has been some suggestion from families to the contrary.

I will not speak any further, because there are a number who wish to contribute to this debate. In conclusion, I repeat that we support the motion and the decisions that the Government has made. We regret that it has been developed as something of a muddle on its part and we hope that there will be greater clarity in purpose and application in the future in relation to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator POWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset, the Australian Democrats welcome the opportunity that this motion provides for a parliamentary debate on the international crisis in the Gulf and, in particular, on the commitment of Australian troops in that area.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion before us is a long one and encompasses the widest range of issues involved in the crisis in the Gulf. It begins by condemning the invasion of Kuwait by Iraq, and I wish to strongly associate the Australian Democrats with that condemnation and make it clear that anything further that I might have to say should not be construed in any other way other than in the context of a condemnation of that invasion. Indeed, that has been a starting point for us as it has been, I think, for all Australians.

As the next part of the motion points out, there has been concern about threats to the territorial integrity of Saudi Arabia which have led to further actions. I have not seen evidence that such a threat was indeed as immediate or could be taken as given in the way that has been put both by our Government and by other governments around the world and used as a reason for a massive build-up of troops of an offensive nature. Certainly, the kind of invasion that has occurred in Kuwait is as strongly condemned by us as by the Government in the terms of this motion.

The second point in the motion calls upon Iraq to withdraw its forces unconditionally from Kuwait-again we would support such a call-and to facilitate the restoration of the legal government of Kuwait. I wish to point out that that government which was usurped in the invasion has itself a poor record when it comes to democracy. Indeed, it has a record of suppression of a pro-democracy movement in Kuwait itself. The Australian Democrats concur, of course, with calls upon Iraq, as set out in this second part of the motion, to respect the rights of foreign nationals. We must remember that it is not just Australians who are in that area, but also nationals of many other nations around the world.

The third point in the motion affirms the fundamental importance of the United Nations (UN) Charter as the basis for the conduct of international relations and the preservation of peace, an affirmation with which again we would want to strongly associate ourselves.

The motion also speaks of the vital principle of the sanctity of international borders. At this point, while not disagreeing with the point as stated, I believe that some questions do need to be asked, and I believe that this is one of the important aspects of being in a position to debate this issue here. The sanctity of international borders has not always been adhered to and we do not have to look very far into the past or very distant in global terms to see that. We were not faced with a similar motion in this place when, for instance, the United States-I quote here from Professor Fred Halladay from the London School of Economics-`engaged in an equally illegal invasion of Panama earlier this year'. There was no such call in this place for the sanctity of international borders on that occasion. We have to ask: what action did Australia take against the United States for subverting the independent state of Nicaragua for some eight years? We really need not ask what action this Government has taken against the illegal Indonesian invasion and the annexation of East Timor. We in this chamber have been party to the corollary of that action, or lack of action, again motivated by oil, where not only has this country not acted against that illegal invasion, but has actually colluded to the extent of signing a treaty with the perpetrators of that action in the interests of access by ourselves and Indonesia to the oil which rightfully belongs to the Timorese people. So the sanctity of international borders has not always been questioned when it has been violated.

In the area in question, too, we need to look at Israel's occupation of Arab lands since 1967 and Turkey's occupation of northern Cyprus since 1974. Indeed, what action did the West take when in 1980 Iraq invaded Iran, another of its immediate neighbours? It is claimed that in fact that action was approved by many in the West. These double standards should not be allowed to occur again. The sanctity of those international borders should not be violated in this way. We simply want to put on the record the fact that there is a great deal of hypocrisy in that particular stance. Nevertheless, we do not oppose a call for that sanctity to be inviolate.

The motion moves on to welcome the unprecedented action of the United Nations in its condemnation of the invasion and in adopting mandatory and comprehensive sanctions against Iraq to force it to comply with the UN decision. Indeed, this has been the swiftest and strongest action taken, in terms of the economic sanctions applied extremely quickly and very broadly against Iraq following the invasion, and it is a measure of the way the situation in international relations has changed. Because there is now no longer an automatic use of the veto by the Soviet Union against proposed actions by the West, because there is cooperation, because there is glasnost, the UN has been able to act-a United Nations which many times in the past has suffered from the criticism that it had its hands tied behind its back. That is no longer the case. Things have changed and it is regrettable that one thing that has not changed has been the sort of response, the militaristic approach, which has been adopted again by the United States and, subsequently, by this nation upon a call from the United States rather than a willingness to allow the non-military option of sanctions and continuing diplomatic negotiations to have an effect in the Middle East. So, certainly, with those comments the Australian Democrats will support the fourth point in the motion.

Fifthly, the motion supports the Australian Government's prompt action to implement UN sanctions. To become involved in these tough economic sanctions against Iraq, following the invasion, was a strong action particularly by a country with such massive exports into that area. Indeed, I think we demonstrated by our immediate action as part of that United Nations sanction that we are committed to all of those points which precede this one in the Prime Minister's motion. It is regrettable, as I have said, that, having committed ourselves to a military course of action, in addition we have not permitted those non-military options an opportunity to succeed.
It is at the next point that I diverge, on behalf of my Party, substantially from the motion and, indeed, I will move, as an amendment, to delete the next point from the motion. That point is:
... the Senate ... supports ...
the Government's decision to send ships of the RAN ... in enforcing UN sanctions against Iraq ...

As I have made clear, I think already, while agreeing with the other points so far in the motion, we cannot agree that this sort of action should have been taken. It is interesting to look at the Prime Minister's speech on this motion because right at the beginning of his speech he points out that he believes that this invasion of Kuwait by Iraq has challenged us-we, in the international community-to, `...define the way in which the world community will cooperate in the years ahead'. All I can say is that if this is a measure of world cooperation to come in the years ahead, then there is more a sense of deja vu, and that indeed we are not looking ahead. We have plenty of examples behind us, from the past. Indeed, there are many examples in history; there are bitter examples where the word cooperation has been used to mask what has indeed been confrontation and that is clearly what is happening here. The proposition that what we are doing now in the Middle East is defining the way that we will operate in the future and that for some reason because the Cold War is over there is now no deterrent on smaller nations from doing the sort of thing that Iraq has done, is quite a fraudulent approach in this particular situation.

As I have already said, there are plenty of examples of the violation of territorial borders during the time in which the Cold War was still in operation and it is clear that that prospect that there was for some reason an urgent need in a military sense to deter Iraq from taking over more territory has not been proven. The motivation here is very much an economic motivation on behalf of a set of Western economies still very heavily dependent on oil.
The international rule of law is also referred to by the Prime Minister in his speech. He says:
We are going to protect the international rule of law . . .

The question is: who makes that international rule of law? The Australian Democrats believe that as with the economic sanctions, so in the event of any military intervention the United Nations is the appropriate body to enforce that sort of action and to implement, that sort of action. We place on record the fact that, should that have been the case, then we would see it appropriate for Australia to fulfil its international obligation under the flag of the United Nations. It is not accurate to say that there has been no action by the United Nations. A monitoring committee has been established under the same resolution which established the sanctions themselves, and that monitoring goes on. Again, to reiterate, should the United Nations feel that further action is needed, there is no impediment any more to that being a majority decision without a veto necessarily occurring in the Security Council. So that sending off of Australian troops is not supported by the Australian Democrats.

The Prime Minister, in his speech, points first to the fact that the vast majority of Australians agree to the condemning of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait and, again I repeat, the Democrats share that view. But the Australian community is indeed divided on this very question-the question of a deployment of Australian forces. It is in that context that I think it is extremely unfortunate that the Prime Minister chose to make this decision without due process. It is a matter of wide concern in the community that the Prime Minister's decision was made in response to a call from the United States and without recourse even to the Cabinet, but with individual discussions with a small number of individual Ministers.

It is important that we get the processes right in this sort of situation. Should we be sending troops overseas? It is a matter of policy for the Australian Democrats and, indeed, for many years we have been putting forward a private member's Bill to require that the sending of troops overseas is only done by a decision of this Parliament, with an exception for a direct attack on our shores. This is important because of the very point that Senator Hill made when he said he regretted that there had been no direct prior consultation with the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Senator Hill made the point that it is important when there is to be deployment of Australian forces overseas that there is a measure of community support for that. Indeed, we have a whole group of Australian service personnel who still suffer because that was not achieved-the Vietnam veterans.

While the Democrats oppose the deployment of troops in this situation at this time, and in this way, we certainly do not, in any way, condemn any of the individual members of the Australian armed forces whose duty it is to heed the call when it is made. We certainly hope that the Government will see that its action is wrong and will not finally send them to the Middle East. I am encouraged by the comment that perhaps they will not go right to the Gulf. I encourage the Government to keep them in Fremantle. But should they go, we certainly wish them a speedy return and no condemnation whatsoever for their actions as members of the Australian armed forces. The decision is the Government's decision. It is the Prime Minister's decision. We are saying that the process is wrong and that it is very important that due consultation as far as is possible, and as widely as possible, is undertaken and that the Parliament, as a representative of the people, should be involved in these sorts of situations.

The motion supports the continuing diplomatic efforts at the UN and elsewhere. I would stress that the militaristic action which has taken place, and of which we are a part, is an impediment to that continuing diplomatic effort. Quite obviously-this is perhaps the saddest part of what we are facing as a nation now-it is an impediment because the amassing of Western forces, of which we are now a part, creates additional tensions which make the job much more difficult. Of course, now we find that people have been placed in very direct danger in a quite scandalous and outrageous manner. We certainly support a call for a speedy resolution.

We very strongly support the sixth point, which expresses concern for Australians and, indeed, other innocent people, including the people of the Middle East, who will definitely suffer unless by some miracle there can be a very speedy and peaceful resolution.

In the brief time that I have had to look at the Prime Minister's statement, I note that he made the point that Iraq is an extremely strong force in the Middle East and that, therefore, the sort of action that Australia is involved in is an appropriate response. I simply put the points that Iraq is certainly a very strong nation and that that strength, that military might, is a product of arms sales from the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and from France, most of which occurred during the Cold War period as the East and the West competed for influence; and that this invasion provides compelling evidence of the urgent need for conventional force reduction and a great reduction in arms sales, particularly to repressive and aggressive regimes. The fact that Iraq has had easy access to arms supplies, given its appalling record in the human rights area and its military adventurism of the past, is really an outrage. It is now rebounding on the world at large.

From Australia's point of view, it is particularly shocking that our Government was in the middle of an $850,000 sale of engine components to the Iraqi air force, whose most notorious action was to kill 5,000 Kurds with chemical weapons in 1988. The export licence has since been revoked as part of the sanctions. But the questions remain: How was the sale authorised in the first place, and does the Government's professed policy of not selling arms to countries with poor human rights records mean anything at all?

I am concerned by the appeal to nationalism that has been put forward in an attempt to win majority support for the sending of troops into this disturbed area, particularly by the Prime Minister. At the send off for the frigates in Sydney the Prime Minister accused those opposed to the deployment of forces of supporting appeasement. I consider that to be an extremely serious charge and I reject it outright.

The name of Adolf Hitler has been invoked in this debate. There is at least one fundamental difference between Hitler and Saddam Hussein, and that is the imposition of those sanctions. Unlike Hitler, Saddam has suffered the strongest and the toughest sanctions. There has been a cut-off of supplies of war materiels as well, an example of which I have just given. Saddam Hussein has very little domestic industry or resources from which he can compensate for the loss and yet, in that context, this non-military option has not been given an opportunity to work.

The crisis in the Middle East has not been this Government's finest hour. The decision has been rash and unwarranted and does not measure up to the earlier speedy and honourable decision to be involved in the economic sanctions. The Government needs to change that decision. It was never a decision that came before the Australian people. It is a backward move in a time in the world's history when we have a chance to advance, given what has happened with regard to relations between the East and the West. It is a move which the Democrats deeply regret. Nevertheless, we support the terms of the motion, with the exception of the second point in the fifth section. Therefore I move:
Leave out subparagraph (e)(xi).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade)

TALK.START.PARA: —In understanding why the world has reacted as it has to the events in the Middle East, in understanding why Australia has reacted as it has, and in understanding why it is that this Parliament should, hopefully unanimously, pass this motion today, I think it is very important to appreciate the very particular and very acute nature of the threat that Iraq's actions represent, not just to Australian interests but to the interests of this entire world. It is not an appeal to nationalism that I am about to make, Senator Powell; it is an appeal to internationalism, because the nature of the threat, and the nature of the challenge to the world order that has been posed by Iraq's behaviour, is of a very special and acute kind and one that really demands the international reaction that we have so far seen.

SPEECH.PARA: The point can be very simply made. Iraq is not just any old power, any old regional power. Iraq is a country, although not with a large population, with an absolutely formidable military capability. There are over a million men under arms; another 800,000 people are part of a reservist legion; five and a half thousand tanks are at its ready disposal, and a significant air strike capability; there is a massive chemicals weapons capacity combined with a very significant ballistic missile capability; and, worse, a demonstrated willingness to use them.

Iraq has demonstrated a willingness to acquire nuclear capability just as fast as it possibly can. It has a military record of not only using chemical weapons against its external enemies and internal opponents, but also waging aggressive war-war against Iran that has cost already, on the best estimates, one million lives. It is a country that has demonstrated by its assault on Kuwait and by its threatened assault on Saudi Arabia that it simply does not begin to understand what international law or international morality is all about.

Senator Powell and some others have doubted the reality of that threat against Saudi Arabia. All I can say is that, on the best information available to me and to the Government and on the best information available to every other government, not only in the Western world but in the Arab world as well, that has reacted to these events, there was very little doubt in anyone's mind but that that willingness to act was there. The rapidity and size of the deployment of men and tanks against the Saudi border in the immediate aftermath of the Kuwaiti invasion and annexation were proof in themselves of that.

So, too, were the realities of oil in the Middle East. Senator Powell and others seem to regard it as just a little unprincipled, somehow, to even refer to this. But one has to refer to it to understand the nature of the temptation to which Iraq has been exposed and the nature of the havoc to and the devastation of the world order that would be posed were Iraq to succeed in its manifest ambition to gain a stranglehold on the kinds of oil supplies that we are talking about. Iraq itself sits on 10 per cent of the world's reserves. Kuwait sits on another 9.2 per cent. Saudi Arabia has fully 25.1 per cent of the world's reserves. Nearly half of all the oil reserves of the world, 45.3 per cent, is tied up in those three countries.

Similarly, the three countries together have present production capability amounting to something like 20 per cent of the oil being pumped, or able to be pumped, out of the wells of the world. The capacity that that kind of control would create to manipulate prices and thereby the entire world economy is not something for passing or quizzical reference as just another demonstration of how greed or the enthusiasm for money or profiteering will move nations to behave in unacceptable ways. What we are talking about is a fundamental capacity and a demonstrated willingness to use that capacity, to hold the rest of the world to ransom. So it was crucially important that the world responded as it has.

The way in which the world has responded has reflected very much the nature of the interests that have been perceived to be at stake. As far as the world as a whole is concerned, what we are faced with here is, for all the reasons that I have described, a fundamental challenge to the world order-the kind of challenge that was mounted by Japan in invading Manchuria in 1931; the kind of challenge to the world order that was mounted by Italy in invading Abyssinia in the middle of the 1930s; the kind of challenge to the world order that was mounted by Hitler in his invasions and annexations in the latter 1930s in the immediate years before the Second World War-challenges which in each case were not responded to, challenges which in each case the League of Nations and all the rest of the apparatus at the time of the collective security conspicuously failed to be able to address, and challenges which, unmet as they were, produced the slide into chaos and world war that we saw.

It is not an exaggeration, for reasons that I have already outlined, to say that, unless the challenge is met on this occasion, we have the potential for that to happen all over again. Not least do we have the challenge of the precedent that it will represent as far as other significant regional powers are concerned worldwide. This is something we cannot afford to ignore-not just the particular situation in the Middle East and the exercise of regional power and authority there with worldwide significance, but the capability that already exists, that will continue to exist and that will have even greater capacity for exercise in a non-bipolar world of the future of existing regional powers with great relative regional strength.

Unless we respond to this first example, as I have described it, of crisis management in the post-Cold War world by a demonstration of international reaction of a formidable and formidably effective kind, we are establishing a precedent of inaction that will be marked all too well by many other regional powers as circumstances, conditions and situations change in the years ahead.

Of course, there is a direct and immediate Australian interest involved here-not just in Australia's capacity as a citizen of the world, not just in our capacity as a country in a region which we are concerned to keep inviolable, but as a nation in our own right with interests of our own, including economic interests. We have a very obvious economic interest, not only in being able to quickly restore our very large trade with this part of the world but also, of course, in avoiding the kind of devastating impact that manipulation of the world oil market will mean for us. People say that Australia is a net energy exporter, and therefore it will not hurt us. That is to fundamentally misunderstand the nature of our dependence on a full range of resource commodities and the reality that, if there is a massive inflation and change in the world oil pricing scene, that will inevitably result in a slowdown of growth which will impact quite dramatically upon our economic capability and performance.

We have got interests, but the appeal that the Australian Government is making, the appeal internationally that the Australian Government is responding to, is not an appeal of immediate self-interest in that narrow sense; it is an appeal to principles of world order which it is crucially important that we apply. Senator Powell has drawn attention to some examples in the past when the world has not responded with similar unanimity to examples of aggression or annexations. Not all are examples which by any means fall remotely into the category in which she sought to put them, but maybe some of them did. Even if they did, surely the point is that failure to respond in the past cannot in itself be any kind of a credible reason for failing to respond now-not least in the particular circumstances which I have already described.

What is unique about this situation, and what is really unprecedented, is a naked example of a state attacking another state in circumstances where the great powers of the day have agreed on the guilt of the attacking state and agreed, moreover, on the kinds of measures that are needed to deal with it.

Australia and many other countries have responded with criticism, with resolutions, and with expressions of outrage when some things like this have happened in the past. We have not been able to respond credibly or successfully because the great powers of the world have in the past been divided on these issues. On an occasion, in an atmosphere, and in an environment where the great powers of the world are united in their response, and where the cause is as manifestly just as this one is, for us not to respond would be, I believe, the Government believes, and, I am glad to hear, the Opposition believes, an abdication of our responsibility.

The nature of the response that has been mounted should be appreciated for the wide-ranging one that it has been. Not only have we had a series of United Nations resolutions of a fundamental and far-reaching kind, but we have also had a rapid, quick and far-reaching response from many countries of the world-not just simply to apply the UN sanctions in the way that they are required to do under the charter, but also to supply resources and materiel to put, in effect, their respective money where their mouths are.

We have had Canada, the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, and at least seven other European nations at the moment already responding with a supply of ships to the region. We have had, in the Arab world, the extraordinary, unprecedented and unexpected response of 12 out of the 20 Arab League nations voting to send a combined Arab force to the Gulf region to join with the Gulf Cooperation Council states and to join with the Saudis. The Egyptians have sent forces, the Moroccans have sent forces and the Syrians have sent forces.

Only three entities actually voted against that resolution: Iraq itself, Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organisation. The truth of the matter is that there has been an extraordinary degree of unanimity, not only in the Western world but in the Arab world itself. The most obvious way that that unanimity has expressed itself has, of course, been in the application of sanctions-the unanimous acceptance by the UN of the sanctions resolution.

Of course, we have Senator Powell saying, `Why don't we just sit and wait for that sanctions resolution to take effect, to work itself out? Why don't we take note of the difference which exists now from the 1930s and the situation confronting Hitler when there was no such sanctions exercise of a kind which commanded anything like the unanimity that this one does?'.

The truth of the matter is that sanctions were tried in the 1930s and were conspicuously unsuccessful. The reason they were conspicuously unsuccessful was that there simply was not any commitment to back them up with effective enforcement. The truth of the matter is that these sanctions will be unsuccessful unless there is an effective backup of enforcement to demonstrate that. One can say that ships are not going to go into the Gulf region in breach and defiance of sanctions. That is absolute nonsense. They will unless and until there is some very good reason, in the case of ships from many nations, to stop them.

The insurers, to some extent, are stopping trade at the moment, but the insurance premiums are not flowing from the UN resolution as such. They are flowing from the fact that the region has been identified as a war zone as a result of the military presence that is already there. But we have already seen the reality that Iraqi tankers are not going to be stopped by a shot across the bows. In fact, I am advised that there are four Iraqi tankers now steaming towards the Port of Aden in the Yemen which, unless intercepted by the exercise of some appropriate military response, are going to off-load those cargoes and create in the process a precedent that will be well observed by many other countries that have only too many motivations to break the sanctions embargo in question. The truth of the matter is that sanctions will not work. Due to the nature of the dynamics of the real world we live in, they cannot work-unless there is an effective iron fist in that sanctions glove. That is what the exercise is all about.

At the moment the UN has not specifically mandated, through resolutions of the United Nations Security Council or anything else, the exercise of military force. That is, nonetheless, justified by the principles of the United Nations. I have absolutely no doubt-and most international lawyers, certainly in the United States and other countries that are participating in the exercise, have no doubt-that the exercise of military force is mandated by article 51, the collective self-defence provision, of chapter 7 of the United Nations charter. This collective self-defence takes the form, under existing practice, principle and precedent, of allowing nations which are subject to attack-as Kuwait was in this instance-to call upon friendly countries to assist them in any way that is appropriate to deal with the consequences of that attack, to assist them by way of military retaliation; to assist them by way of economic retaliation; or, by extension, to assist them by way of military support for an exercise of economic retaliation. That is a separate, independent, acknowledged and freestanding justification for the exercise of the kind of force that is proposed to be exercised in this case.

The Australian Government acknowledges that it would be desirable were there to be a more explicit and direct UN Security Council mandate for this. We would prefer the whole military sanctions enforcement operation in the Gulf to be a blue flag, blue helmet United Nations operation. We have made that clear. We are being extraordinarily diplomatically active not only in New York but also in capitals of the major Security Council players to try to secure that result. That kind of pressure from Australia and other countries is, I hope and believe, beginning to bear fruit.

It is my understanding that right now in the Security Council in New York a motion is being debated which would in fact give explicit Security Council endorsement for the kind of military enforcement of sanctions that I and the other participating nations in this naval exercise believe to be necessary. I hope that that will bear fruit. A great number of difficulties of a practical, political kind-not a principled kind-confront that. We can only wait and see what the outcome will be, but, certainly, Australia will be very actively pursuing that course. It is something that will be very much in the forefront of my preoccupations as I travel around the world in the next week discussing this issue.

The question of the Australian role needs to be specifically addressed. It was the subject of quite a substantial discussion by Senator Hill in his contribution. I simply make the point in reply that there is no confusion or ambiguity about the Australian response. The initial response to the proposal that we contribute our own resources to this exercise was necessarily of a rather generalised kind. It certainly had not been the subject of any detailed evaluation of the particular operational deployment role that we might be able to play, in particular the role that we might appropriately play in conjunction with other participating nations. The nature of the initial response and the initial announcement was simply in terms of Australian ships going to the area in support of a sanctions enforcement exercise. The nature of that support was left inexplicit.

Cabinet took a major step forward in making the nature of that involvement more explicit last Tuesday in saying that the role of the Australian ships, subject to further review in the light of still further consultations, would be one of identification, contact, interrogation, warning, plus, of course, the role of acting in self-defence were we to be subject to attack. That role has been the subject of further discussion and consideration, as one would expect, in subsequent days. It is becoming even clearer than it was last Tuesday at the Cabinet meeting, following those further discussions, that this role fits perfectly within the kind of operational concepts that are being devised by those who are working out a layered response to deal with this situation.

It is inappropriate for me to go into very great detail about this, but, in short, an interception role is required, a discouragement role is required-which broadly corresponds to that which I have just identified as the Australian position-and there is a lesser role again of simply monitoring. Broadly speaking, those three naval roles coincide with particular areas of operation: a highest level of intensity operation, by way of interception, being required in the Persian Gulf and in the northern reaches of the Red Sea; a lesser degree of `discouragement' type operation being required in the Gulf of Oman and the further out reaches; and the monitoring role being most appropriately contemplated in the context of the outer reaches of the Indian Ocean approaches to the whole Gulf area.

As presently advised, as the Prime Minister has said, the thinking is that this will be a role that Australia can sensibly play, in that second level of activity, in that second order geographical area. That will be the subject of further, more precise refinement between now and when the ships arrive on station. It will be the subject of an extensive technical conference that will be held in the next few days, in which Australia will, of course, be participating. These things will then be able to be articulated much more clearly. But as presently advised, there is no particular reason to believe that our role will significantly change. If it does change, it will be the subject of a Cabinet decision following the widest possible consultation.

Our hope is that in all of this there will be not war but peace in the Middle East: a just peace-not a capitulating peace and not a peace that acknowledges that might can be right and that might can win and reap unjust, wildly inappropriate rewards. That is our hope for our sailors and, above all else, for our Australian nationals that are caught up, as are those from so many other countries, in this horrible crisis.

I can only say in response to Senator Hill's invitation that we are doing everything we possibly can diplomatically to maintain contact with our own people and to make representations to the Iraqis about the iniquity, the enormity and the illegality of the position they are taking in relation to Australian nationals. At the moment we have a consul from Baghdad in Kuwait trying to make that contact. We are giving the clearest possible advice that we can to our citizens through the Radio Australia channel that has been opened up. It is just a situation which, regrettably, we are going to have to continue to monitor and which is unlikely to be able to be resolved, I fear, other than in the larger context of the resolution of this whole question.

All of us participating in this Gulf crisis response hope against hope that there can and will be an honourable, peaceful resolution. There cannot be peace at any price. It must not be peace by way of appeasement. It must be a peace of which we in Australia and in the rest of the world can be proud and which will not create unhappy precedents for the future. I move:
