SPEECH.PARA: It is my privilege to outline to the Senate the Budget proposals of the Government.
Australia has negotiated a difficult transition over the past 12 months-from an economy where spending and growth were overblown to an economy with lower activity and fewer imports.
Tonight I am able to report that we are emerging from this phase in fundamentally better shape having succeeded in this transition.
National Accounts data released tonight with the Budget show that the economy has slowed. The trends are clear-exports are up and imports are down.
The current account deficit is falling and inflation is abating.
Economic policy has worked and is working.
The faith the Australian people exhibited in the Government at the election is now being repaid as the economy adjusts to a sustainable rate of growth without a catastrophic collapse.
This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.
In short, the kind of outcome the Government was seeking, delivered without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession.
An outcome delivered by a Government which kept its nerve in the face of sustained sectional criticism, so as to produce a better result for the community as a whole.
A community which faced these difficulties with a great degree of understanding and forbearance.
An understanding that the reformation of the economy is a continuing and at times difficult task.
And forbearance that has allowed the necessary policies time to succeed.
The Government's task now is to build on that trust towards a more balanced and independent economy.
Tonight's Budget is about just that.
It builds on the fiscal achievements secured to date and maintains fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt.
With a surplus of over $8 billion-the fourth successive surplus-it provides Australia with a period of sustained budgetary discipline unprecedented in its history.
It adds this further $8 billion to national savings to cut the call on overseas savings and hence overseas debt.
But not only does its rectitude provide an advantageous bottom line, it also underpins the fairest array of Commonwealth spending policies in the history of the Federation.

Included in these are the personal tax cuts announced during the election to be paid from January 1 next year costing the Budget $1 billion, as is the fulfilment of the Government's election commitments on childcare, improved services for outer suburbs, and the environment.
Yet these outcomes are provided in the context of a slower economy which has placed additional pressure on outlays and dampened revenue growth.
With a similar surplus as last year, which was a year of high activity, the Budget is set to have a more substantial impact upon Australia and its economy this year.
This is particularly appropriate as the Government has now wound back official interest rates by four percentage points as the economy has slowed.
But we cannot let up on the restructuring of the economy made necessary by the high Government spending of the 1970s and early 1980s and the broken investment of that period.
Like many worthwhile contests, the fight with our economic problems will not be won in one championship round.
It will need to be fought over a number of bouts.
This Budget keeps us in the right financial shape to carry that fight into the 1990s.
BUDGET OUTCOME
Mr President, the Budget will deliver in precise terms, a surplus of $8.107 billion.
This surplus-larger than last year's outcome-has been achieved with outlays and revenue to GDP falling.
This year revenue will fall to only 25 per cent of GDP, well below the last Budget of the Fraser Government.
This has been brought about by the fact that over the Hawke Government's seven years in office we have more than fully indexed the tax scales for inflation.
This Commonwealth surplus will ensure that Australia's public sector as a whole is in balance.

The net public sector borrowing requirement for 1990-91 will therefore be zero as once again the Commonwealth Budget surplus offsets the combined borrowing of all Commonwealth, State and local government authorities.

This means that the whole public sector of Australia will borrow no new money and that total Commonwealth debt as a share of the economy will be cut further to be only a third of what it was five years ago.
OUTLAYS
Mr President, I now detail the outlays side of the Budget.
This year outlays will be cut again to only 23 per cent of GDP, a reduction of 6 percentage points in six years.

These figures underline the enormous task undertaken by this Government to cut back public spending so that the Budget of the Commonwealth of Australia is today as tight and as fair as any in the world.
This is a proud claim for a country which only seven years ago had a runaway public sector brought into disrepute by over spending and abuse.
So great is the transformation, Commonwealth spending is now at its lowest level as a proportion of GDP since 1974, and in three years will be down to the level of the 1950s.
Yet this has been achieved while funding services that either did not exist 20 or 30 years ago, or if they did exist, were much less comprehensive.

Areas such as child care, aged care, the family allowance supplement, schools, universities and environmental programs, are being supported and generously funded today from a Budget of early 1970s size.
It has made Australia a fairer and better place to live while meeting the requirements of broad economic policy.
The discretionary savings undertaken by the Government in this Budget round net to over $1 billion.
I now detail the major decisions.
SAVINGS MEASURES AND NEW POLICY
Mr President, last year the Government announced its Retirement Incomes Policy-a sweeping package of reforms to provide security for all Australians in their retirement years.
To do this, we have totally excluded full-rate pensioners from the tax system, making it more worthwhile for them to sensibly invest their savings to generate extra income.
Yet many pensioners still disadvantage themselves by holding their savings in accounts that pay little or no interest.

Therefore, to encourage sensible savings practice, from March 1 next year the Department of Social Security will assess cash and deposits of pensioners and beneficiaries amounting to more than $2000 as earning an interest rate of 10 per cent.
If the rate of return is greater than 10 per cent, the actual rate will apply as at present.

Because many pensioners retain some savings in a low interest account for day-to-day convenience-running a cheque account for instance-the first $2000 of such deposits will be assessable at the actual rate of interest.
These changes mean a pensioner couple with $50,000 in a bank account earning 4 per cent could be $40 per week better off by being encouraged to put their savings in a higher earning account.

It is also important to appreciate that a single pensioner with no other income would need at least $20,800 deposited, and a married couple $36,400, before losing one cent of pension under these new arrangements.
To accompany these reforms the Government will expand the Financial Information Service for Pensioners so they can take advantage of these changes to improve their disposable income.
This Government has restored the integrity of the social security system.
The Minister for Social Security is tonight releasing a number of statements detailing further measures to tighten the administration of payments.

These include a six-week amnesty during which people who have not notified the Department of Social Security of changes in their circumstances may do so without having to refund any overpayments or face prosecution.
Following the amnesty the Government will implement measures to further tighten administration.
The existing tax file number system will be extended by the Department of Social Security to cover virtually all incometested payments.
This will occur under the strict supervision of the Privacy Commissioner.
These measures will save $120 million this year and $318 million next year.
Mr President, the Minister for Community Services and Health is announcing tonight the most far-reaching restructuring of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme since it was introduced.
Since 1948 this scheme has enabled all Australians to get the pharmaceutical drugs they need at an affordable price.
But today, scientific advances have resulted in a massive increase in the number and variety of health care drugs available.
It took almost 40 years-from 1948 to 1985-for the costs of that scheme to grow to half a billion dollars.
It took only another 4 years for the costs to grow by another half a billion dollars.
And in another three years those costs would have reached over $2 billion were we not to have acted now.
The alternatives are stark: reconstruct the scheme so that it remains fair for everyone, or lose the scheme altogether, so that access to complete health care would only be available to the wealthy.
The measures we are announcing tonight will cut the growth in spending on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme by about $1 billion in the next two years.
Those measures include an increase in the general pharmaceutical charge from $11 to $15 per prescription, with a safety net of $300 after which the price will fall to $2.50, to a maximum of $50.
There will also be a new standard charge of $2.50 per prescription applying to all social security recipients and to all families who receive the Family Allowance Supplement.
This charge will be offset by a $2.50 increase to weekly pensions and a safety net to protect chronically ill pensioners or beneficiaries who require a large number of prescriptions.
These arrangements mean that for all those facing the $2.50 charge for the first time the charge will be at worst income neutral.
Pensioners will be protected by this change, and many will be better off.
Importantly, it will discourage the indiscriminate consumption of drugs.
Mr President, this Government has already implemented landmark income support schemes to help lower income families with children.
However, we believe that in the current economic circumstances the community endorses the view that those who can afford to pay their own way should do so.
As a consequence, from January next year Family Allowance payments will be subject to an assets test.
This will mean that the Family Allowance will be withdrawn only if net assets, excluding the family home and debt, exceed $300,000.

In addition, the income test taper on the Family Allowance is to be abolished so that payments cut out for family incomes in excess of the income limit, currently $57,620 a year for families with one child.
Further, the assets test applicable to the more generous Family Allowance Supplement will be reduced from January 1 1991 from $322,000 to $200,000.
Mr President, through the past seven years we have seen record levels of job growth and we have dismantled the barriers that have prevented many Australians from getting into work.
In the past, opportunities were closed to women for many reasons, not the least of which was the lack of decent and affordable childcare places.
Following the pledge we made in the election campaign, we will double spending on childcare over the next three years with a first instalment of $75 million this year.
And over the next 5 years we will create another 50,000 childcare places.
Mr President, another election commitment honoured by the Government tonight is the abolition of the old unemployment benefit structure.
As from July 1991 unemployment benefits will cease to exist.
In its place will be a short-term Job Search allowance and a Newstart allowance for those unemployed for 12 months or longer.
The Government will provide the opportunities people need to get back to work-and we will insist that they take advantage of these opportunities.
As part of this reform the rate of payment to jobless 18 to 20-year-olds living at home and without children will be reduced from the full adult rate.

A similar strategy of positively encouraging the disadvantaged into self-fulfilling work will be applied by replacing the Sickness Benefit and Invalid Pension with a Sickness Allowance and a Disability Support Pension-a new structure of income support complemented by training and rehabilitation opportunities.

There will also be a more rapid cost recovery of tertiary education charges by increasing the rate of repayment by higher income graduates through the taxation system-the assets test on Austudy will also be tightened.
Mr President, given increasing disparities in home prices between cities, the First Home Owners Scheme is no longer proving an equitable way of assisting home buyers.
It is to be abolished from tonight. The Commonwealth will be providing funds for additional deposit assistance for low income earners to be administered by the States.
Existing commitments under the First Home Owners Scheme will continue to be met.
Mr President, the standard of behaviour of some individuals in Australia's corporate sector has fallen short of what should be expected by the general community.
The Commonwealth Government will ensure that corporate activity will be regulated and supervised in the interests of ordinary shareholders and investors.
From January 1 next year Australia will for the first time have a single corporate regulatory authority-the Australian Securities Commission.
An extra $210 million will be provided over the next four years-resources for corporate regulation will increase by nearly 50 per cent.
Mr President, the Commonwealth believes that the States should carry full responsibility for managing their debt.
Consequently, tonight's Budget incorporates the proposal put at the Loan Council meeting for the States to refinance all maturing debt presently held on their behalf by the Commonwealth.
REVENUE
Revenue as a share of the economy is more than two percentage points lower than its peak of four years ago.
In world terms Australia is now a low tax country.
The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development last week announced that we are the third lowest taxed country in the developed world.
This has been achieved by making the size of government in Australia much smaller, thereby requiring a lower tax share to finance it.

At the same time, the Capital Gains Tax, the Fringe Benefits Tax, the abolition of entertainment as a deduction, the taxation of foreign source income and the abolition of rorts have made the Australian taxation system one of the fairest and most secure in the world.
As a result, we have been able to cut personal and company tax rates.
And as I indicated at the outset, further personal income tax cuts, equivalent to $7.75 a week for a worker on average earnings are included in this Budget.
CRUDE OIL
Mr President, as recent events in the Middle East have emphasised, Australia's oil reserves are a scarce resource that must be carefully husbanded in the national interest.
In order to maximise production and revenue from the Bass Strait field over its remaining life, the arbitrary excise and royalty system is to be replaced with the Resource Rent Tax.
This will result in a substantial cost to revenue in the initial years but will subsequently provide a positive taxation flow.
The Government will also provide a substantial boost to exploration activity by allowing exploration costs to become deductible on a company-wide basis for RRT purposes.
TAX AND THE ENVIRONMENT

Mr President, in the Environment Statement last year, the Prime Minister undertook to review aspects of the interaction of the tax system and the environment. In the past, mine site rehabilitation and the dismantling of oil production platforms have been regarded as capital costs and thereby not a deductible expense.
Tonight I announce that mine site rehabilitation and platform removal expenditures incurred from July 1 1991 will be deductible.

Full tax deductibility to combat land degradation will also be extended to all rural businesses earning income from the land, and will also cover the erection of fences for the prevention of such degradation.
Finally I announce that the Treasury will undertake a review of the taxation treatment of other environment-related capital expenditures incurred by business.
SMALL BUSINESS
This Budget also includes measures to help small business.
From August next year companies with sales tax liabilities of less than $50,000 a year will be able to remit payments quarterly rather than monthly.
And from April 1 next year the threshold for annual instead of quarterly payment of Fringe Benefits Tax will be lifted from $1000 to $3000.
Taxes on business inputs generally will be reduced by exempting from sales tax computers used in manufacturing.
PROVISIONAL TAX

To keep the tax system fair, provisional tax arrangements will be extended to remove scope for high income earners deferring tax payments on wage and salary income at the expense of ordinary taxpayers.
This practice has been particularly prevalent in relation to directors' fees, commissions and bonuses, and short-term, contract employees and will raise $370 million this year.
ECONOMIC CONDITIONS AND
PROSPECTS
As I indicated at the outset, Australia is now emerging from a period of very high but unsustainable economic activity.
One consequence of that phase was a sharp reduction in Australia's unemployment rate.
Now that the economy has paused for breath, unemployment is expected to rise a little.
Even so, the number of people in work is expected to increase over 1990-91.
In other words, we will succeed in doing what we set out to do-to slow the economy without impairing longer-run growth prospects or jeopardising the economic and social advances of recent years.
The commendable incomes restraint of the Australian community is acting to ensure that workers do not price themselves out of jobs during this period of slower economic activity.
At the same time, the historically high rate of business investment of the past two years is finally providing us with the capacity to trade our way out of our troubles.
Fresh statistics released tonight show that as last year progressed a growing proportion of Australia's economic growth was generated by the export and import replacement sectors.
In this financial year, that trend will be even more dramatic.
All of this year's expected GDP growth of 2 per cent will be provided by these net export sectors.
This will in large measure be generated by growth in export volumes of 7 1/2 per cent-the largest since 1986-87.
At the same time our imports are forecast to fall by 3 per cent.
The overall effect will be a reduction in Australia's current account deficit of around $3 billion, with the current account to GDP ratio falling by over 1 percentage point.
And just as the economic slowdown helps our trade accounts, it will also help to reduce inflation.
By June next year the rate of increase in the consumer price index will have fallen from around 8 per cent today to 6 per cent.
That forecast is consistent with an inflation rate for the financial year on average of 6 1/2 per cent.
Of course, the present Middle East situation is a source of some uncertainty-for both the domestic and world economies-and our forecasts have had to assume a higher world price for crude oil.
But it is important to keep this matter in perspective.
Oil is not nearly as large a factor in the world economy as it used to be and, to date, price changes have been much more moderate than experienced at the time of earlier price shocks.
This is important because the inflation outcome relates to our wages policy.
Earlier this year we negotiated a wage arrangement which should see wages grow at 7 per cent in 1990-91.
This was premised on inflation falling to 6 per cent, as we are now forecasting.
If oil prices were to rise dramatically we should of course need to reconsider matters.
But any reconsideration would need to be in the context of reducing inflation while seeking to maintain disposable income.
These are all matters that would be put to the Industrial Relations Commission.
MONETARY POLICY
The economic developments of the past year have established a platform for sustainably lower interest rates.
Official interest rates have been reduced four times this year, moderating the stance of monetary policy as activity and spending have slowed.

In the year ahead we will ensure that monetary policy maintains the right balance so as to prevent a needless falling away in activity and employment and to create the environment where growth and employment can steadily strengthen.
However, our approach to interest rates will be tempered by our on-going concern not to rekindle demand pressures that could threaten progress in cutting inflation and the current account deficit.
CONCLUSION

While prime attention is focused on broad goals to do with the current account, inflation, unemployment and interest rates, it is also important to improve the way our economy functions on a day to day basis.
Much has already been achieved from the floating of the dollar in 1983 to the fundamental modernisation of industrial awards and union structures that is going on today.
Our taxation system now no longer penalises those who invest to produce income rather than speculative profits.
Tariffs have been reduced, encouraging our industries to become more competitive.
Far-reaching reforms are already taking place on the waterfront and in aviation and shipping.
The Government is determined to extend these reforms to other areas where the public sector is involved with industry and business enterprises.

The guiding light will be to make government business enterprises innovative, efficient and competitive to ensure that they are not holding back our industries and are delivering a proper level of services to the community.
This must involve all levels of Government. But make no mistake.
Governments can only do so much.
Private business must also be part of this process.
I cannot over emphasise the commitment required of both the Government and the nation if we are to overcome the deep-rooted structural weaknesses of the economy.
Our problems developed as a result of decades of economic neglect and we will not resolve them quickly.
Australia is not part of any trading bloc.
There is no easy market waiting to comfort us.
The intransigence in the current GATT trade round is evidence of that.
We will have to make it by ourselves.
Fortunately for us, we can.
But we must capitalise on the substantial gains made to date.
The economy has to be able to produce more and not rely so heavily on imports.
Spending will have to be kept in check for a substantial period to create an exportable surplus.
But these goals can only be accomplished if broad economic policy is kept tight.
This Budget will more than uphold its end of that bargain. As I said at the beginning of my speech, it is a Budget that will keep us in the right financial shape as we enter the 1990s.
It will give us a very solid foundation for whatever we as a nation have the courage to undertake.
I commend the Budget to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising, following the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in this debate this evening, on the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), I am deeply conscious of the great importance of this debate. I think it is probably the most important debate in which I have taken part during my term in the Senate. In doing so, I reaffirm the Opposition's strong support for the motion that has been proposed for the actions that have been taken by the Government. I certainly agree with them, and the reasons for those decisions, which were eloquently expressed by Senator Evans in his speech before the suspension of the sitting for dinner. However, I do so with a particularly heavy heart, not because I have any difficulty at all with the decisions which have been made and the reasons for them, but because of the fact that they had to be made at all.

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances which have occurred-the international scene in the Middle East since 2 August-are of such gravity that the actions of the Government, with the support of the Opposition, were clearly necessary. It is pleasing, of course, to see that the international community, as expressed through the United Nations resolutions, as expressed by the support which is coming in various ways from so many countries bear clear witness to the enormity of the threat and challenge to the peace of the world which has been presented by the actions of Saddam Hussein.

The reason, however, for the deep concern that one feels is exacerbated by the fact that until 2 August it appeared as though the world may have been on a new threshold of peace and stability of a much greater order, and with much greater hope for the future, than had occurred at any time in our deeply troubled twentieth century. Indeed, it looked as though one could look forward to an era of peace more like that which prevailed throughout the nineteenth century.

The extraordinary events of the past 12 months culminated in some major developments during the northern summer this year, such as the end of the Cold War; the dissolution of the Eastern bloc; the moves, at great pace and with affirmative discussion towards new security arrangements in and for Europe, resulting not only in a new collective security system for the Western alliance but one probably extending to the whole of Europe itself; and the clear rapprochement between the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation, the Soviet Union and what was the Eastern bloc-because it has now dissolved-all portended this new era.

Unfortunately, the actions of virtually one man-Saddam Hussein-but no doubt supported by people around him, have thrown all those prospects into dis- array and doubt, and have thrown the world back into a state of great uncertainty which is of great concern to us all.

It was in the context of that sad and deeply worrying situation that, fortunately, President Bush of the United States took the lead by the actions which he announced on 9 August. In the meantime, of course, the United Nations Security Council, on 6 August, passed an historic resolution to impose the mandatory sanctions, of an extensive character, as its effort to arrest the aggressive actions of Iraq under the leadership of its President.

The world community has responded to that decision of the United Nations Security Council in a very impressive way. The response to the call for sanctions has been widely accepted in a positive way. Clearly, there is an opportunity, in this case, for a much more effective sanctions regime than probably has been established before. However, as Senator Evans so clearly stated, sanctions in the past have failed, despite their support by the United Nations because, for one reason or another, there has not been adequate enforcement of them.

It was the leadership of President Bush, in giving support to the enforcement of those sanctions-by his statement and then giving, of course, separately, support and a guarantee to the defence of Saudi Arabia-which lead to the situation in which the Australian Government, indeed the Australian Opposition, was faced with that momentous development. Following President Bush's announcement on 9 August, the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, not only supported what had been done-and he had already supported the decisions of the United Nations and of President Bush-but also called for something more than simply verbal support for these decisions and said that there was action that would be and should be required.

To the credit of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and those whom he consulted-we now know, of course, that it was not the full Cabinet; nevertheless, he conducted consultations with some of his Ministers-the decision was taken on the next day, 10 August, to send the naval force; that is, the two frigates and the supply ship to the Middle East. This is referred to in the motion. As the Prime Minister said at the time, they will go there to enforce the blockade. That is the reference by the Prime Minister to the United Nations sanctions. The Opposition responded immediately-naturally it is not something that we had not considered, and we were fortunately in a position to respond immediately-and supported that decision announced by the Prime Minister to send Australian Navy ships to deploy in the Gulf region for the purposes of enforcing sanctions. The Prime Minister used the word `blockade'.

Clearly, our vessels are going to the Gulf region to protect these most important principles of international behaviour and international law. They are going there to operate with other countries in an act of collective opposition to the naked aggression of Iraq under Saddam Hussein, and, of course, they are going there because our trade and political interests require a response to the Iraqi aggression.

It is very important to emphasise those features. They are clearly decisions which Australia has taken under the best judgment of its Government and of its Opposition. They are the very solid and independent reasons which we have exercised in our own right and not because we are making some knee-jerk reaction to the fact that President Bush had promptly taken the decision-as notable as it was-giving leadership to the world in this regard. Nevertheless, our own decisions have been taken for those very good and clear reasons which I have mentioned and which Senator Gareth Evans also clearly enunciated in his speech before the dinner adjournment.

I want to make a few comments on the fifth arm of the Government's motion. It is the one which, from the speech made by their Leader, Senator Powell, before dinner, has apparently caused trouble for the Australian Democrats. I understand that an amendment is to be moved by the Democrats to delete the support for the limb which reads:

The Government's decision to send ships of the RAN to the Middle East to assist by means of identification, contact, interrogation and warning in enforcing United Nation's sanctions against Iraq under Article 51 of the United Nations charter.

That is the way the Government is now expressing the decision which, as I have said, the Prime Minister himself referred to as a decision to enforce the sanctions of the United Nations. There does seem to have been some further reflection by the Government following that announcement of the Prime Minister. Senator Gareth Evans, last week, was the first to refer to this more limited role of the Australian ships in the Gulf region, whereas it now has been summarised in this motion as one of `identification, contact, interrogation and warning'. It is not at all clear to me why that change was introduced into the reasons given for the deployment of the ships during last week, but that apparently is now the Government's firm decision.

There are a few matters arising from that which I want to mention. However, before doing so, I want to refer to a couple of other matters that seem to have developed following the Government's decision. Firstly, of course, there were clearly pressures brought to bear on the Government by a number of its own supporters in opposition to the Prime Minister's decision. We witnessed a fairly lengthy debate within the factions yesterday and into last night and at a Caucus meeting today which fortunately has not hidebound the Prime Minister and the Government in having to make further decisions in this very difficult, fluid and dangerous situation which may well arise. It clearly is a benefit that it has not done that, but nevertheless there has clearly been some influence to weaken the resolve so firmly stated by the Prime Minister in the first place.

There have, of course, been other influences brought to bear. No doubt we shall hear one of them in this debate tonight from Senator Vallentine, who is just dying to attack this decision. Without even waiting to hear her, I can say that we will not agree with anything she says. The Democrats, perhaps somewhat sadly, have also taken up the position of critics of this decision. It is most important for Australia, and certainly most important for those 600 servicemen who are proceeding in the three ships to the Middle East, that there should be a widespread support in the Australian community for the dangerous and difficult task they have been asked to undertake and which they have undertaken in accordance with their duty. I have no doubt that they will perform in accordance with their duty and with their great capabilities. It is important for them to know that as widely as possible the Australian community are behind what is being done. I would think that they would take some heart from this debate tonight, in which the Government has put down this very firm motion which has, as I said, been so eloquently supported by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, in his speech before dinner, and has been supported from the word go in a full-blooded way by the Opposition. We are firm in that commitment. We are not under the pressures that seem to be bearing a little bit on the Government. Nevertheless, the situation is that the Government and the Opposition are united in the support of this move which the Prime Minister first announced over a week ago.

That is a very important factor indeed. It is very important also because it clearly indicates a widespread agreement in this community in denunciation of the sort of aggression to which this response is being made and to the threats that are being made to world peace by these actions. That is a very widespread Australian response to those challenges to world peace.

There were also some doubts cast last week about the suitability of the ships for their task. I am pleased that the Prime Minister in his statement today has made clear the capability of the ships, the quality of training that the servicemen have had, and their ability to undertake this task. There have also been doubts cast about the legality of this exercise. I am pleased to be able to support the views that have been expressed by Senator Gareth Evans and the Government and the reference to article 51 of the United Nations Charter in this motion to support the legality of our being present in helping to enforce the sanctions and in doing so as part of a collective security force in the region.
I might add that the Security Council's resolution of 6 August 1990, in calling for the widespread sanctions, includes the following term, amongst many others:
Affirming the inherent right of individual or collective self-defence, in response to the armed attack by Iraq against Kuwait, in accordance with article 51 of the Charter.
The Security Council's own resolution imposing the sanctions has acknowledged the right of `collective self-defence'; and that is what this operation is all about.

I am pleased that the Deputy Prime Minister and a former Foreign Minister of the United Kingdom, Sir Geoffrey Howe, who is in Australia, was reported in this morning's newspapers as saying that he had also come to the same conclusion in firm acknowledgment of the legality of this exercise. Let us put that aside as one of the other objections that have been raised.

Before I conclude, I would like to make one or two further remarks. Senator Hill, on behalf of the Opposition, has flagged most of them. We have some concern about the fact that there are not yet any rules of engagement and that there still seem to be a number of doubts about the manner in which the warships are to be deployed. For instance, it does not seem to be established yet under whose operational control and command these ships will be operating. They, of course, will be under the command of their captains. They will also be acting under the rules of engagement, which are yet to be laid down and which are taking far too long, in our view, to determine. There seems to be no reason why they should be taking so long. We will certainly be pressing the Government for an early resolution of that. The rules of engagement will lead to the ships' crews doing some exercises; they have to learn how to operate them before they are thrown into a dangerous situation. There is also the question of the geographic limits under which they will be operating; that has also not been established.

It is disappointing that the Prime Minister's statement does not give us any more information about these matters. In fact, it raises a few more concerns because, apart from leaving open the extent of the role of identification, interrogation and warning and clearing up what doubts there may be about the limits of effectiveness that these will place upon the ships and the crew, the Prime Minister goes on:
The operational roles of our ships will be reviewed if necessary to ensure that they meet the aim of the deployment . . .

There still seem to be doubts in the mind of the Government as to whether this operational role which it has laid down will be satisfactory for Australia and for the other ships in the multinational force, and whether all of them will be able to operate under the limitations that have been stated.

The Prime Minister still seems to be in doubt as to whose operational control they will come under. At his press conference on 10 August 1990, the Prime Minister said that the Australian naval vessels would remain under Australian command but that, once on station, they may operate under United States or some other form of operational control. That very serious question still seems to be unresolved.

The Government says that the vessels have some time before they get there. They are in HMAS Stirling in Cockburn Sound today and they are leaving tomorrow for the Gulf region. It is most unsatisfactory that these matters have not yet been resolved. The Opposition hopes that they will be resolved soon and will be pressing that they should be resolved before the vessels get to the Gulf and not left until they get there.

The question also arises of an adequate defence position and posture for these ships if they are not operating under what Vice-Admiral Beaumont said at the Prime Minister's press conference: that the ships would be operating as part of a task group and that there would be a layered defence process. That is very important for their defence and safety in the dangerous situation in which they will clearly be. There will be more danger for them if they are not participating under a layered defence process and under a properly structured operational control. These are all matters that are of concern to us in opposition. We are disappointed only on this one point in the statement: the Prime Minister has not cleared those matters up and we sincerely hope that they will be clarified as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may surprise Senator Durack, and even disappoint him, to know that I actually agree with a lot of what he has just said. For example, I agree with most of the motion of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) on this subject, including sections one, two, three, four and six. I have a great deal of difficulty with section five, especially the second part of it, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Government's decision to send ships of the RAN to the Middle East to assist-by means of identification, contact, interrogation and warning-in enforcing UN sanctions against Iraq under Article 51 of the UN Charter.

I have great difficulty with that section; in fact, I totally oppose that section of the resolution, so I will not be supporting the whole. As for the rest of it, I can agree with the sentiments expressed, particularly the support for the United Nations.

There has already been a great deal of national and international opposition not only to the decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to send Australian frigates to the Gulf region but also to the other military responses. I have been part of an international grouping which has called for an alternative to the present approach of the West, which is leading to a deepening and increasingly dangerous crisis in the Gulf region. In terms of the international approach, I wish to advise the Senate that the opposition has come from France, Germany, Britain, the United States (US) and New Zealand, as well as from many groups in Australia. I want to speak to the resolution which has been put forward by this international grouping, but I will not be reading directly from it.

In framing our alternative approach, we first of all extend our sympathies to the people of the region, whose lives are directly affected by the present crisis. We wish to cooperate with them to bring about a quick, just and peaceful resolution to this crisis. Secondly, we strongly condemn the use of force by Iraq in invading and annexing Kuwait. It is clear that any just solution must involve the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. Thirdly, we are deeply concerned by the militaristic statements and actions in response to the Iraqi invasion led by the Bush Administration and supported by a number of Western governments. The military intervention by the United States and other forces has inflamed the region and revealed the ultimate ineffectiveness of military solutions to this international conflict. Our goal must be the non-violent resolution of such conflict. We call on Western governments to reverse their decision to deploy military forces in the Middle East.

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you want Iraq to do?

—If Senator Schacht had listened, he would have heard that I had already said that any just solution must involve the withdrawal of Iraqi troops from Kuwait. The United Nations issue has been mentioned by several speakers in this debate already and I want to clarify the situation. The United Nations sanctions have been enthusiastically endorsed almost unanimously and there has been greater support for this United Nations initiative than for any other United Nations initiative. That is commendable and I am glad that the Australian Government is also supporting those economic sanctions.

SPEECH.PARA: What I object to is the United States and other Western governments, including our own, taking it upon themselves to try to enforce these economic sanctions by military force and then having the gall to try to get United Nations (UN) approval for that. This action which Senator Durack has said is legal and that we must have no more debate about is not legal under the terms of the United Nations charter. It is quite clear in the terms of the United Nations charter that if this were a United Nations peacekeeping force under a United Nations flag then, yes, it could be supported. But that is not the case at the moment.

Retrospective permission is being sought from the United Nations to do what President Bush and his advisers, such as Henry Kissinger, who is just saying, `Go in there and bomb them', want to do. It is retrospective permission that is now being sought from the Security Council, and that is not good enough: it is an undermining of the United Nations institution. It is not good enough to say that we are going to send in the troops and then seek the endorsement of the United Nations.

If the United Nations had decided on a peacekeeping force under a United Nations flag, then there would be great support for that. That is not the case. The Bush Administration could not wait to get in there to use its military might. It has thousands of troops already on the ground in Saudi Arabia and the Australian Government has been silly enough to jump on the bandwagon far too fast without adequate thought or consultation about this matter. It has been very embarrassing for the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) to have to back-pedal and to try to say, `Oh well, the Prime Minister did not really mean what he said when he said that once the Australian ships got to the Gulf they would be under United States command'. That is another point on which I would agree with Senator Durack.

It is crucial that these matters be cleared up. Of course, I think the ships should not go. But it is not good enough for the Prime Minister to say one thing, for example, `We will fight or be under the United States flag' and for the Foreign Minister to have to backtrack from that and say that we need to get the endorsement of the United Nations. Talk about closing the stable door after the horse has bolted! It is an undermining of the position of the United Nations.

We know very well that the United States does not care a jot for the United Nations. For years it did not even pay its dues to this body-the best international body that there is-which may have some role to play in peacekeeping and in finding a non-violent and non-military solution to this crisis.

I am appalled by the Prime Minister's speech this afternoon. He had the cheek and the temerity to talk about the hostages and to criticise the Iraqi Government for using foreign nationals as hostages in this situation. There are 150 Australian nationals whose lives are at risk because of the Prime Minister's rash decision to send three Australian ships to the region. If the Australian Government had not said that it would send its ships to the Gulf, then the Australian nationals, along with nationals of other countries who have been given exit visas, would by now be out of Iraq and out of Kuwait.

Our Australians' lives are at risk right now because of the action of our Prime Minister in following President Bush's request for Australian military involvement and backup for the United States' military posturing. If Australia had not agreed to send a military force, then the Australians would not be being rounded up into the hotels and being used as virtual hostages. Other nationals from other countries have been given exit visas. They are out of the countries of Iraq and Kuwait already. So Australian lives have been put directly at risk by the Prime Minister's unwise decision.

The other Australian lives put at risk are the ones who are on board the ship. My great sympathies go to the families who tomorrow will farewell these young men who have been given orders and who, in some cases at least-there are a few absent without leave, I gather, who are not accounted for as yet-are reluctantly following orders to go into this very dangerous war zone.

It is only four months since the Prime Minister, with tears in his eyes at the Gallipoli seventy-fifth anniversary, said that never again shall young Australians' lives be under a foreign flag on foreign fields. They were the Prime Minister's words on 25 April at Gallipoli. But here we are again: Australians sent off to a very dangerous war zone where they may well find themselves engaged in the most devastating war that humanity has ever known.

Senator Sam Nunn of the United States Armed Forces Congressional Committee has said that there is a very real possibility of the use of tactical nuclear weapons in this conflict. We have had Kissinger saying, `Go in there and bomb them'. We have had the Iraqis threatening to use chemical weapons. What kind of situation is our Prime Minister sending these young Australian men into?

It is not our war; indeed, it need not be anybody's war if the United Nations' sanctions were allowed to take effect. I beg the Australian Government to reconsider its decision and to allow the United Nations' sanctions to take effect. For the first time in history the global community had the opportunity for a peaceful and non-violent resolution of this conflict. It is being escalated by the military posturing on both sides.
We had unprecedented support for the United Nations and it is being blown before there has been the opportunity for us to see whether it could be effective.

I was also appalled to see in the Prime Minister's statement no reference whatsoever to the historical background to this region. Nobody else in the other chamber or here has mentioned it yet. There is a huge problem in the whole of the Middle East and in the Gulf region in particular. Foreign powers have to take some responsibility for the tensions and the deep hatred that there is in some Arab nations for the West. It is not without foundation. It is not without reason.

Let me give the Senate a short summary up to 1930 when oil was discovered in the region: In 1899, to exclude growing German interest in the area and to suppress piracy which threatened the Suez to India route, Kuwait was detached from the Ottoman Empire and became a British protectorate. The local ruler had responsibility for internal affairs, and Britain took responsibility for foreign policy and defence. That was nearly 100 years ago.

In 1915, the secret Sykes Picot agreement carved up the Turkish Empire between Britain and France in the event of a Turkish defeat in World War I. At the same time Britain had been promising the Arabs independence if Feisal, the Sherif of Mecca, would support it against the Turks. After the First World War the Arabs found that they were grossly deceived when Britain took Iraq and Palestine and France took Lebanon and Syria. Iraq was under the Anglo-Indian administration of a British civil commissioner. There was an anti-British revolt in Iraq in 1920. Two thousand British lives were lost and millions of pounds were expended to put the revolt down. This is the kind of background that we actually need to know about this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does it justify the use of force?

—I am not saying that it justifies any violence whatsoever. Will Senator Newman listen? I am saying that, if there is violence in the region, it should not be countered with more violence. That is a basic principle. It will not do any good whatsoever.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1921, Britain installed Feisal as a puppet king in Iraq. That was imposed without consulting the Iraqis. In 1930 the Anglo-Iraq Treaty was meant to grant independence to Iraq. It is with this kind of background that we must try to understand the Middle East crisis. Of course, matters got much worse when oil was discovered. Since the 1930s, and particularly since 1950, we have been increasingly dependent on a petroleum economy and foreign powers have deliberately had a divide and rule policy. They set out, for example, in 1953 to prevent the growing friendship between the democratically elected Government of Iran and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. The Central Intelligence Agency organised a coup to install the Shah as dictator of Iran.

This is the kind of background that has not been mentioned by anybody yet; but it must be understood. It organised the anti-Soviet Baghdad pact, setting up the CENTO group to be a Middle Eastern version of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation alliance. The pro-Western Government maintained itself by setting Kurd against Arab and Sunni against Shia, working a policy of divide and rule which has been extremely successful.

We then had the Iraqi revolution. We have had eight coups in Iraq from 1934 to 1958. There has been tremendous tension and turmoil in the region. There have been three Kurdish wars, and there have been several attempts by the Iraqis to claim Kuwait, which they do not acknowledge as being independent.

TALK.START.PARA: —The UN does.
—The UN does. I am just giving the background to the issue. It is important to understand that the Iraqis believe they have a claim in that region. As I said, Iraq--
—You are becoming an apologist.

—I am not becoming an apologist at all. In 1961 Kuwait was declared independent of the British protectorate but, of course, that did not guarantee the absence of claims from the Iraqis in that situation. I am not in any way justifying their intervention in that region right now.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to understand that this crisis is about the West's dependency on oil. We are living in a petroleum dominated economy. In the first oil crisis in 1973 we had the opportunity to rethink that dependence on Middle East oil, given the turmoil in the region, given the history of colonialism and outside intervention and given the deep-seated distrust of the West by the Arab nations which, as I have tried to point out, is not unfounded. We should have looked then for other sources, as Australia wisely did. But also we should have looked at other sources rather than fossil fuels. We should have looked to renewable energy sources; we should have looked to conserving our very wasteful use of energy.

The United States uses 50 per cent of the world's petroleum-50 per cent! Military engagement in the Middle East, which is getting closer and closer day by day, is to protect the United States glutt- onous habits in its overuse of oil resources. Why did the global community not take stock of the situation in 1973? We have had almost 20 years to turn away from dependence on Middle Eastern oil and we have not taken the opportunity. It is important that we learn the lessons from what has happened in the Middle East and that we not be so dependent on Middle East oil and on the petroleum economy. We must look to alternatives.

I totally dispute what Senator Evans says about Australia's involvement in the Middle East situation being necessary from our national point of view. Australia is 70 per cent self-sufficient in oil. We should be more self-sufficient than that. One of our other oil sources is disputable because it is located in the Timor Gap. It is stolen oil from the East Timorese people. I will get onto that later.

It is not in our interests to jeopardise the lives of Australians who are in the Gulf and the servicemen who are on the ships going there. It is not in our interests to jeopardise future Australian trade by being engaged in the military posturing. To be engaged in the United Nation's economic boycott, which is supported by most nations in the world, I believe is a very different thing from sending our warships to the region.

We are now considered an enemy country by many of the Arab nations. I do not think that that is very helpful in terms of our future trade opportunities. We have to look at the very devastating accident potential in this region that the Prime Minister is blithely sending our young men into. The Iraqis have already engaged in the use of chemical weapons. They have a huge stockpile of these weapons and they are not afraid to use them. They have already demonstrated that.

We also have to acknowledge that a huge armada of warships is sitting in the Gulf at the moment carrying nuclear weapons. If the missiles start to fly-I hope they never do-there is a huge potential for accidents because of those nuclear weapons. Also we have people in the United States Administration threatening to use their short-range tactical nuclear weapons. The Government is sending young Australians into the most devastating situation possible.

Australia could take a very creative role similar to the role the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade took in the Cambodian crisis. The Government could engage in a bit of lateral thinking, for goodness sake, instead of just rushing in where angels fear to tread. I do not support people who engage in name calling of either of the parties in this dispute. But, whatever one thinks of Saddam Hussein, it is very unwise to threaten somebody who is so heavily armed, who has shown that he is not afraid to use his worst weapons and who is feeling extremely threatened. The worst thing one can do is threaten him further with the use of military force. It is just a stupid response to make-absolutely stupid.

Australia should be suggesting demilitarisation of the whole region. That is what the international response should be. The United Nations must be looked to as the main body capable of determining the appropriate responses to this situation. We support the United Nation's attempts to resolve the conflict by non-military means, including economic sanctions, and we call for the withdrawal of all foreign troops from the region. The Arab nations, amongst themselves, have huge problems to work out. We should not be interfering in the military sense.

It is important to note that with the intervention of US ground troops in Saudi Arabia and the presence of US, British and French naval forces in the Gulf the three nations which have acted as the main colonial powers in the Middle East in modern times have been brought together. Of course, this is like a red rag to a bull. Why inflame the situation by going in there with weapons systems when that is exactly the kind of excuse that Saddam Hussein might use to attempt to justify the further use of force in this situation. It is just giving him the excuse that he does not really need but might take advantage of. As a result, the stage has been set for a military conflict to develop between the nations of the north and south to replace the old Cold War between the East and West of which, thankfully, we have seen the demise in recent times.

This situation has been worsened by the profiteering of Western nations, which have exported large volumes of modern arms to countries like Iraq. These same Western nations are now crying foul because these weapons are being used in ways which threaten their access to cheap and abundant oil. In my notice of motion this afternoon, I said that the Soviet Union was one of the chief nations involved in arms sales. I absolutely acknowledge that. I want to quote from an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of Tuesday, 14 August which is headed `Exporting double standards'. This article is about Australia's involvement in sending arms to the region. We are not exempt from that criticism of those who support the Iraqi regime's huge militarisation program. Before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait the situation was as follows-these are not my words; I am quoting from this article; I would not use this terminology myself:

. . . The Defence Department thought highly enough of the Butcher of Baghdad to give approval to Hawker de Havilland to sell $850,000 worth of aircraft parts to the Iraqi Air Force. Last week, the Government cancelled the sale.

Last week! So this is Australia's involvement-selling armaments to the Iraqi forces. Then we cry foul and say, `Oh, we must go there, and we must use our forces to stop this man'. We have helped him with his armaments. What a double standard that is? It is so hypocritical.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never got the arms.
—This is just the last one that we know about; the one that was cancelled.
—It was by sheer chance.

—That is right. Iraq was one of the small group of countries, including Iran, South Africa and members of the Eastern bloc, to which sales were banned. This was before the relaxing of the defence export guidelines, which the former Minister for Defence was so proud to introduce into the Parliament in 1988. Before that, sales to countries such as Iraq, Iran, South Africa and members of the Eastern bloc were banned. But that was before the end of the Iraq-Iran war. Obviously, we decided then that Iraq was smelling much more sweetly, the odd bout of chemical warfare notwithstanding. Once the war between Iran and Iraq actually stopped, it was okay for the Australian Department of Defence to sell military parts to Iraq. That has happened.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1988, the Defence Department has had the authority to give export licences to arms manufacturers in Australia. That has been happening since the end of the Iraq-Iran conflict and since the guidelines of Minister for Defence were gently softened to make it possible for Australia to sell armaments to almost anybody. I repeat: until last week, we were selling parts to the Iraqi Air Force.

It is also important to note that, according to this article, the Washington correspondent for the Sydney Morning Herald wrote last Friday that George Bush rang Bob Hawke to thank him for offering Australian Navy ships. This is not something that we have heard very much about in the Australian media. We have heard that Bush rang around and was trying to get support. But we did not know that Hawke had actually offered the support until George rang him and put the hard word on him. It was not very difficult for him to get the consent, of course. Our Prime Minister insists that the Americans asked us first. It may be mere semantics, but the perspective from Washington is quite different.

It seems that we have advanced little as a nation in the past 20 or 30 years. Sir Alan Watt, Head of the External Affairs Department in the early 1950s, wrote in 1967, `Many nations must depend on others for their ultimate security, but in most cases they try to maximise their own independence within a relationship of dependency'. Australia has seemed intent on doing the very opposite, maximising its dependence, first on Britain and lately on the US. I think that that is a great shame. It is a national shame.

There are parallels between this and the Vietnam situation. However, the great difference between the two, which needs to be pointed out, is that in the Vietnam situation it was a Liberal-Country Party government which sent Australians off to join the United States in a foreign field and thus to their deaths. The Australian Labor Party was great in opposition. The Labor Party was out there and it would be interesting to know how many of the Labor Party people now sitting in these two chambers were involved in the anti-Vietnam marches. I have no doubt that there were many of them who were proud to be so, as Senator McMullan is only too pleased to recognise. I am glad that they were there, but they are not there now because this time it is the Labor Party that is sending Australians off, despite the Prime Minister's glib and tearful promise at Gallipoli only a few months ago that Australians would not be sent off to fight under a foreign flag. That is exactly what has happened and we still have no clear idea from the Prime Minister or the Foreign Minister-who is madly backtracking and trying to undo Bob Hawke's promises-of whose command those Australians will be under when they get there.

However, I do not think that that is the most important issue at all. The important thing is that the global community has missed a great opportunity to ensure that the United Nations sanctions work. It must be stated that there is no point in confronting violence with violence. All one gets is more violence. All we are going to get out of the Middle East from a military response in this situation is more violence. There is nothing surer.

I want to reaffirm the Western Australian Greens' total commitment to non-violence and we will ensure that opposition to the Prime Minister's decision is heard in this country. I am very pleased to be working in an alliance with the Australian Democrats, the Rainbow Alliance and other groups around the country. There are many groups involved in an alliance in Western Australia at the moment. It was interesting that at the Young Labor Party's conference over the weekend there was huge dissension over this issue, too. I know that although Labor people here will not be able to say how they feel about this issue, already many Australian Labor Party branches in various States have put forward motions to their State executives condemning this decision.

The opposition will be there. It will be seen; it will be heard. Great shame will be heaped upon Mr Hawke, as our Prime Minister, for making this very unwise decision. It is not too late to stop the ships from leaving Garden Island tomorrow, but I doubt that that will happen. It is very interesting that even Gough Whitlam has criticised the Prime Minister's decision. I thought that the Prime Minister's response to Gough Whitlam's criticism was very interesting. He said, `Oh well, his Prime Ministership wasn't perfect either. Everyone makes mistakes'. I wondered whether the Prime Minister was beginning to think that maybe he had made a mistake. He has made a gross error of judgment and it would take quite some courage to admit it and to stop those ships leaving Garden Island tomorrow. How much better it would be for the Prime Minister to admit that he had made a gross error of judgment; to do something which will relieve the situation for the 170 Australians stuck in Kuwait and Iran right now. They could be out of there in a flash if Australia were not part of that military blockade.

The Prime Minister could stop even the prospect of Australian lives being lost in the Gulf if he had the guts to admit that he had made a mistake and if he reversed that decision. That is what I and many others in the country are calling on him to do-to acknowledge the error of that decision that he made without much consultation. That issue has been covered by other people. I know that the Westminster system gives him the ability to make that decision in that way. I do not like it, but that is the system. But to admit that he has made a mistake would be a courageous thing to do, and how much better for him to admit that now and to stop this insanity before it goes any further.

Why cannot the Australian Government make the kind of response that the New Zealand Government had the courage to make-that it would abide by the United Nations declaration, that it would be involved in a peacekeeping force only under a United Nations flag, and that it would send a Red Cross team to the area? I think that that is a plausible response and I commend the New Zealand Government for having the wisdom to think carefully about this decision and to listen to the voice of sanity of its own people and this plea from the international community not to engage in a military conflict which could have more devastating consequences than people sitting around this chamber could ever imagine in their enthusiastic endorsement of the military response.

I find it quite sickening that there is this kind of enthusiastic support for the troops going off to a dangerous war zone. I think that that is a great shame. The voice of the Australian people will be raised on this issue and I think it must be heard. We have a couple of weeks before those ships are actually due to arrive in the Gulf and my plea is that the Prime Minister will see reason; that he will reverse his decision to engage in military posturing in the Middle East.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Loosley, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech in the Senate. Therefore I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loosley Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy President. May I begin by congratulating both yourself and the President on your election today. I have known the President of the Senate, Senator Sibraa, for some 15 years. I am well acquainted with both his qualities and his capacities. I am certain that both of you will continue to acquit yourselves well in this chamber and I look forward to your counsel.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I begin my maiden speech, may I say how pleased I am that my wife, Lynne, is in the gallery tonight.

Mr Deputy President, I rise to support the motion as moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. There is no doubt that at certain times in human affairs the two elements most required are those of courage and resolution. So it is with the current circumstances in the Persian Gulf and in the Middle East generally. We have seen an act of unprovoked aggression by the state of Iraq against its neighbour, Kuwait. At a time when relations between East and West have seldom if ever been better, we are obliged to confront a conflict in which the norms of both international law and civilised behaviour have been cast aside.

Mr Deputy President, no-one should be in any doubt about the motivation of Iraqi President Saddam Hussein in seizing Kuwait. By itself, Iraq currently controls some 9 to 9 1/2 per cent of the world's proven oil supplies. Kuwait holds approximately 10 per cent of the world's known oil supplies. At one stroke, Iraqi aggression has given it a capacity to become not simply a major oil supplier but a primary oil supplier to the entire world. The dangers in that for the international economy and the world community are self-evident. Moreover, what is not commonly realised is that prior to the intervention of the United States, the kingdom of Saudi Arabia was in very real jeopardy.

Let me state openly that I hold no particular brief for the feudal monarchies that dominate this part of the globe, but two points ought to be made. First, we must deal with political realities; and secondly, these monarchies are broadly preferable to the awful regime that exists in Baghdad.

Mr Deputy President, prior to the arrival of the forward elements of the 82nd Airborne Division and the United States Air Force, the Iraqis could have easily overrun a strip of territory some 400 miles by 50 miles in Saudi Arabia and Qatar, which would have given Saddam Hussein some 15 to 20 per cent more of the world's known petroleum reserves and the consequences of that aggression would have been staggering.

In these circumstances what should the Australian response have been? First, let us deal with a couple of myths. Some have likened this conflict to the war in Indo-China of the 1960s and 1970s. Some have drawn a parallel with Australian intervention in Vietnam. We should dismiss this canard immediately. There is no analogy with the Vietnamese civil war. The two conflicts stand in contrast, rather than in comparison. And I speak, like Senator McMullan, as one who opposed our Vietnam involvement.

The second myth: the telephone call from President Bush to the Prime Minister of Australia represented an end to the process by which consultations had occurred between Australia and the United States. The Australian position had already been drafted in the national interests of our country. When the formal request was made to Australia to contribute significantly to the multinational naval force in the Gulf, Australia was in a position to respond immediately. Let me add that it stands to the credit of the Opposition that it has not been suggested on the other side of the chamber that the decision of the Government was anything other than in the national interest.

Mr Deputy President, this brings me to a point about the formulation of foreign affairs and defence policy in Australia generally. I have long held the view that there should be a greater degree of bipartisanship in the field of foreign affairs, defence policy and on matters of trade. Taken together, these policy positions constitute our international perspective and our international profile. Certainly there should always be a vigorous debate within Australia's political parties and between our political parties. It should involve the broader community, and this body has an important role to fulfil in terms of this debate and in terms of Senate committee procedures.

Like the United States Senate, this body has the opportunity to stand back from time to time and form a considered view and take a deliberate position. It is very pleasing that we have achieved a bipartisan position on the Gulf crisis in Australia's national interest. There should be more bipartisanship in shaping Australia's international political direction.

Mr Deputy President, the feature of the Gulf crisis which is quite extraordinary in terms of international relations is the degree of cooperation between the United States, the Western powers generally and the Soviet Union on the issue. It is reflected not only in the votes taken at the United Nations Security Council but in the practical decisions taken by the Soviet Union itself: first, in the dispatch of its naval vessels to the area to monitor developments; second, in Defence Minister Yasov telling the Iraqis that their logistical support has evaporated; and, finally, in the words of Mikhail Gorbachev, who two days ago told his military chiefs in Odessa that the Soviet Union had supplied Iraq with weaponry for its own defence and not for use in a war of aggression against smaller neighbours.

Mr Deputy President, not since the Potsdam Conference in 1945 has there been a better climate between the major powers on which efforts to find a solution might be based. This brings us to the situation of the United Nations. There is no doubt that the multinational response is within the terms of article 51 of the charter of the United Nations on collective defence. It is legal and it is justifiable. There is no doubt either that a formal resolution of the Security Council to underline the embargo and to reinforce the sanctions would be a welcome step, but as the Prime Minister said this morning, in the absence of that, decisive action was required.

I quote the Prime Minister in the Caucus of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party this morning: `There is no use of sanctions simply existing on paper in New York'. The sanctions against Iraq in the face of this aggression had to be enforced. In this, the analogy is not with Vietnam, but with Korea in the 1950s. As the great British socialist Mr Nye Bevan once remarked, `We all need to be aware that there are some men who think with the blood'.

Turning to people who think with the blood, let us look at the record of Iraq over the last decade. It is true that circumstances change rapidly in the Middle East; it is also true that until recently Iraq may have been regarded in some quarters as preferable to the fundamentalism of Iran-that the Iraqi military would act as a bulwark against potential Iranian aggression in the Gulf. Indeed, even in the early part of 1989 the US National Security Council's advice to the President was that the USSR and Iran posed a greater threat to the Gulf than did Iraq. So, there are lessons for Western policy makers in what has occurred. But one element is always consistent in Iraqi foreign policy, and that is the use of force-maximum and most brutal force, accompanied by recourse to dreadful technologies such as chemical weapons, which were used indiscriminately against the Kurds-Hussein's own people-and against Iran in the province of Khuzestan in the war, and we now see their threatened use against the world community and against Western hostages. Should I say, Mr Deputy President, that the taking of hostages fills all civilised men and women in this chamber, in Australia and in the world community with horror. It is a return to the practices of the Dark Ages. Sometimes, civilisation has to confront a manifest evil. This is such an occasion.

Turning to the terms of the resolution before the Senate-it is both comprehensive and clear, and, most importantly, it offers leadership both in domestic terms and within the international framework. The international framework has altered for the better. In the Middle East, Saddam Hussein's period, like that of Libya's Muammar Gaddafi before him, as pretender to the role of leader of the Arab world is now at an end. The leadership of the Arab world has returned to the Egyptians. Not since 1967 has Egypt's role in world affairs been more significant or more decisive.

On that score, it is interesting to note that Egypt, Morocco and Syria have all intervened militarily in support of the kingdom of Saudi Arabia, and most of the rest of the Arab world is at variance with Iraq and has said so. Iraq is isolated; it is already discredited and in international terms it is, in effect, a pariah nation. However, it is now imperative that Saddam Hussein be seen to lose as a consequence of his aggression, for if Iraq is not seen to lose decisively, then it may be anticipated that Hussein will return to fresh adventurism-emboldened, stronger and more aggressive-and in a few years time Iraq is likely to have a stronger economic base, improved chemical weapons capacity, delivery systems for ballistic missiles and artillery for long-range bombardments, and potentially, even, a nuclear weapons capacity. Iraq so armed would be far more formidable and far more dangerous than it is currently. Hence, the reaction of the world community needed to be utterly decisive and so it has been.

To date, the following countries have intervened: the United States, the United Kingdom, Canada, France, Netherlands, the Federal Republic of Germany, Syria, Egypt and Morocco. Spain, Portugal, Italy, Greece and Japan have offered support, as has Turkey. The international community has responded with determination.

As I said earlier, Mr Deputy President, the analogy ought to be drawn with the Korean War, which began in 1950. In Korea we had an act of naked aggression. We had military adventurism on a grand scale. We had policy being made on the basis of force of arms and President Truman, like his predecessor, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, was equal to the challenge of aggression. So was Australia in 1941, so was John Curtin, and so was the world community.

To continue the process of drawing analogies-what are we to say about the despot Saddam Hussein? Mr Deputy President, in my view the comparison ought not to be drawn with Hitler, with the monumental evil on that scale-though some do. It is perhaps more apt to compare Saddam Hussein with Haile Mengistu, the dictator of Ethiopia, who also murders his military commanders and his Cabinet ministers at the table, who persecutes his own people, who uses force of arms against his neighbours, and who wages war against the Eritreans and the Tigreans. The two are very similar. But there is one element in Hussein's make-up that justifies comparison with the fascist dictatorships of the thirties and the forties. I quote from someone far more eloquent than I-Bertolt Brecht in the Resistible Rise of Arturo Ui-on the defeat of fascism in the forties.
Therefore learn how to see and not to gape
To act instead of talking all day long
The nations put him where his kind belong
But don't rejoice too soon at your escape

Mr Deputy President, I come to this chamber elected as a Labor senator, as an internationalist who believes that Australia should act in her own self-interest, in consultation with her friends and her allies as part of the Western democratic group of nations. My great Party, the Australian Labor Party, takes an international perspective. We are committed to the Socialist International and the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions. We are committed to the United Nations and to its agencies, particularly to the International Labour Organisation. And, like all Australians, we are committed to essential democratic values, to constitutional government and to parliamentary representation, as I am sure are all within this chamber.

Mr Deputy President, Australians do not seek to impose our democratic views upon others. We may argue in support of them but we resist the appeal of imposition-the appeal that is inherent in imposition. But we are determined to respond when these values are threatened, and these values are threatened in the Gulf crisis. We are not defending the Emirates or the kingdom of Saudi Arabia in isolation. We are responding on the basis of a principle that international law and civilised behaviour ought to prevail in world affairs and that Saddam Hussein, Iraq and their allies ought not to be permitted to dictate the course of events either to this country or to our friends and allies or to any other nation on the globe.
