The analogy with Korea is appropriate. Other analogies might also be drawn from the period of the 1930s-from the Rhineland, Czechoslovakia, or from the outbreak of the Spanish Civil War. The world then failed in its obligations; the democracies failed; and the League of Nations failed. On this occasion we ought not to fail. The evidence overwhelmingly suggests that the international community will not fail this challenge.

In finalising the analogy, the United Nations did not fail in Korea; it did not fail in Zimbabwe; and it is not failing in South Africa. International opinion does prevail if it is supported by resolution and determination, the kind of determination that Australia has demonstrated over the previous few days. Australia's role may not be decisive, but it is significant in the successful outcome of the process of ensuring that international opinion does prevail.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I congratulate the preceding speaker, Senator Loosley, on his maiden speech which was an excellent and responsible speech to the motion which is before the chair tonight. I rise in support of the motion moved by the Government and supported in speeches made by my Leader, Senator Hill, and by Senator Durack and Senator Gareth Evans. I propose to be quite brief tonight because I think most of the essential material has been covered. I just want to raise some slightly different points. We are dealing in the international arena with an armed invasion without any warning or provocation of one country by another, the overrunning of that country, and the removal of a legitimate government going about its lawful occasions. Within 48 hours of that invasion the country was annexed by its invader.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is quite irrelevant to say that it was a large country invading a small country, although the comparison that springs to mind is that between Australia invading New Zealand because the populations of Iraq and Australia are about the same, and Kuwait is about the same size as New Zealand. But the bald fact is that, irrespective of the ratios of the size of the countries, it is a conquest by armed force of one country by another and, as such, it is a breach of international law and it cannot be tolerated.

We have to live by a rule of law within countries, within societies and internationally. We cannot live in free societies. If there is no rule of law, there simply is anarchy-the strength of somebody's right arm where might is right, and that is not the way societies have chosen to live. Any grouping and aggregation of people to have stability has always had some form of law. It might not be a perfect law; in fact, we have had legislation and rules ever since man banded together in the caves, and those rules are still improving and changing. That is why we are here as legislators trying to improve the system, but the system is the important thing. It was perfectly correct for the Government to recognise that Australia had a national interest to defend with respect to an international rule of law, to speak up and to make a commitment to see that that rule of law internationally is supported and enforced.

I think it is very strange that in a century where we have seen the greatest feats of arms in history, where the dangers of not controlling international relationships and an international rule of law have cost so many hundreds of millions of lives, people such as members of the Australian Democrats, Senator Vallentine and the appeasers have not learned from the terrible lessons of history. We have learned that if we do not stand up and be counted when the law is broken and seek to impose that rule of law, then the situation will get very much worse. That is why the United Nations was set up in the aftermath of the Second World War; that is why Australia played such a signal part in setting up the United Nations-to create some peace, stability and predictability in international relations. In the 45 years that the United Nations has been in existence it has unfortunately been hamstrung because of the great polarisation that has occurred between the Western democratic nations and the Soviet Union.

On only one occasion has there been a similar situation and that was in relation to Korea, when the Soviets boycotted the Security Council. The Soviets, the British, the Americans, the Chinese and the French were the five permanent members of the Security Council. They all had the right of veto of the 11 members of the Council. It was in the early 1950s, while the Soviets were boycotting the Security Council, that the United Nations could resolve to take action against the lawlessness of the North Koreans when they invaded South Korea. But since that time the power of the veto of either the Soviet bloc or of the Western democratic nations has prevented the United Nations fulfilling the ideals which led to its inception. But now, in the Gorbachev era, we see a very welcome rapprochement between the Western democratic nations and the Soviet Union. For the first time in 45 years we see the opportunity for the United Nations to demand that the rule of law internationally be applied.

There is more to it than that because, welcome though it is that the rapprochement has taken place between the Soviets and the Western democratic nations, the facts of life are that where we had two superpowers in existence up till the present, we are moving into a situation where we will have at least six superpowers in the immediate future-in the next 20 years, a very short time in international affairs-the United States, the European Community, Russia, Japan, China and India. Arguably within 30 or 40 years we might well have Indonesia joining that group.

A world where we have so many superpowers and power blocs is a very different world to where we have two superpowers and a stabilising influence that comes between a choice of either/or. Potentially, unless there is a very effective United Nations enforcing a rule of law we are moving into a very unstable and unpredictable world. It is inevitable that frictions and competition will arise between nations as they pursue their goals as they see them. Competition by itself is not dangerous, but one never knows when that competition exceeds acceptable bounds and when a person such as Saddam Hussein will come along. The defence of all the nations of the world is in the establishment of an international body which will maintain an international rule of law. The actions that the Government and the United Nations have taken are absolutely beyond dispute in this matter. They have acted with proper motives and for proper goals.

I would like to turn briefly to some problems we have in the Middle East area. One problem is that in all the Arab countries there is a very marked degree of social instability, not only in places such as Iraq where a dictatorship is running, but in other countries societies do not follow the democratic forms of government that we support. While that may have been quite tenable in those societies up to 30 years ago, the last 30 years have seen the growth of an educated middle class in those countries, technically educated people with liberal ideas, who do not wish to live under the restricted administrations that exist in so many of those Arab countries. So we have a basic instability in all those areas.

In the particular case of Iraq, we have what can only be described as an archetypal Third World dictatorship. Iraq has a leader who has murdered his opponents and competitors, who has shown a consistent belligerent and warlike approach to his neighbours, and who embarked on a war with his neighbour Iran, in September 1980, which led to at least a million dead. While no wars are pleasant-they are distinctly unpleasant-the war fought and prosecuted by Iran and Iraq was a particularly barbaric one. While I would not wish to draw distinctions between them, I think one has to say that the actions of Iraq really were far worse than those of Iran, because we saw the use of chemical weapons for the first time since the First World War.

Chemical weapons were introduced in the First World War, and the weapons principally used were chlorine and mustard gas. While those chemical weapons were lethal and toxic agents, their use then was so dramatic on the troops on both sides that they were subsequently shunned in the great conflict of the Second World War. The major combatants were prepared for chemical warfare, but they never used them; they refrained from using them, knowing the horrors that existed. We now have chemical and biological agents which are, in their lethality, several magnitudes beyond anything that existed in the First World War, and the Iraqis have shown a great readiness to use them.

Looking at the potentiality for chemical and particularly biological weapons, I think there is very little to choose between them and nuclear weapons. In fact, some of the arguments that can be advanced about biological weapons are that they are more dangerous to the world as we know it and to human life than nuclear weapons. They are simple and easy to produce, and they are things that countries with low technology can get into. The intelligence reports are that Syria, Iraq, Iran, Libya and possibly Egypt all possess chemical weapons.

Iraq first started using chemical weapons-basically chlorine and mustard gas-in December 1982, and it used them in 1983. In 1984 it used nerve gas. There was a break for a while, and then in 1986 Iraq went back to large scale use of chemical weapons. In 1988, of course, Iraq used chemical weapons against its own defenceless nomadic tribe in the north-the Kurds.

I raised the use of chemical weapons many years ago in the Senate, as the Hansards show. The point I drew attention to at that time was that the peace movement, with its antinuclear obsession-people like Senator Vallentine and the Australian Democrats, of course-showed not the slightest concern about the use of these quite horrifying weapons. It was only much later in the day after I had brought the matter up that they turned their attention to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is very unfair and untrue.

—It happens to be factually correct, and it probably embarrasses Senator Coulter. We now have the certainty that the Iraqis are moving down the path of acquiring nuclear weapons. Any form of weapon seems to be fair grist to the mill for Saddam Hussein.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference has already been made tonight to the way that Saddam Hussein has rounded up foreign nationals in his country and is using them as hostages and as a human shield. By any standards, the way the internal or international affairs of Iraq have been conducted shows that it is not a fit and proper member of the community of nations.

What should we do? We must respond to this challenge. It is always a great temptation when difficulties and dangers exist to pretend that there are reasons why nations do these things. It is always very easy to find an excuse as to why nothing should be done. It is always very attractive for the Senator Vallentines and the Democrats of this world to believe that if they feed the crocodile they will never be eaten. But that is not the fact of life. He who feeds the crocodile ends up inside the crocodile.

The first avenue in our approach must be to take a political solution to the problem-and that is why the Government has raised the matter within the United Nations. The United Nations Security Council, to its credit, reacted very rapidly. It condemned the invasion by Iraq and imposed sanctions. We are now at the stage of enforcing those sanctions. It is really quite fatuous for the Democrats to say that there is no legal right for the enforcement of sanctions by running a blockade against goods entering and leaving Iraq. When the members of the Security Council passed that motion applying sanctions, they thought through and were conscious of the implications of their decision. They knew that words were not enough. They knew very well at the time that the motion had to be backed up and that the only way it could be backed up was by having a presence on the seas to stop ships coming and going. As Senator Durack and Senator Gareth Evans have said, the legality of what the Security Council did is fully mandated by Article 51 of the United Nations charter.

This is a very crucial time for the United Nations. I believe that if the United Nations does not respond to the challenge here and does not remain consistent in enforcing sanctions against the Iraqis in order to re-establish the independence of Kuwait, we will see the end of the United Nations, in the same way we saw the end of the League of Nations before the Second World War.

We cannot foresee where this is going to end and how long it will take before Kuwait is re-established as an independent country. We must maintain the sanctions. We must be prepared to take, after a reasonable period, further steps to re- establish the independence of Kuwait, even if it means following the example of Korea, where the United Nations in the end had to resort to military force to re-establish the rule of law in that area.

Last week I saw Dr Kissinger taking part in what I thought was a very responsible and moderate interview on television. At the end of the interview Dr Kissinger in effect said that if Saddam Hussein was not brought to respect the international rule of law we face the certainty in the short term of a massive conflagration in the Middle East.

We have to support the actions of the United Nations here and what the Government has done to see that the international rule of law is preserved and enforced. We cannot tolerate a system where one nation invades and conquers another with impunity. I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the motion moved by the Government. I have chosen to speak in this debate as a result of hearing a number of the remarks made by Senator Vallentine in particular. Some would say that one should not rise to the bait of some of the points she made, but for the record I think that some of her remarks should be responded to, because they leave an unfortunate emphasis that can be misinterpreted, not just in this chamber but elsewhere in the Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Vallentine made great emotional play about the Australian sailors on the three ships that are being dispatched to the Middle East as part of the Australian commitment to help solve the crisis there. She left the impression that these sailors had no choice; that they were being sent against their will and were very unhappy. I accept the fact that any people serving in the armed forces may be unhappy, concerned, and fearful of being put in a situation where quite clearly their lives could be at risk. I do not dispute that. But it should be remembered that these people are all volunteers who joined the armed forces of their own free will. When they joined the armed forces they accepted the obligations that went with it.

There can be no parallel drawn with the sending of conscripts to Vietnam. This is totally different. These people are not conscripts and they are not being sent to the Middle East against their will with no choice. They are people who, of their own free will, have chosen to join the armed services of Australia and, in doing so, accept the obligations that go with that. Unfortunately, from time to time it may mean their having to serve in a theatre of war or potential war. I think that Senator Vallentine does the armed forces and the volunteers in it a great disservice by implying that they are being sent anywhere against their will.

Senator Vallentine then tried to give some historical background to the dispute between Iraq and Kuwait, in particular, and the other Gulf states. I do not dispute that the history lesson she gave us was by and large probably correct. I do not dispute the fact that for a long time Iraq has disputed the boundaries with Kuwait. It could be argued that the imposition of colonial powers in the earlier part of this century created boundaries that were not agreeable to the indigenous people of the Gulf. That is certainly no different from the position in many other areas of the world which suffered the colonial experience. But we must remember that Kuwait has been recognised as a sovereign state by the United Nations (UN).

Senator Vallentine made great play of the fact that we should do everything according to the United Nations. By and large, I do not disagree; but I point out to her that Kuwait is a sovereign nation that is represented in the United Nations, that it is recognised as such and that its boundaries are recognised by the United Nations.

I point out to Senator Vallentine that, for example, the boundaries of Africa were basically drawn up by the colonial powers during the seventeenth, eighteenth and nineteenth centuries and in the earlier part of the twentieth century. Many of those boundaries are illogical under any definition of demography, geography and ethnic composition. But the Organisation of African Unity (OAU), which is made up of the independent countries of Africa, takes the view that, although those boundaries may not be the best, they are the only ones they have got, they have to live with those boundaries and they will not move away from them unless there is agreement between the countries themselves. The OAU makes it quite clear that the boundaries drawn up by the colonial powers are the ones it accepts and the ones which the United Nations has accepted in Africa. I believe that a similar situation applies with regard to the boundaries of Kuwait and its recognition as a sovereign nation.

My colleague Senator Loosley, in an excellent maiden speech, made the point that in no circumstances would he support the undemocratic features of a number of the Gulf states with their monarchical or even semi-feudal systems of government, which are the antithesis of the systems in which we in Australia believe and which from time to time we all criticise, but that one does not overcome the problems posed by lack of democracy in those countries by allowing a country such as Iraq to invade Kuwait. On balance, Kuwait, despite its monarchical structure, probably has a better tradition of allowing some form of dissent than Iraq has had in the past 20 years.

Senator Vallentine also spoke about the role of the United Nations, and took the view that nothing should be done unless it was sanctioned by that body. However, she skated over the impact of the decisions which the United Nations has already made in putting in place trade sanctions against Iraq. Those trade sanctions are the most severe that have been imposed by the United Nations in recent times, and we hope that those sanctions will be very effective. But let us remember that the only way to ensure that they will be very effective is by backing them with actions by the Western democracies to ensure that there is no sanction busting. I believe that the quickest way to bring this matter to a conclusion is to show the Iraq Government, particularly Saddam Hussein, that we will not give in to a military invasion, that we will ensure that the trade sanctions are effective, and that, unless Saddam negotiates a political settlement which includes the withdrawal of troops from Kuwait, the trade sanctions will have a strong effect on his country.

During the past 20 years, I suppose, Senator Vallentine and others would have wished that there had been more effective sanctions against Rhodesia, which declared unilateral independence in 1965. If they had been enforced, a long and bloody guerilla war would not have been necessary for the majority of the population of what is now Zimbabwe to achieve their proper independence. The trade sanctions against Zimbabwe were clearly broken because they were not effectively imposed. I believe that the trade sanctions are absolutely necessary. I believe that the decision of the Australian Government to send ships to the Gulf area is covered in an international legal sense by article 51 of the United Nations Charter. Senator Vallentine did not seek to dispute that point in logic, though she tried to dispute it by assertion.

Senator Vallentine, and indeed all of us, should take note of the fact that the United Nations will now play a much more positive role in world affairs. We are now in what is called the post-postwar era when the superpower tensions between the United Nations and the Soviet Union have basically diminished to a level which now gives us a new opportunity and when the United Nations can play a role in sorting out regional disputes such as the present Gulf matter without having to deal with the superpower rivalry which in many cases over the last 20 or 30 years made the United Nations ineffective because one superpower or the other vetoed actions within the United Nations.

All of us who have supported the concept of the United Nations will welcome this development. We are already seeing this new post-postwar era in operation when the Soviet Union has not used its veto in the United Nations Security Council but has supported the resolutions so far carried in that body and has condemned the invasion, even though only a few years ago many people would have accused Iraq of being almost a client state of the Soviet Union, which supplied Iraq with much of its weaponry.

Senator Vallentine then got quite warmed up, saying that this is `all the politics of oil'. Naturally oil plays a major part in the way countries are going to react. It is not just the United States which consumes oil from the Persian Gulf; it is all of western Europe and it is Japan.

If the Japanese economy is drastically affected because of the impact of its oil imports having a rapid price increase, or Japan's having to make arrangements with such people as Saddam Hussein in Iraq to get adequate oil supplies, that affects the Japanese economy. Japan is Australia's major trading partner. Can anyone deny that that will not have an impact on Australia's economy? An adverse impact on our economy means a loss of jobs in Australia, a loss of production and the real threat of a recession which will affect ordinary Australians.

I do not deny, and I make no apology for the fact, that Australia has a self-interest in the outcome of the events in the Gulf. I believe that therefore we are justified in being involved in the Gulf by sending the ships as we have announced under the arrangements that we have announced. I believe it would not be acting in Australia's best interests if we had not taken this action. I would point out to Senator Vallentine and others that on the very day the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made his announcement about our involvement in sending the ships I was interviewed and publicly went on the record in support of that decision, and I have seen nothing since to make me change my mind. I believe that the decision was correct in its concept and in its implementation. I accept that in any matter of international affairs with a situation such as exists in the Gulf events will change daily, hourly and weekly, which means that by the time the ships get to the area there may be a different situation which the Australian Government will have to weigh up at that time.

I want to also hit on the head the assertion by Senator Vallentine that Australian ships will be under the direct command of the Americans and under American flag control. That is not the decision that the Australian Government has made. The Australian Government has made it quite clear that the security and the safety of the ships will be the responsibility of the Australian commanders and the Royal Australian Navy. That has been the long term policy of this Government, not just in this particular crisis but in two world wars. We always argued that Australians should be under the command of Australians and should not be put at risk by being under the command of any other nation's authority. I think that Senator Vallentine has put a very exaggerated view about the risk to Australian ships by claiming that they will be under the direct command of the Americans or somebody else. That is clearly not the case in the decisions announced by the Australian Government in recent days.

I notice that Senator Vallentine claimed that all the Arab countries were against Australia. A number of Arab countries have indicated that they support the Americans in one form or another. They include Egypt, Turkey-which is less an Arab country but is a Moslem country-Syria, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and I think also Amman. Again, I admit that none of those countries is a practising democracy as we would like to be the case, but I point out that the Arab world is not united behind Hussein. I think it is quite remarkable in view of the history of the region that a number of Arab countries have indicated in one form or another their support for the Western democracies and the action that they have taken so far.

I say also to Senator Vallentine that I know it is difficult for her to argue her point without it appearing that at times she could be supporting the Iraqi Government. I accept the fact that she under no circumstance supports the Iraqi Government in its activities. She is, as I am, a member of the parliamentary branch of Amnesty International, which has condemned and is horrified by the political oppression that has gone on in Iraq. But the difficulty she has-and I think she has to take note of it-is that in her emotional way of putting her case she could easily be misconstrued by others outside this chamber as supporting in some form or another the activities of the Iraqi Government. I think that she ought to be very careful about that. As I say, I am not going to accuse her of supporting the Iraqi Government because that is preposterous, but if one is arguing her position it has to be very carefully put.

The final thing I want to comment on concerning this issue is the question of perception versus reality. There is one area in the Australian community where I think perception has taken over from reality in this public debate. It is the question of consultation between Australia and the United States of America. I have no doubt that the major criticism made against the Government over this decision is the perception that we made the decision only after we received a phone call from the President of the United States. I am aware of the background to this decision. Before there was any consultation in telephone conversations between the Prime Minister of Australia and the President of America, the Australian Government was already well under way internally in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence and amongst Cabinet Ministers in making the decision that was finally made public I think last Thursday week.

But of course because there was consultation and a conversation between our Prime Minister and the President of America this was a very easy way for people in this country who basically have a cynical or critical view of the United States to portray the situation as though this decision was made only because the Americans wanted us to make it and we jumped when they rang us. It is clear that that is not correct. It indicates that it is very easy for people to promote a view based on a perception which is emotional and very difficult to counter. In a sense in the Australian community at the moment it may not do rational decision making much good if people are willing to believe this sort of perception.

One of my colleagues said to me today that perhaps Bob Hawke should have said to George Bush, `Ring back tomorrow', rather than have the discussion. Clearly that would have been preposterous. That is a flippant suggestion but it is raised because of the perception that some people are willing to promote, that we in Australia do things only when America makes that phone call.

When we look back over the record of this Government in the past seven years we see that there have been many occasions when Australia has indicated its opposition to American foreign policy. In fact, I could probably think of half a dozen right now-among them the MX missile; the American policy in Central America; the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty; Cambodia. There is a whole list of areas where Australia under this Government has had a different foreign policy view from the Americans and has stated it publicly. But it seems that when we do agree with the Americans people forget that we have had differences of opinion and claim that we act only as a clone of America.

Senator Vallentine and others do not promote a decent debate in Australia by creating an emotional perception rather than debating the reality. I think Australia is part of the Western alliance, not just the American alliance. It is the Western alliance of like-minded countries with a commitment to democracy, pluralism and all the freedoms that are written in the UN Charter.

I think that when we have a situation in which one military dictatorship decides of its own volition for its own good to invade and take over another country for its own self-interest, the democracies of the world have no alternative but to be very tough and say, `The line is drawn. We are going to take all action necessary to resolve the situation'. If peaceful mediation is not able to resolve it, then in the end, I hope with UN support, we may have to take even more direct positive action involving some force. We just cannot conduct international diplomacy when we allow an individual-in my view a madman-to ride over all reasonable, rational approaches to diplomacy by using the power of the gun. In the end we have to stand up to that and I think Australia has done the correct thing. I support the motion and hope it can be carried unanimously in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The state of crisis in Kuwait understandably leads us to this being the priority item for our first day of the resumption of Senate sittings. Indeed, weighty contributions have been made from both sides of this chamber and the other place. The motion of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) received unanimous and overwhelming support today not only in the House of Representatives but also in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: We have indeed a grave situation in the Gulf. A highly militaristic dictator has, against all international law, invaded a smaller neighbour. That total invasion has been followed by a further gathering of tanks and scores of thousands of troops on the border of Saudi Arabia. This is a time, then, for resolution and decisiveness and this is at the heart of the motion moved by Senator Button and supported by the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Hill. I, too, support the motion. In the brief time that remains, I wish to underline that support with some remarks of my own and reference to some few matters that have not yet been touched upon in the contributions of other senators.

I wish to congratulate Senator Loosley on his excellent maiden speech in this chamber. All of the intelligence, emotions, commitment, analysis that he put into that first contribution are entirely welcome in this place because they go to the issue of priority at this time-the determination by the nations of the world to stop, to rebuff, this invading dictator of Iraq. I welcome, as well, the contributions, that have been made by my colleagues, Senator Durack, Senator MacGibbon and others that have spoken.

I think this debate has only been spoiled by the contribution that was made by Senator Vallentine. None of us doubt her sincerity. We acknowledge that she has views entirely different from the rest of us, certainly supporters of the Government and the alternative government in this chamber. I know that all senators have an entitlement to express views and we listen to those views carefully. But I doubt whether one senator, apart perhaps from some of the Democrats, was moved by the contribution made by this lone voice. To me her speech displayed a simplistic, sincere naivety that people were made of sugar and spice and all things nice. At a time when there is such enormous risk to the world, to international law, the solution to this grave crisis in the Gulf, is to plant a bed of flowers along the Kuwait border and hope that this militaristic aggressor will somehow withdraw.

All of us recognise that Senator Vallentine gave assent to the proposition that Iraq should withdraw from Kuwait, but, nevertheless, in an appeasing way she sought to set out some case for Iraq's actual claims to Kuwait over the last 25 years. I am dumbfounded that there can be such a set of excuses can be given, even however sincere they may be, from one senator who, as a person, as many know, I respect. But I believe that this is the only detraction of significance that we have had in the debate in the House of Representatives and the Senate today. This totally contrary, and I believe unrepresentative, view in terms of the people of Australia has been put to us by one senator from Western Australia.

The Australian Democrats have a much more minor difference of view. In fact, the amendment that they put forward seeks to take out one subclause of the motion that is before us. The fifth point of the motion speaks of support for the Government's decision to send ships of the Royal Australian Navy to the Middle East to assist. Those are the words that the Democrats are seeking to withdraw from this motion. No doubt Senator Coulter, in speaking after me, will go to why those are the only words that the Democrats are seeking to withdraw. Otherwise they will be supporting the motion. I totally reject the amendment. I think it is entirely inappropriate. But I put their relatively mild opposition down to pragmatic politics.

It is, I believe, understood by us all that the Democrats would have supported ships going if the United Nations had adopted the next stage beyond the Security Council's unanimous acceptance of international sanctions against Iraq-the actual commitment of a military force under the United Nations auspices, such as the force that is there now at the invitation of Kuwait and Saudi Arabia, if that force had been invited after a resolution of the United Nations.

The Democrats are on the record as saying that they would have no difficulty in seeing an Australian military commitment, such as the three ships that we are sending-indeed more-being part of such a United Nations force. They only draw back that one step, I believe, for political, pragmatic reasons. I did not see the same oozing sincerity in the speech earlier today of the Leader, Senator Powell, of the Australian Democrats. So I despise that kind of minority pragmatism by a few who have not sustained their argument in this debate. But, as I say, Senator Vallentine's position is entirely another matter. I believe that she displayed no capacity to judge the kind of gravity in which the world is placed in facing up to Saddam Hussein and his brazen invasion of Kuwait.

I want to make it entirely clear that there is no ambiguity in the Opposition's position of support for the serious decisions that have been taken by this Government and which are before us in the motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government. Right from the outset the Opposition has judged the gravity of this situation and has seen that the invasion of Kuwait must be checked and repelled and that sanctions must be so effective that in fact Iraq withdraws from Kuwait.

In discussions over the past week, some have drawn two lines in their consideration of the Gulf crisis: one, with regard to Iraq's coming to Kuwait and the other, with regard to the threat of a second stage of invasion into Saudi Arabia. Some speculate in those conversations that at least the prompt and effective action by the United States and other allies of Saudi Arabia, in moving on to Saudi soil and being in the Gulf with ships, has deterred what most likely would otherwise have been the further aggression of the Iraqi military into Saudi Arabia. But in this debate I have not heard that anyone is resiling from the goal of all of us as allies in this matter-to see an actual total withdrawal of Iraq from Kuwait. It is no satisfaction for those of us who have taken part in this debate in the Senate to see merely the stopping of a further invasion of Saudi Arabia, a further spreading of the Iraqi menace. So, we need to acknowledge clearly that Saddam Hussein's objective will have been achieved if he is enabled to sit tight in Kuwait. He must fully withdraw.

I note that there has been a minority point of view expressed here by Senator Vallentine and, it would appear, some of the Democrats and perhaps some of the socialist Left of the Labor Party. At least, that is what has been reported to me in informal conversation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in here!

—However, I acknowledge to Senator Collins, who is across the way and appearing to interject, that in the Caucus discussion of this matter there was reportedly unanimous approval of the Government's actions, the Government's announcement and, indeed, of the terms of the motion that has been moved in the House of Representatives by the Prime Minister and in the Senate by the Leader of the Government, Senator Button. I therefore accept that whilst there was an appearance, a perception, put about yesterday that the Government was being hauled over some coals by the socialist Left, the persuasion of the Government has been total, at least for the time being.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a propensity in the Labor Party for that solidarity to be broken down. Let it be fully understood that there is such a bipartisan and genuine support for the proposition that is before us in this motion that there ought to be all the more decisiveness in this chamber to ensure that the objective of Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait is achieved.

I acknowledge as well that there has been some confusion, particularly in the period between 10 and 17 August, about the Prime Minister's announcement in his reference to a blockade and the subsequent contradiction of that by the Foreign Minister. Indeed, even now it is not entirely clear what the rules of engagement are or will be and it is still not clear what the structure of command is in the Gulf. All of us hope that there will be a clear resolution in the United Nations to see that command structure under the blue flag of the United Nations. We also hope there will be a clear and unequivocal resolution for making the sanctions decision effective by a military commitment on the part of the United Nations.

But short of that, the Opposition acknowledges the prompt placement of a military deterrent by the United States; indeed with the full support of Australia and of so many other allies. Indeed, it is pathetic-and rightly pathetic-that the only opposition expressed even within the Arab League to this solidarity with Saudi Arabia and Kuwait has been by Libya and the Palestine Liberation Organisation. Two and a half countries against the world. Two and a half countries are prepared to be influenced by this militaristic dictator of Iraq. I hope that we will see such a United Nations decision as I and many others have expressed a desire to see in the coming days.

I wish to conclude by making just a few references: the response of the Soviet Union under Gorbachev has been singularly positive, along the lines of international law and of enormous significance in its solidarity with the other allies seeking to contain and repel Iraq. This is the outcome, I am sure, of the super power dialogue that we have all not only observed but also encouraged over the last five years at the summit meetings and in disarmament conferences. Let us be absolutely sure in this Senate that it is peace through strength. It is through an ultimate military deterrent in the hands of the West-in particular the United States-that we have seen the success of that dialogue. That has been an essential reason why we have seen such unanimity in the Security Council and indeed in the deployment and cooperation of Soviet forces along with the West in this Gulf crisis.

I would also like to make this brief observation about assessing Australia's military capacity. In all our debates that sometimes focus on Fortress Australia, there has been an underplaying by this Government of the need for a military capacity such as we now see is required in the Gulf. Too many members of the Government of all factions, have tried to assert that the only military capacity that we need is the littoral defence of the territory of Australia and clearly this is an inadequate assessment of our military capacity. We do need to deter aggression in the way that we are now committed in the Gulf. We do need to act in consort with allies from time to time, as we are now. We do need to keep open sea lanes and lines of communication. We do need to safeguard essential world resources for their access by the nations of the world. There are lessons too with regard to the need of a two-ocean navy and also lessons with regard to the need for immediate response by all three of Australia's Services.

There is not sufficient time for me to go on to my own assessment of the instruments-the mad, brutal and ruthless instruments-that are in the hands of the dictator of Iraq. I cannot refer to his military capacity or to Islam and his call for a jihad; to his calling up an anti-establishment socialist reaction against the sovereign sheikhs in the various Arab countries; or to his brutal intimidation of his own Cabinet colleagues-disagreeable generals or disagreeable minorities such as the Kurds.

I have no time to refer to the instrument that he has now placed in his own hands of horrifically using foreigners as hostages, as human shields in his military pursuits. These instruments are unusual, but they are instruments in the hands of a ruthless man. That is why I welcome all those in this debate who have talked about a time for resolution, a time for decision, a time for action and a time for constraining such a person with these instruments that he is in fact using.

I conclude by saying that from the beginning right through to this point and indeed in the days ahead, the Opposition stands ready to see not only in support of the motion as before us, but in a bipartisan and genuine way, a resolute action by Australia along with allies to gain the objectives that we all hope for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President, it is said that those who do not know history are condemned to repeat it. In Saddam Hussein we see a man who does know history and yet is intent in making us all relive it. And what is this history that Saddam Hussein is so keen on recreating? It is the history of Assyria and Babylon, it is the history of the kings like Ashurbanipal, whom Saddam Hussein so readily worships, that he wishes to impose upon the rest of the world. It will be a world in which we will see tyranny triumph; it will be a world in which the taking of hostages, which we have already seen in the last couple of weeks, will be repeated again and again and again. It will be a world in which force and brutality will be allowed to triumph over good and the right of ordinary people in every nation for self-determination.

SPEECH.PARA: Tonight there have been a number of speakers who opposed what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and this Government have done in sending our ships to the Middle East. They said, amongst other things, that it was something that the United Nations should do. But we have heard these same cries before. We heard them in 1928 when the League of Nations brought about the signing of the general treaty on the renunciation of war, the preamble to which said that the signatories were persuaded that the time has come when a frank renunciation of war as an instrument of national policy should be made, to the end that the peaceful and friendly relations then existing between their people may be perpetuated. Yet by the end of the next decade we had seen the invasion of Ethiopia and of Abyssinia, the annexation of the Sudetenland and Austria, and German tanks rolling remorselessly through Poland and France. So much for the appeasement of the 1920s and 1930s, and so much also for the appeasement of the 1990s!

From those people who have been very forthright in their apologies for Saddam Hussein there has been criticism that what we are doing is contrary to international law. That is not the case. The actions which we have taken and which other nations of the free world have taken are not only justified under article 51 of the United Nations Charter, but they are also justified under customary international law. In 1962, when the United States brought about a blockade of Cuba, on 23 October, the day after, the Council of the Organisation of American States resolved that member states take all measures, individually and collectively, including the use of armed force, to prevent the Government of Cuba becoming an active threat to the peace and security of the continent. Those same sentiments have been echoed by the Arab nations in their condemnation of the actions of Saddam Hussein and in their endorsement of the actions of the free world in opposing his brutality and his tyranny and in supporting and imposing a blockade upon Iraq.

The only thing that is achieved by the vacillation of the Australian Democrats and their friend Senator Vallentine is the wholesale ravaging by Iraq of Kuwait. I want to know how many Kuwaiti women have to be raped, how many innocent civilians have to die and how many more small nations must be ground under the heels of tyrants before the Australian Democrats and Senator Vallentine find some common sense, find a collective backbone and find the will, the courage and the commitment to stand up for free nations throughout the world and to recognise our responsibilities as international citizens. We do have responsibilities as international citizens, responsibilities that grow more and more important as we see the changing of the world, and as we see the end of the Cold War era. These are responsibilities which Australia as a nation and which Australians as responsible human beings must embrace wholeheartedly. These are responsibilities which I am very pleased to say the Government and the Opposition recognise, and I have great satisfaction in saying on behalf of the National Party that we willingly associate ourselves with this motion.

I would add as a personal note that I had to think very long and hard on this matter because I have never come into this Parliament wanting to ask another Australian to go to war; I never wanted to ask any young Australian of my age to do anything that I was not willing to do myself. It would have brought me a great deal more personal satisfaction, Madam Acting Deputy President, if I had been one of the people going there rather than one of the people having to make the decision. But the decision has to be made and I believe that it is a time for resolution, a time for courage and a time for a commitment to a world order where peace can be brought about.

We are running very short on time this evening, so I will conclude with one thought, a thought that was written by Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery at the end of his book, History of Warfare in an epilogue on the ideal of peace. He said this:

The true soldier is the enemy of the beast in man and of none other, and it is a soldier's hope that one day will come, a golden sunset, when the last post will be sounded over enmity and strife and a glorious sunrise when reveille will waken the nations of the world to an era of goodwill and peace.
This can be achieved only if nations such as Australia have the courage of their convictions, have the willpower to back up the words with action to ensure a free world for all.

On behalf of the National Party we welcome the Prime Minister's statement today; we wish the crews of Australia's ships a safe voyage and God speed, and I wish them to know, and we should recognise, that they are acting to bring about a new world, a new world order and a new security for all and that their contribution will be valued for many, many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just cannot help but reflect on the closing remarks of Senator O'Chee and suggest that perhaps when that sunrise and that sunset occur he may be looking in the other direction and may miss them altogether, because indeed the conditions of the recent past are quite unlike those conditions which have obtained previously, particularly in relation to the uniformity of United Nations agreement in relation to sanctions. We may indeed be at the dawn of that day, but unfortunately many people, as I have indicated, may be looking the other way. They are looking back in history instead of looking forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Before I begin let me just make one remark. I understand that in the early part of this evening several members of the Opposition were critical of the Australian Democrats for not being present at the beginning of this debate. I just want to put on record that we obtained our copies of the Budget Speech at 7 o'clock, unlike Opposition senators, who I believe obtained theirs at 5.30, and we were rather busy with that Budget material.

The present situation is indeed grave, and it is one in which it is extremely difficult to make black and white judgments. Throughout this debate one of the things I have found rather depressing is the attempt to gloss over many issues in which there are indeed shades of grey and to misrepresent the case which has been put by the Democrats and was also put by Senator Vallentine. For instance, it has often been claimed that the exhibition of nuclear capability by Western nations throughout the period since the Second World War has prevented the outbreak of a further world war, perhaps with the use of nuclear weapons. Indeed I think that was hinted at tonight when Senator Baden Teague used the line again: peace through strength. I merely observe as a person who has worked in science for most of my working life until I was elected to the Senate that it is very difficult to draw a judgment from an experiment in which there is only one observation.

There has been the exhibition of nuclear strength since the 1940s and we have avoided a major world conflagration using nuclear weapons. But that by no means indicates logically that had the trillions of dollars that have been spent on military preparedness for war been spent in addressing the serious problems which beset the world in terms of the differences between rich and poor, the differences in access to resources, and the problems which beset us because of lack of democracy-to which many honourable senators have drawn attention this evening in the debate-then it is at least arguable that the world may well have been a safer place now than had that money been spent as it has been on military preparedness. I do not think anybody can gainsay that argument. It is at least as plausible.

A similar situation obtains here. There is a case to be made-and it has been made by the Government and the Opposition-that following the imposition of the United Nations sanctions it was necessary to go in and insist that those sanctions were backed up by military force so that essentially a blockade was imposed on Iraq. The contrary view, which the Democrats and Senator Vallentine are putting, is that the United Nations, for the first time with almost uniformity, has imposed sanctions, and we believe it would have been wiser to wait and see whether those sanctions could operate, given the fact that this is the first time in history that there has been such agreement between the nations of the United Nations with respect to the imposition of sanctions. We will never know-as this was again an experiment of one-which course of action was objectively the correct action.

We believe it is a great pity, given that this is the first occasion on which the United Nations has imposed sanctions, that America, Australia and a number of other nations were not prepared to wait just a little longer to see whether those sanctions would not become effective. Should they become effective the sunset and the dawning to which Senator O'Chee was referring would have been visible. We would have had a demonstration of circumstances which in future would have been a very powerful object lesson. We could have turned around the trillions of dollars that have been spent on military preparedness to peaceful settlements and the imposition of sanctions imposed by the United Nations would indeed have been effective because they had been effective in this case.

In opposing the particular paragraph in the Government's motion we are not, and I believe Senator Vallentine was not, in any sense condoning the actions of Iraq or Iraq's dictator, nor are we excusing those actions. By pointing out the history which has led to this situation we are attempting to draw attention to the fact that it is extremely unwise to go into a situation like a bull in a china shop and be unaware of the longer term consequences which flow from that action. There is-for the reasons that have been mentioned, particularly by Senator Vallentine tonight-a long history of anti-Western feeling throughout the Arab nations. The imposition of sanctions by the United Nations, of which the Arab nations are a part, may well not have allayed the longer term objections or the augmentation of ill feeling towards Western nations which may well flow from the imposition of a military closure of Iraq at this time. Had we delayed a little longer, and had the United Nations decided to impose that military blockade, then I believe the possibility of a longer term Arab backlash to that action would have been very much muted.

I found that much of the argument, particularly that put by the Opposition and to some extent by the Government, somewhat hypocritical when several speakers who have spoken about the rule of law, and the rule of international law, are the same people who have been party to the sale of military equipment to other nations, nations which may provoke a situation similar to the one that we now have in the Middle East and, indeed, did not raise any serious objections when countries such as America invaded countries such as Panama and Granada, or when the Indonesian nation invaded East Timor. I think, as Senator Powell pointed out, that we have compounded the situation in East Timor because we have signed an agreement with the Indonesians to exploit oil which really should belong to the East Timorese people.

That brings me to the final point that I want to make. We need to see this war in a somewhat longer context. We are seeing a run-down in the non-renewable resources of this planet. We are seeing the larger populations more voraciously devouring the last resources of the planet. We will, unless we are careful, see more and more of these conflicts arising. To be spending money on military preparedness without addressing the very serious problems of resource depletion, and the inequity of distribution and access to those resources, is simply to leave to our children a situation in which these types of conflicts which we see in the Middle East will become more general, more widespread and more frequent. In that context it was particularly distressing to see in the Budget brought down by the Government this evening, a decrease in the amount of money devoted to those environmental considerations which address these problems while at the same time spending substantial amounts on military preparedness.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 9 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the national working group submitted its report and recommendations for an alternative strategy for screw-worm fly defences as foreshadowed by the Minister on 20 February 1990 when announcing the closure of the Papua New Guinea screw-worm fly facility at Laloki; if so, what is the strategy.

(2) If an alternative strategy is yet to be devised, is the Government satisfied that, in case of a screw-worm fly incursion into Australia, effective eradication, or at least successful containment can be undertaken.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. Australia's SWF preparedness strategy has, since the early 1980s been based on four key elements:
- a substantial recurrent expenditure program to provide an emergency response capability using the sterile insect release method (SIRM) technology at a facility in Laloki, Papua New Guinea (PNG);
- monitoring and surveillance activities in the Torres Strait/Cape York area, at ports and off-shore by quarantine authorities;
- detection activities within Australia by animal health and abattoir inspection authorities; and
- development of nationally co-ordinated strategic and operational plans for responding to an actual incursion of SWF.

This strategy orientation has been largely influenced by the judgement that natural spread of the SWF population (Old World species) endemic in PNG, across the Torres Strait Islands and down the York Peninsula of northern Australia posed a very real entry threat. While this judgement was based on scientific evidence available in the late 1970s, it is now clear that the risk of SWF entry by natural spread from PNG is very low. Ten years of intensive monitoring of the Torres Strait region has shown no evidence of any SWF population movement from Papua New Guinea.
However, no scope is seen for terminating or winding back the Torres Strait/Cape York monitoring program.

Significant limitations have also been identified with the development work to achieve a SIRM based emergency response capability at Laloki. These problems relate to the lack of sovereign control over the Laloki site, throughput capacity of the irradiation equipment, difficulties in developing field release techniques and the possible need to use strains of SWF other than the PNG strain for SIRM in an outbreak.

In light of the revised assessment of the risk of a natural incursion of SWF and, given the limitations of the SIRM development work in PNG, the work at the Laloki facility will not be continued. However, SIRM is the only proven technology for eradication of SWF, having been used by the USA over a 30-year period to eliminate populations of the New World species from North and Central America, and a program of work has been developed for reconsidering the role which that technology will play in Australia's SWF strategy.

The national working group report sets out `blueprints' for three different SIRM capabilities for Australia's future SWF preparedness strategy and recommends that they be fully developed and costed over the next twelve months before a final decision is taken by Government and industry. Immediate action to address the lack of a short term SIRM capability for Australia has been taken up and satisfactorily resolved in discussions with the United States Department of Agriculture to develop a framework agreement for access to the expertise it has proven in field operations. In effect, this will involve topping up the considerable body of new technology that was developed at Laloki with relevant elements of the US SIRM capability so that Australia can mount a SIRM program.

The programs that have complemented the Laloki SIRM project will continue to play a crucial role in the future. Given that it is no longer realistic to assume that a SWF incursion could be quickly eradicated, it is extremely important to up-grade and give greater focus to monitoring, surveillance, detection and outbreak planning measures.

Expenditure is also recommended in a new area of preparedness, viz the development of a model taking into account the economic, climatic and biological variables relevant to predicting the likelihood of SWF establishment in Australia, its possible spread, production losses and control costs. The threat/consequence model will utilise objective assessments of the elements supporting SWF incursion threat judgements made in this report, but far more importantly, it will provide guidance to decision makers as to which long term SIRM option to pursue and for the management of any SWF incursion in Australia.
(2) Not applicable.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 9 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service received the final report of the research project undertaken in New Zealand referred to in paragraph 4 of his predecessor's answer to my question on notice No 1285; if so: (a) what were the major conclusions of the report; and (b) what is the service's assessment of the risk of chalkbrood entering Australia in honey and honey pre-packs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) received the final report of the New Zealand research project in December 1989.
(a) The report's major conclusions were:
(i) A more sensitive test has been developed that can detect very low levels of the chalkbrood fungus.
(ii) Viable chalkbrood spores were detected in 12 of 15 samples tested from honey produced and packaged in both the North and South Islands of New Zealand.

(iii) A significant reduction in the number of viable chalkbrood spores occurred in honey held at 65 degrees C for 4 hours and at 70 degrees C for 1 hour. No viable chalkbrood spores were detected in honey held at 65 degrees C for 8 hours or at 70 degrees C for 2 hours.
(iv) Samples from the honeys tested as per 2 (ii) above were subjected to 70 degrees C for 2 hours and no viable chalkbrood spores were detected.
(b) Following circulation of an AQIS position paper, AQIS's assessment was that the risk posed by importation of honey of introducing chalkbrood into Australia can be addressed by requiring that:
(i) honey be certified as originating from a country known to be free of chalkbrood; or

(ii) honey be accompanied by certification stating that all parts of the product have been held at 70 degrees C for at least 2 hours. Representative samples of the treated honey would also be tested for presence of the chalkbrood fungus by a method approved by AQIS, to gauge the effectiveness of this requirement.

AQIS has sought information from New Zealand authorities to gauge the practicality of the above heat processing, given concerns in Australia on whether adequate technology exists to process at the required level. Once a reply is received, AQIS will consult with the Honey Research Council and the beekeeping industry to finalise this issue. If the required level is technically acceptable AQIS will contact all chalkbrood affected countries to inform them of AQIS' new requirements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 9 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What funding has been provided or committed by the Federal Government to Tasmania for forest and forest-related issues during the period 1 November 1988 to 31 December 1994.
(2) How many separate and different commitments have there been.
(3) What has been the amount involved in each area.
(4) What is the specific purpose assigned to each.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since 1 November 1988 the Commonwealth has provided or committed $63 788 390 to Tasmania for forest and forest related matters for the period up to 31 December 1994.
(2) There have been five separate commitments.
(3) Funding for each of those areas is as follows:
Tasmanian Forest Industry Package
Forests and Forest Industry Strategy
National Afforestation Program
Tasmanian Woodchip Research Fund
Dry sclerophyll forest research
TOTAL
(4) The specific purposes assigned to each are as follows:
Tasmanian Forest Industry Package

In November 1988 the Commonwealth and Tasmanian Governments agreed on a package of measures to deal with a range of issues arising out of the Helsham inquiry into Tasmania's Lemonthyme and Southern Forests. As access for logging operations in certain State forests was withdrawn by World Heritage listing, a $50 million industry package over five years has been committed by the Commonwealth to assist the State in restructuring its forest industry. The measures currently being put in place include: an education and training program and facilities to improve the value-adding skill base; research and intensive management and development of native forests and plantations to augment the forest resource; development of value-adding processes that diversify the veneer and sawlog sectors.
Tasmanian Forests and Forest Industry Strategy

In December 1989 the Commonwealth agreed to provide $10 million to assist Tasmania in the development of a Forests and Forest Industry Strategy. The Council which is to undertake this task includes representatives of government, industry, unions, and conservation groups. The Strategy is to provide the framework for a long term resolution of forestry issues in Tasmania.

The Commonwealth funding has been committed for the following purposes: to provide for alternative timber harvest scheduling and roading until the Strategy has been developed; to provide additional research and co-ordination capacity to support the Strategy's development; to assist the establishment of a centre at Geeveston designed to demonstrate the importance of forests for both conservation and development; to provide for research trials to assist the veneer industry; to help small scale sawmillers improve efficiency.
National Afforestation Program

This three year program was introduced across Australia by the Commonwealth in 1988 to help develop an additional resource base for the forest products industries. Tasmania will receive $2,788,900 to assist the establishment of 4,650 hectares of eucalypt plantation. A further $722,050 has been committed to Tasmania for plantation research.
Tasmanian Woodchip Research Fund

The Tasmanian Woodchip Research Program was established in 1989 with a commitment by the woodchip export companies to contribute $350,000 per annum for five years. The Commonwealth contributed $100,000 in 1988-89 to the Program. Fifteen research projects aimed at environmental matters relating to woodchipping operations have been approved for funding under the Program.
Dry Sclerophyll Forest Research

The Commonwealth provided $87,440 to Tasmania to assist research into the adequacy of existing conservation measures for dry sclerophyll forest. This forest type is one of the major resources of the forest industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 9 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has the Government taken, or does it intend to take, on the 1988 meat industry study which highlighted the array of unnecessary, restrictive and conflicting meat laws now on the statute books of the States and the Commonwealth.

(2) Is it correct that: (a) meat sales and handling are governed by 382 Acts of Parliament and Regulations; (b) meat inspection and retail outlet standards are controlled by 42 Acts and Regulations; and (c) meat has 39 different definitions in these Acts and Regulations.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The great majority of the laws identified by the `Meat Regulations Study' commissioned by the Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC) are enacted in State legislation and are therefore beyond the direct control of the Commonwealth.

The study found that there were actually very few restrictive provisions imposed on the meat industry and there were no conflicting or inconsistent provisions within a State or Territory, but it did identify some inconsistencies and overlaps between States and Territories. The study considered the main problem with the legislation was the amount impacting not only on the meat industry, but on retailing in general, rather than a restraint of trade or inefficiency and confusion caused by any inconsistencies.

The meat industry is following up the recommendations of the study and I understand the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia is planning to liaise with State Governments to determine whether the legislation involved can be rationalised. The Government will, of course, support any move to achieve rationalisation between State legislation or between that of the States and the Commonwealth. At this stage we are awaiting the outcome of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation initiatives before deciding whether it is necessary or desirable to have the matter considered by the Australian Agricultural Council.

(2) The AMLRDC study identified 382 Acts, supporting Regulations and amending legislation as having an impact on the meat retailing industry. Of these, 42 Acts and Regulations give inspectors power to ensure compliance. The study also found 39 provisions defining meat. I have no information available to me that would contradict these figures.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: South Pacific Forum: FLNKS Observer Status

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 11 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the Government support the call by the Melanesian Spearhead Group to allow the FLNKS observer status at the South Pacific Forum, if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Melanesian Spearhead Group's recent decision to further seek observer status for the FLNKS at the South Pacific Forum is inconsistent with the consensus reached at the 1986 Forum meeting which limited observer status to Pacific island governments on the verge of achieving self-government or independence. Australia supported that consensus.

During my recent visit to Melanesia, I took the opportunity to discuss this question in each country. I came away with the impression that observer status would be difficult at this stage because of reluctance on the part of Forum member countries to change the existing eligibility criteria. There may, however, be other avenues for enabling the FLNKS as well as the other partner to the Matignon Accords, the RPCR, to present its views informally to Forum leaders.

Australia has encouraged the Forum Secretary-General to explore all possible avenues towards a consensus on this issue, which is of course one to be decided not by Australia alone, but by all the Forum countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister aware of press reports, most recently in the Sun Herald newspaper on 29 April and 6 May 1990, on the research carried out by Melbourne accountancy lecturer, Barbara Smith, describing tax avoidance schemes based on current low levels of withholding tax on interest earned by non-residents.

(2) Is the Minister aware that the report quotes an Australian Tax Office spokesperson as stating that Tax Office calculations put the tax avoided through those schemes between 1982 and 1988 at up to $500 million.
(3) Does the Minister agree that such a loss of revenue warrants urgent action and can he advise which measures the Government intends to take and when it is intended to introduce them.
(4) Does the Government intend to take any action before the end of the financial year, given that any increase in the withholding tax rates would result in substantial savings to the public purse.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When I saw the allegations made by Melbourne academic, Ms. Barbara Smith, describing alleged tax avoidance schemes involving withholding tax on interest paid to non-residents, I immediately sought an explanation from the Commissioner of Taxation. In seeking this explanation, I was mindful that over recent years the Hawke Labor Government has taken action on a number of fronts to ensure that Australia's economy was not disadvantaged through the various taxation arrangements that existed with our international trading partners. The particular legislative changes I will deal with shortly. However we also recognise that quite legitimate family and commercial arrangements exist. Given the nature and composition of Australian society, it is not exceptional that income does flow overseas.

(2) Despite what amounts the press reports claim, the fact of the matter is that the Tax Office investigation into the alleged rort is still in progress and until it is completed, it is premature to give a figure involved. Notwithstanding that, preliminary enquiries reveal that Ms. Smith's estimate of $1 billion is hopelessly exaggerated. Her estimate is clearly flawed because it:
- ignores the effect of genuine arrangements;
- fails to take into account changes in the level of foreign debt in recent years;
- disregards changes in interest rates over the period; and
- ignores the impact of the dividend imputation system.

(3) This Government has over successive years taken decisive action to implement significant and strategic taxation initiatives in legislation to stamp out these and other practices in order to protect the revenue and to ensure that Australia's economy is not disadvantaged through the various taxation arrangements with our major international trading partners. For example:

- 1987: introduction of the Thin Capitalisation rules with effect from 1 July 1987, which deny deductibility of interest payments by companies, trusts and partnerships where certain debt : equity ratios are exceeded;
- 1988: introduction of the Debt Creation rules with effect from 1 July 1987 which deny deductibility of interest payments in certain capital restructuring arrangements;
- 1989: release of draft Accruals Tax legislation;
- from 1 July 1990: proposed introduction of the Accruals Tax legislation which will bring to book unremitted income which had been accruing offshore in non-taxable forms; and
- from 1 July 1991: proposed introduction of the Passive Investment Fund rules which will supplement the Accruals Tax measures.

In addition, the Commissioner advised that the level of compliance with the laws in this area is a matter which the ATO has had under active investigation, as evidenced by some recent successes in court. As with all taxes, the ATO seeks a high level of voluntary compliance. But where that fails, the full force of the law will be used to assist. Investigations of cases in breach of the rules have been and are being vigorously pursued and contested with some notable successes. In the Melbourne Branch Office alone, the ATO has 210 such cases pending, involving $14 million tax in dispute. Income Tax Rulings have also been issued to confirm the Commissioner's attack on arrangements where non-resident beneficiaries were never intended to receive the benefit of purported distributions. The Taxation Office recognises that in this and other areas it has to remain vigilant to protect the revenue from schemes which seek to exploit the taxation laws. While the ATO is confident of success, the work is resource intensive and there are difficulties at times in obtaining evidence, particularly from overseas. With the proposed introduction of provisions relating to the admissibility of documents maintained in foreign jurisdictions, the ATO will be able to go a long way to redress the position and continue to ensure that the taxation laws are fully complied with.

(4) Pending the outcome of the ATO's investigation, the Government considers that the existing legislation and the success of the ATO's attack are sufficient at this point in time to stem the alleged withholding tax rorts. As regards the withholding tax rate, the Commissioner said that the taxation law has for many years provided that distributions to non-resident beneficiaries of Australian resident trusts attract a withholding tax of 10. That income may also be taxed by the country of residence of the beneficiary. Any suggestion to increase the rate of interest withholding tax would be out of step with most other countries and international standards, would require revisiting all our double tax treaties and would impinge upon the normal commercial raising of funds from overseas. From a commercial standpoint we must be in step with our major trading partners and accordingly no change to the rate of withholding tax is anticipated at this time.
