QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 17 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When did the French Space Agency, CERES, erect the 2 satellite beacons, which formed part of the DORIS worldwide satellite tracking system, in Australia.
(2) Where did CERES erect these 2 beacons.
(3) Which Australian Government department gave CERES permission to erect these beacons in Australia.
(4) Did the French authorities obtain clearance from the Department of Defence to erect these beacons; if not, why not.
(5) Why have these beacons remained in place for 3 years if they have not received clearance.

(6) (a) Has the Australian Government asked the French Government to make a formal submission on the DORIS system through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade; if so, when did they make this request; (b) has the French Government made such a submission; if so, when; and (c) will the Australian Government respond favourably to this request; if so, why.
(7) Is there a link between the DORIS system and the military version of the SPOT-2 satellite; if so, what is the link.
(8) Did the New Zealand Government order removal of a similar beacon placed on the Chatham Islands without its knowledge.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The French National Space Centre (CNES) based in Toulouse, France, originally approached the then Division of National Mapping of the Department of Resources and Energy for permission to erect DORIS (Doppler Orbitography and Radiopositioning Integrated by Satellite) satellite ground beacons in Australia. The Division of National Mapping was amalgamated with the Australian Survey Office in July 1987 to become the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group of the Department of Administrative Services, which has provided the following answers to parts (l)-(5) of the question.

(1), (2) &(3) In February 1987 the French National Space Centre erected a beacon at Orroral Valley, ACT. Permission was given by the then Division of National Mapping. In August 1987 the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group erected a beacon, for which it had given permission, at Yarragadee, Western Australia. The beacons were erected subject to finalisation of an agreement on their operation.
(4) No. However the Department of Defence has since been included in the interdepartmental consultative process.

(5) The beacons have not been activated. ANSWER.PARA: (1) People with infectious diseases may be allowed to enter Australia depending on the disease and the purpose and duration of the applicant's proposed stay in Australia as well as the likely cost to the public health and welfare systems as determined by a Medical Officer of the Commonwealth. Applicants with active Tuberculosis (TB) cannot enter Australia until they are made medically non-infectious and those with a history of TB are placed on an undertaking to report to State or Territory health authorities. HIV/AIDS is a cause for rejection of applicants for permanent entry due to their potential cost.

(2) All applicants for entry to Australia are required to meet the health requirements given effect by the Migration Regulations. Those seeking permanent or longterm temporary entry must undergo a thorough medical and radiological examination. Mandatory HIV/AIDS testing was introduced on 19 December 1989 for permanent entry and can be requested on clinical grounds for long term temporary entry. Applicants for short term entry may be required to undergo medical and radiological examination where their health is assessed to be of special significance.

(3) The health standards are determined on the advice of the Minister for Community Services and Health and are designed in Australia's interests to protect the community from public health risks, to contain public expenditure on health and welfare and to safeguard access by Australians to public health facilities and services. Countries design their health policies to meet their own particular situation and needs. Australia's policy is not dissimilar to that of the United States of America (USA), particularly in relation to permanent entry. A major difference, however, is that the USA's legislation does incorporate a detailed list of prescribed diseases which result in the rejection of applicants. Australia prescribes only TB in regulation and a case by case approach is used for assessing all other diseases and conditions against medical guidelines.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 30 May 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) To what extent do Australian cattle suffer with the disease brucellosis.
(2) Can this disease be passed on to humans; if so, what measures are in place to prevent this happening.
(3) Are cattle suffering from the disease slaughtered for human consumption and their meat sold in shops.
(4) Is any meat from brucellosis-infected cattle exported from Australia; if so, is the meat supplied for human consumption totally free of brucellosis after it is slaughtered.
(5) Is there a way of eliminating brucellosis from cattle after slaughter.
(6) Apart from inoculation, is there any method of stopping the spread of brucellosis in cattle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (4) Australia was declared free of bovine brucellosis in July 1989. Freedom from brucellosis is declared once all cattle herds have been assessed, by laboratory examination of sera, and there is no known remaining brucellosis infection. Monitoring of cattle for that disease continues, particularly at slaughter.

(2) Bovine brucellosis can be passed on to humans. The most effective method to prevent infection of humans is to eradicate the disease from cattle in Australia. Hygienic preparation, handling and treatment of foodstuffs, eg milk, meat and meat products, can minimise risk of infection where bovine brucellosis has not been eradicated. The disease is primarily of concern to occupationally exposed groups, in particular veterinarians, dairy farmers and abattoir workers. Consumers are not at risk if meat is handled and cooked by normal hygienic methods.
(3) Cattle showing clinical signs of brucellosis are not slaughtered for human consumption.

(5) Carcase parts (uteri, testicles etc) which may harbour Brucella bacteria may be hygienically separated from meat during the dressing process and condemned. Brucella bacteria may also be eliminated from meat by cooking.

(6) The spread of brucellosis in cattle may be prevented by separation of herds which tests show are clear of brucellosis from other herds and, wherever appropriate, destruction of infected animals. Quarantine and destruction of infected cattle would be used to prevent spread should the disease recur in Australia.

(2) Was the RAAF correct in understanding that 4 Army personnel were planned to remain at Casey between voyages 4 and 5 to assist them.
(3) Is it true that as a result of an `administrative error' the Army personnel continued with the ship.

(4) What is the reason for the contradiction regarding the use of Army personnel to construct the Casey runway as mentioned in the October 1989 publication and the response given to my question in the Senate Estimates Committee meeting on 17 May 1990. (Hansard Ref. pC160).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(4) There is no contradiction. Treaty Exchange information reflects intentions for the following season. The material is often prepared well in advance of detailed operational planning and subsequent adjustments are often made. It is for this reason that Treaty Exchange information also provides advice on modifications to aspects of the previous season's information. The information provided in the Estimates Committee reflected what happened.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 16 October 1989:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) With reference to the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council Report 1988-89, which on pages 15 and 16, refers to a number of issues which it considers deserves further consideration in the cosmetics industry, namely:
(a) the need to define the line between therapeutic goods and cosmetics described in pseudo-scientific terms and to develop a standard terminology;
(b) the need to put the manufacturers name and address on all products;
(c) the need for a `use by' date;
(d) the possibility of establishing a system similar to CODEX;
(e) guidelines into health food outlets, backyarders and mail-order firms;
(f) the need for consumer education and information about cosmetics;
(g) the need for clear, consistent labelling to prevent deception and facilitate comparisons at the point of sale, and
(h) the need for an accurate indication of the likely effects of cosmetics on various types of skins,

and in view of the Council's considered opinion that there would be benefit in the establishment of a working party of the Consumer Goods Advisory Committee to consider the above issues, has such a body been established or is it contemplated.
(2) Will a working party investigate all the problem areas identified by the Advisory Council.
(3) Will this be a prelude to legislation to tighten up on what the Advisory Committee obviously considers to be highly unsatisfactory aspects of the industry.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the views of the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, as expressed in its 1988-89 annual report, on the cosmetics industry. I believe that Council has provided most useful advice on this subject.
I will be giving consideration to the report and have asked the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to consult further with those having expertise in this area on the development of a draft standard.
(2) The Bureau will be taking into account all of the matters identified in Council's report.

(3) I do not anticipate that it will be necessary to introduce new legislation as the consumer protection provisions which currently exist in Commonwealth, State and Territory legislation provide sufficient legislative powers to address the problem.
